PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, will be absent from the chamber until 18 June inclusive. Senator Cook is attending the International Labour Organisation conference in Geneva. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio should be directed to me, and any questions in relation to those portfolios he represents should be directed to Senator Bolkus.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement of May 1989 that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we are all in a position of service, responsibility and duty to the nation where there is a fundamental requirement for integrity, probity, the ordinary decencies of public life and honourable conduct.

Given that members of the Australian public now know that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, for political convenience, lied to them time and time again before the last election and since, why should Australians now trust in and believe anything these people say?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate knows, Mr Keating is now a backbencher in the House of Representatives. As far as the Prime Minister is concerned, the Prime Minister has on numerous occasions made statements about appropriate standards of government and has adhered to them. The reason why the Australian people should look to this Government for leadership in the future is that it has a leader who has been immensely successful and will continue to be so. The reason for that is not only the policy superiority of this Government but the intellectual leadership which this Government has had over many years and will continue to have into the 1990s. The Opposition really should not today try to take too much comfort from a temporary discomfiture in the Government as a result of the speculation and so on which went on over the weekend prior to the ballot which took place for the leadership today.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a great tendency amongst Opposition senators to count their chickens before they have hatched. They have done that before as they have watched the unemployment figures rise; they have got excited and started to count their chickens. They did that in 1990; they tried to count their chickens before they were hatched. Mr Greiner did it in New South Wales. Members of the Opposition have done it in almost every conceivable election in the last few years.

As Mr Wal Murray said last week, the Liberals think they are God's gift to the political world. Opposition members may think that, but there are a lot of very important issues facing this country and many difficulties for this Government at the present time. Those issues will be dealt with. I would not get too excited about today's events in the light of the question which has been asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which goes to the core of the question in the first instance. If Mr Hawke, as we now know, lied to the Australian people before the last election as to his intentions, why should they trust him now?

—Every time before an election the Opposition says that one cannot trust the Prime Minister. In political life that is always said. Ultimately, the people of Australia will make a judgment about that issue and I am quite confident about the nature of it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the ministerial statement on defence policy delivered by Senator Robert Ray on 30 May. In that statement, Senator Ray referred to the outcome of the review of the guidelines on defence exports and noted that existing foreign policy criteria for considering applications for exports had been strengthened. Can the Minister provide more detail with regard to these new guidelines and their operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to spell out a little more detail on this subject in response to Senator Childs's question. Prior to this year's review, the foreign policy component of the guidelines referred only to the non-export of relevant goods `in particular cases where specific foreign policy interests outweigh export benefits'. That kind of language was clearly only a very general criterion. Therefore, it was thought desirable to provide the relevant interdepartmental committee with more specific examples of those situations where foreign policy considerations needed to be taken into account.

ANSWER.PARA: Four specific examples have been identified and are now part of the guidelines. They are as follows: first, where Australia's foreign policy and trade interests could be adversely affected by the reactions of third countries; secondly, where the proposed country of destination is involved in internal or external conflicts or there is a state of tension which indicates conflict is likely; thirdly, where exports could potentially contribute to destabilisation in the region concerned; and, fourthly, where the country is acquiring non-conventional weaponry in contravention of Australia's non-proliferation interests.

I should stress that these guidelines are just that; guidelines for the interdepartmental committee in its consideration prior to making recommendations to the Minister for Defence, whose responsibility for final decision making all this is. They are not intended to be precisely prescriptive and will obviously need to be taken into account and applied on a case by case basis. However, they do represent a clear and, I hope, unambiguous statement of the Government's concern to ensure that important strategic, external policy and human rights considerations are not prejudiced by the defence exports policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the comments made by him in early February 1990, and particularly on 8 February 1990, that a deal had been done between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating over the leadership succession. In particular, I refer to the Minister's remarks that `it's been worked out for a very long time'. When did the Minister become aware of the terms of a deal which had been agreed between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating over the leadership? Will he now tell the Senate what he knows about this deal?

—I am not sure where the honourable senator got the quotation from of what I allegedly said on 8 February 1990. Let me say that I have no recollection of saying that a deal had been worked out for a very long time. I do not believe I did say that. I did say that I suspected an agreement had been reached. I said that only in the context of the way in which Mr Keating and Mr Hawke were working very well together at that time-and they were; they were working together very effectively. In so far as my knowledge of any agreement, I had no knowledge of any alleged agreement until last week.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports that the Shepparton Preserving Co. Ltd (SPC) has decided to restore to its employees the conditions they had agreed to give up in order to help the company through its economic difficulties? Are these reports correct? If so, can the Minister advise the Senate whether this development vindicates the Government's reform of the system which was designed to encourage workplace level bargaining, with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission mediating between management and workers in the interests of fairness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened at SPC has been interesting and important. The Opposition got a lot of comfort out of the problems at SPC earlier in the year. Dr Hewson even made a visit to Shepparton to try to capture some credit, as it were, for what had taken place at the SPC plant. What took place at the SPC plant in Shepparton was a result of negotiations between management and the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: It is extraordinary that when one looks back at all of that, one sees that the successful achievement of change and productivity gains had nothing to do with the Opposition's policies, despite its attempts to claim these events as its own. In the absence of any realistic industrial relations policy, I suppose it was inevitable that the Opposition would do that. But the productivity gains arranged and negotiated at SPC are the product of a section 115 agreement negotiated in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was almost despite your Government's actions.
—In the Liberal Party's folklore of achievements in industrial relations, the Party has claimed the Dollar Sweets case and SPC as its own.
—Have you ever heard of Mudginberri?

—Mudginberri as well-that is part of the folklore. They are three places out of the whole range of industrial activity which has taken place in Australia. Probably none of the Opposition senators have heard of section 115 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
—We have heard of section 45d.

—Senator Michael Baume is up to section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. These gains were negotiated under section 115 of the industrial relations legislation. If Opposition senators have any doubt about that, Mr Corboy, the Chief Executive and Chairman of SPC, said on 3 January:

ANSWER.PARA: The proposals the Commissioner has put forward cater for all the conditions the workers have put to us as far as the company is concerned. We have everything we asked for. I think it is a very practical solution and it demonstrates that the system has the flexibility to help companies like ourselves.

Indeed, Mr Corboy, as Chairman of SPC, spoke to the Prime Minister about this quite recently. In the course of that discussion they covered a range of issues. It was clearly the view of Mr Corboy that tapping the willingness of Australian employees to work was the key to improved productivity. That is, I must say, a distinct difference of emphasis from the Opposition's policies, which seem to believe that these issues can all be dealt with by waving a big stick in the industrial relations field. That is not so; Senator Zakharov understands that is not so and that is why she asked the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister responsible at the Federal level for the multifunction polis (MFP), I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the report MFP-Adelaide, People, Technology and the Environment released one week ago and accompanied by press releases from both the Minister and the MFP management board. I would remind the Minister that the report says, inter alia, that South Australia's gross product in the first 20 years could be boosted by between $1.6 billion and $10.8 billion and the extra direct income to the State by between $320m and $2.1 billion. Both of these estimates range over a factor of seven between the lowest and the highest. The report then goes on to state:

QUESTION.PARA: The development of the Gillman core site is commercially viable and can offer a rate of return of approximately 24.3 per cent.

And I stress 24.3 per cent. How is it that with a sevenfold uncertainty in the main estimates the management team can be so certain that the rate of return will be approximately 24.3 per cent and does not stating such spurious accuracy indicate that the management team knows nothing and cares less about the presentation of accurate and reliable information? Does the Minister not agree that the management team has failed to come to grips with the community's concern over the MFP and has attempted yet again another wordy snow job on the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always known Senator Coulter's view about this issue because he formed his view before there was any material to consider. Let me just make a few points about it. Any figures or estimates in the management board report will be dependent on the rate of investment and the rate at which the MFP site and investment are developed. I can only make that by way of comment. But let me also say that, as far as the Government is concerned, we have to respond to the management board report. I am certainly not going to respond to that report on the basis of some selected figures taken out of it. We will respond to it as a whole in due course and then, in a month or two, Senator Coulter will be able to question me about the Government's response rather than words in the management board's report itself.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, I am not going to endorse Senator Coulter's view about the competence or integrity of the management board. I certainly will not do that. We look forward to dealing with the issues which are raised in that important report. When we do that we will make a response as a government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The report repeats yet again the plan which shows three axes superimposed on Adelaide. These are labelled Monument/Technology, Water/Environment, and Land/Humanity and they miraculously all intersect over the Gillman site. Can the Minister explain what these axes mean as they must be very important to have been endlessly repeated in every MFP document?

—I really have nothing to add to what I have already said. Senator Coulter is asking me to respond to detailed matters in a very comprehensive report. I know his position on this issue, as I have said before. It has been the same all along and Senator Coulter is part of a growing decreasing minority.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of a report by International Data Corporation that spending on information technology over the last 18 months has slowed as users question the value of what they are buying? What is the Government doing to encourage Australia's businesses to become better users of information technology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue. Information technology has been a high growth industry in Australia, higher than in most of the rest of the Western world, if I can use that old-fashioned expression, but certainly in the Anglo-Saxon world, and I am fully aware of the report to which Senator Crowley refers. Many aspects of the information industry strategy adopted by the Government are directed at the business sector. For example, more than a third of $35m devoted to information research and development (IR&) support will be directed into the areas of information and communications technology.

ANSWER.PARA: That is because it is a very important enabling technology across all industries in Australia, not just the services sector or manufacturing but agricultural and mining industries as well. All sectors benefit from a healthy information industry, in terms of both its production and it users.

This Government's initiative on IR& is targeted at major businesses, especially major finance and services companies, because their efficiency in terms of the use of information technology underpins the performance of the whole economy. These businesses have to make a strategic approach to the use of these technologies whether they are banking, insurance, transport or manufacturing.

There is a body in Australia called the Information Industries Round Table, a private sector body on which some government instrumentalities, at both State and Federal levels, are represented. The Information Industries Round Table is chaired by Mr Ashley Goldsworthy, a businessman, and now an academic, with a long association with the use of the information technology industry in Australia. He also happens to fill one or two other minor positions in the country, but perhaps his most important role is as Chairman of that organisation. That body gives particular attention to the interests and concerns of users of information technology.

In so far as research in the information industry is concerned, many of the nation's major companies have good ideas for new products or services which might form the basis for collaborative projects with top information technology research organisations in Australia, and they will be encouraged by the Government.

In conclusion, the information industry in this country is in the areas where it is most likely to grow-indeed, is growing very rapidly-that is, the provision of computer services of one kind or another, particularly systems integration. That industry in Australia is very strong and is deserving of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On 28 August 1988 on Channel 10 the Minister said that Mr Hawke should sit down with Mr Keating and work out a timetable for the leadership transition. Was the deal at Kirribilli House in November of that year between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating what the Minister had in mind? Did he assume that that agreement would be made public?
—If I used those words on 28 August I had no particular arrangement in mind.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister would be aware of the international advanced robotics program. Can he inform the Senate whether Australia is participating in the program and, if so, what benefits will arise for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government--
—She is so interested in the answer that she is listening to the Reps.

—The answers are largely for the benefit of honourable senators opposite. The international advanced robotics program is a program of collaboration in precompetitive research which arose out of the Versailles summit meeting of the economic superpowers in 1982, when it was decided that international cooperation in science and technology was essential for the revitalisation and growth of the world economy.
—Table it. She is not listening.

—I would table the answer but, as there are so many illiterates on the other side of the chamber who would not be able to read it anyway, it is better for me to say it because they are able to hear if they listen.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian robotics was selected as one area for such cooperation. The objectives of the program are to encourage development of these systems that can dispense with human work for difficult activities in harsh, demanding or dangerous environments. Many countries are involved including Austria, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and the United States of America and the European Commission. Research activities of the program cover elemental technologies such as systems architecture, sensors and intelligence; and applications areas include agriculture, mining and tunnelling, space, civil engineering and construction, underwater operations and manufacturing.

It is very important that Australian industry and research organisations have access to these latest developments in research overseas and the opportunity to participate in international collaboration projects. Membership of the program will achieve this, and I am pleased to say that already some international research and commercial cooperation have resulted from this program. Moreover, Australia's reputation in this international forum has been considerably enhanced as a consequence of its active involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing whoever may be the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the April balance of payments figures released today. Will the Minister confirm that the seasonally adjusted current account deficit of $1.6 billion is the largest this year, and almost the largest for more than two years? Is this deficit due, importantly, to a 9 per cent rise in imports, despite Australia being in its deepest and most protracted recession for 60 years? Does this result not further confirm the total failure of the Government's economic policies? After eight years of disastrous government under the leadership of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, will the Minister now seek the joint and united cooperation of his colleagues Senator Richardson and Senator Ray in ensuring that, for the first time in this Hawke Government, there is a Treasurer with policies to advance rather than to destroy the Australian economy and the living standards of all Australians?

—I have not checked all the figures that Senator Short mentioned, but they are essentially correct. This is the inevitable question from Senator Short when one is looking at monthly figures in respect of the current account.
—I took them back over the last two years.

—I know the honourable senator did, in terms of comparison. The honourable senator is always saying that the Government will not meet its budget commitments, but let me say that on this occasion it will. In the 10 months to April this year, the current account has improved by 27 per cent, reflecting a robust 8 per cent increase in exports and a 4 per cent fall in imports compared to the same period last year.
—Where does that leave us?

—Senator Crichton-Browne should not get excited; it leaves us still in government with a better record than the people on his side of the chamber had on a lot of this. The return to a merchandise surplus means that we are more than paying our way for imports over this period, and most of the current account deficit is now the result of debt repayments, which also appear to be stabilising. The current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product will be at least one per cent lower than for last year, 5.9 per cent on the latest estimates. A further indication of the trade turnaround can be found by looking not at the figures for one month but at the national accounts figure. Senator Short asked me a question about the national accounts, but that was not the only area he referred to, as I recall it; he concentrated on some other areas as well.
—Yes, I did. I talked about the recession. There happens to be a recession, you know.

—Yes, I understand that. We all understand that. That was not a particularly brilliant interjection, if I might say so. We can see from the national accounts figure that net exports are now making a significant contribution to overall economic growth. In the past 12 months this contribution of net exports has totalled a huge 3.7 per cent and has been responsible for keeping economic growth positive in the last two quarters. An improvement in Australia's trading performance should be maintained, we believe, as we exit the recession, reflecting not just the strong underlying export performance but also improvements in our competitiveness, occasioned by the fall in inflation and the fall in interest rates.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note that the Minister in his response said that the Government will meet its Budget forecast for the balance of payments outturn in 1990-91. Does he not agree that, given the collapse of the Australian economy since the Budget and its economic forecasts were framed, the balance of payments outturn for 1990-91 should be immensely better, or less bad, than the Government forecast at Budget time, but that that will not be the case?

—I do not agree with that at all. Only part of the improved trade performance can be attributed directly to the recession. There has been very strong growth in non-rural exports, particularly in manufactured exports, which have increased by 17 per cent in the 10 months to this date. That excludes the exports of second-hand aircraft, which are sometimes poked into the figures. This improvement in manufactured exports continues the trend set well before the onset of the recession. In fact, real manufactured exports grew by an average of 10 per cent annually in the seven-year period to 1989-90. That has all taken place at a time when there has been some volatility in the Australian dollar, some uncertainty about international markets and, of course, a decline in our major primary industry export product-wool. So I do not agree with the conclusions in Senator Short's supplementary question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As the Australian Government has, on several occasions since February 1990, said that it is willing to assist materially in the reconstruction and rehabilitation of the devastated island of Bougainville, can the Foreign Minister state when Australia will actually live up to its promise? Does this emergency situation not warrant assistance such as that which Australia has recently given to the Kurds and to Bangladesh? Is it true that Australia has not responded to urgent requests from Papua New Guinea (PNG) Ministers Somare and Momis for emergency relief supplies for Bougainville, despite the Honiara declaration, which removes the last hurdle to sending urgently needed aid to stem the endless toll of human life on Bougainville, which is now agreed on all sides to be thousands of lives, and which continues to this day unabated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine is quite correct in her assertion that Australia has made it very clear that it is prepared to help in any practical way in the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Bougainville when a political settlement is achieved. She is wrong in her claim that we have not responded to the humanitarian situation on the island.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is this: immediately following the conclusion of the Honiara declaration in January this year, the Government publicly-and to the Papua New Guinea Government-said that it was prepared to assist with the re-establishment of telecommunications between Port Moresby and Bougainville and to facilitate contact between non-government organisations (NGOs) and the PNG Government. We also said that we were prepared to undertake a survey of the rehabilitation needs of the island.

I should point out that even before this, in November last year, contact between Australian NGOs and the PNG Government was facilitated by my own intervention in this matter and we have been actively pursuing and supporting that contact since then. In other respects, though, it remains the case that the Papua New Guinea Government has not yet taken up the specific offers that we have made about surveys of rehabilitation needs and resumption of telecommunications links.

We have subsequently funded visits to Port Moresby and Bougainville by Australian NGOs coordinated by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) to develop some proposals to assist in the rehabilitation of medical conditions on the island. We have also helped in the transporting of medical supplies through the use of the Royal Australian Air Force and we recently announced, in that respect, a contribution of $100,000 to the Red Cross Appeal.

In addition, with the Papua New Guinea Government having re-established its authority in Buka, we have confirmed our readiness to assist in restoring services there. Also, last week we were able to make available some funds-in part through the High Commissioner's direct aid program-for three portable sawmills which will provide employment as well as materials for the rebuilding of houses and schools. All that, of course, is in addition to the $275m worth of direct budgetary support which we give each year to the Papua New Guinea Government and some $322m worth in total of aid to that country, quite apart from the defence cooperation program.

We do remain prepared to respond to a request from the PNG Government to participate in the rehabilitation of the rest of the province once a settlement is reached. In the meantime, I am not aware of any urgent requests from Ministers Somare or Momis, to which I think Senator Vallentine referred, although we do continue to be in close contact with Papua New Guinea authorities and we keep them aware of the assistance we are prepared to offer as well as that which we are providing.

In due course, I will be happy to table the report of the ACFOA group when it is received. At this stage, we have only received a draft report on its first visit; we have yet to receive any formal report on its second visit. I think that covers the ground that Senator Vallentine asked me about. If she requires any further information, I will be happy to try to supply it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In light of the shifting sands of the Australian Labor Party leadership, can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that the present Prime Minister, Mr Keating, or other senior Ministers have not covered up any secret deals or negotiations for diplomatic appointments in Paris, London, Washington, Dublin or any other overseas embassy?
—There are one or two candidates on offer, Mr President, but I have to say that there have been no negotiations-subtle, backstairs or otherwise-on any of those matters.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's answer when he said that there were several candidates, could he please name those Ministers to ensure that no special deals are being done in a similar manner to the deal which was done with the former Western Australian Premier, Ambassador Burke?
—You have no sense of humour.
—I think Senator Ray has sufficiently answered the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Government been examining ways and means of enhancing productivity in the Australian Public Service and government business enterprises? Has the Government discussed this issue with the relevant unions? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government has made any decisions as a result of these discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been negotiations with the relevant unions and those negotiations have been directed to the implementation of the accord mark VI. In the Australian Public Service the relevant agreement makes provision for $12 from 16 May 1991, subject to undertakings to continue the process of award restructuring. That process in government business enterprises, particularly bargaining, will be based on achieved productivity and profitability associated with restructuring and agreed changes to work practices.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is looking to achieve real changes in this area and an ongoing improvement to productivity through the accord based process. It seems that the government business enterprises, in particular, can provide a lead to both the public and private sectors in their workplace bargaining and we hope that that will be so. It is too early yet to announce any outcome of that process but, as the honourable senator asked whether that process was taking place and what end it had in mind, I point out that that is the end it has in mind and that the process is alive and well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise whether the current Prime Minister's unprecedented assistance to Ansett Australia during the airlines dispute was based on a debt owing to Sir Peter Abeles for his silence about his role in the secret leadership deal eight months earlier?
—No.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the sheepish response we got from the Minister and the demonstrated lack of integrity in the Government's leadership, can the Senate be sure of the veracity of the Minister's one syllable answer?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Under what guidelines are back bench members of parliament permitted to use VIP aircraft? Did the Australian Labor Party member for Brisbane, Mr Arch Bevis, take a VIP flight from Brisbane to Canberra at 4 a.m. on Friday, 31 May? Was the flight approved by the Minister for Defence? Is attendance at purely party political functions in order to bolster the numbers for the Prime Minister within the accepted guidelines? What costs were associated with this flight and were other people flown into Canberra for the vote?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Arch Bevis returned to Brisbane on Thursday night. He desired to return to Canberra on Friday. Mr Arch Bevis hired a jet in his own name. He will pay for it himself. Maybe I will assist him. There will be no cost for the taxpayer.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of Senator Herron's question related to Senator Cook returning to Melbourne and not being able to return in time. He is entitled to a VIP aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —He returned but couldn't land.

—He returned and could not land. If Senator Herron wants me to go back through the various Liberal Party leadership disputes and to find out who returned by VIP flights, I will. With regard to Mr Bevis, that hire was his own responsibility. There is no cost to the taxpayer.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was the VIP flight by Senator Cook covered by the guidelines?
—Yes, it is. It is entirely covered by the guidelines. I am happy to take Senator Herron through the guidelines and show him the guidelines.
—What were his ministerial duties-to save his portfolio?

—We have the great interjector, the loudmouth over there, who has not read the guidelines. I assume that a couple of people sitting over there have read the revised guidelines and would see that that flight was entirely within the guidelines. Those people say nothing. They know that Senator Macdonald, being a loudmouth, interjecting, never having read the guidelines, wants to make those sorts of statements.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is addressing his comments directly to the honourable senator, and I ask you to direct the Minister to direct his comments through the chair.
—Order!

—Mr President, I will direct my remarks through you, but I say to the honourable senator who raised that point of order that, if people want to persistently interject-and not occasionally in a witty and clever way-they will also cop a bit back.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the recent announcement by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) of an agreement with New Zealand which allows that country to take part in the international satellite search and rescue system. Can the Minister advise how this will improve search and rescue services in this region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have previously commended Australia's participation in the international satellite based search and rescue system. Recently, New Zealand expressed interest in joining the network. On 23 May the AMSA Chief Executive Officer, Mr John Spencer, and the New Zealand Secretary of Transport signed an agreement which permits the linking of a local user terminal in Wellington to the Australian control centre in Canberra. This is the first time in the system that a terminal in one country will be operated by another. New Zealand is providing the receiving and linking equipment, and Australia is providing the controlling equipment and the watch keeping staff.

ANSWER.PARA: There will be advantages to Australia when the New Zealand terminal commences in December this year. It will allow observation of more orbits of the satellites, which will reduce the time for the detection of a distress signal from its activation to an average of 1 1/2 hours along the whole of the Australian east coast.

Particularly when announcing this greatly enhanced capacity for the system, I stress again that all people going to sea should make the very modest lifesaving investment of $200 in an emergency position indicating radio beacon. This system has been responsible for saving in excess of 70 lives since it commenced two years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister.
—The present Prime Minister.

—The present Prime Minister. As Mr Hawke has now become a hostage of the Labor Party's left wing in order to remain Prime Minister, to what extent will the Government's present policies change under a left wing Treasurer in line with the left wing's political agenda, as evidenced by its motions listed for the forthcoming Australian Labor Party Federal Conference, or does the Minister endorse yesterday's stated view of Mr Keating that left wing members are more interested in what Cabinet jobs they get than in a political agenda?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are, of course, various opinion groups within the parliamentary Labor Party. On various issues, they have different points of view and those views are ultimately adopted or rejected by the parliamentary Labor Party or the Government. The Prime Minister is not hostage to any group in the Caucus.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume referred to a left wing Treasurer. I do not know what he means by that-we do not have a Treasurer other than the Prime Minister at the moment. Is that what Senator Baume is referring to? If that is what he is referring to, he certainly would not be hostage. He would be, in the words of Senator Baume's question, a member of the Left-which he is not.

In terms of the forthcoming national conference, there is always an agenda for discussion at the national conference which represents different points of view in the Party, and they will be put. TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 May, Senator Coulter asked a question relating to motor vehicle emissions, prompted by a BMW advertisement, and a supplementary question concerning the car plan. I undertook to provide a detailed response as soon as possible. That information has been provided by Mrs Kelly and I can now provide it. It is, however, a six-page answer and I would seek leave to table the document and have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Before considering the detail of Senator Coulter's question some comments should be made regarding the nature of the BMW advertising feature that prompted it.

BMWs are impressive in terms of the low level of their emissions from their engines, as are the products of several other car firms. The existence of such vehicles indicates what can be done and counters the claim sometimes heard that environmentally protective standards and controls are too expensive to meet. In fact being able to meet the most stringent standards applicable anywhere in the world can give companies enormous sales advantages, as well as benefiting the environment.

However, it should be noted that not even BMW claims it can meet standards 20-30 times as stringent as Australian ones, as Senator Coulter suggests. The BMW advertisement actually states `in general terms BMW engines improve on the lax Australian Standards by between 10 and 20 times'.

The simplest interpretation to put on this claim is that it means the emissions of particular pollutants is at one tenth to one twentieth, in grams per kilometre terms, than is required by the Australian standards. There is no reason to doubt the claim. It would ensure that BMW meets the latest 1990 USA Clean Air Act amendment motor vehicle emission requirements, essential for a company with the USA as a major market.

This being the case-and turning to the detailed response-the answer to the fourth part of Senator Coulter's question must be that the Government does not consider the advertisement to be misleading in a legal sense and will not be taking action on it.

While BMW should be applauded for producing vehicles with such low emissions, the advertising feature that Senator Coulter has drawn attention to is somewhat overblown in its assertions regarding Australia's environmental laxity for reasons that will become apparent in the answer to the first part of the question regarding emission standards.

The first part of Senator Coulter's question asked how many countries have standards more stringent than Australia. The first point to note is that in some respects Australian vehicles are as low polluting as any in the world.

New petrol driven vehicles in Australia have had to run on unleaded fuel since 1986, cutting lead emissions from such vehicles to minimal levels. The European Community first regulated for unleaded petrol in 1989 and this has yet to be adopted by all countries in the EC. Furthermore the amount of lead permitted in Australian unleaded petrol is 0.013 grams per litre. Only one country in the world, Japan, has unleaded fuel with a lower lead content.

Motor vehicles release pollutants to the atmosphere from the exhaust system but also, in the case of hydrocarbons, from the evaporation of fuel from various parts of the fuel system and, at least when the vehicle is new, from losses by evaporation from sealants and plastic materials. Australia is one of four countries in the world that sets standards for evaporative hydrocarbon emissions from vehicles. The others are Sweden, Norway, Canada and the USA.

It is therefore apparently in the area of vehicle exhaust emissions that BMW bases its claims of easily exceeding the requirements of Australian emission standards, and this is the area the rest of the response will concentrate on.

It is very difficult to give a precise figure for the number of countries which have standards more stringent than Australia's. There is no internationally accepted standard for motor vehicle emissions and it is difficult to compare figures because of the different test cycles and methods of expression used, nor is there a simple way of converting test results into equivalent values.

Canada, Sweden, Switzerland and Australia use variations of the USA Federal Test Procedure, other European countries use the Economic Commission for Europe (ECE Geneva) test cycle, while Japan has its own unique tests. Furthermore the last two years or so has seen many changes and the literature is not always up to date. In the case of the European Community (EC) and ECE regulations it is not always readily apparent which member states have adopted recommendations in full or in part.

The picture prior to 1989 was clearer. Australia was then among the world leaders in vehicle exhaust emission control. From the figures available it appears that five countries-USA, Canada, Japan, Sweden and Norway-had more stringent emission standards than Australia. Since then there have been significant tightening of emission standards in some countries. The latest USA regulations following the Clean Air Act amendments in 1990 will further increase the stringency of their emission standards from 1994 on. Sweden, Norway and Canada often adopt the US standards and are likely to do so in this case, though the exact timing is not known.

New exhaust emission limits more stringent than Australia's were adopted by the EC in 1989 and these are to become compulsory throughout the Community. Under the latest EC regulations the level of evaporative hydrocarbon emissions remains unregulated and the lead content of the unleaded fuel-and hence lead levels in exhaust emissions-remains higher than the Australian standard. The attached table summarises the position.

In summary the tightening of EC regulations would suggest that a total of in the order of 16 countries now have, or will have in the near future, vehicle exhaust emission standards more stringent than Australia's.

The second part of Senator Coulter's question asked that if it is possible to meet standards 20 to 30 times more stringent to those now applying in Australia, why has the Government not mandated tighter controls.

It is certainly possible to meet emission standards more stringent than current Australian vehicle emission standards, though 30 times more stringent is exceedingly optimistic. Ten or even in some cases 20 times as stringent is possible. In fact many of the new vehicles sold in Australia today have low emission levels, often considerably less than half of the maximum levels specified in ADR 37, partly because many manufacturers are standardising engines and components to meet US emission requirements. Consequently the actual tail pipe emissions in Australia of the new vehicle fleet, both locally produced and imported, and certainly not just BMWs, are considerably lower than specified in ADR 37.

The Government has not yet mandated for tighter controls because the range of possible options are still under consideration. Emissions from vehicles are controlled through the Australian Design Rule process. Commonwealth, State and Territory transport and environment officials are involved in developing new ADRs, under the auspices of two Ministerial Councils, the Australian Transport Advisory Council and the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council. Australian Design Rules are called up as Regulations to the Motor Vehicles Standards Act 1989 which is administered by the Department of Transport and Communications.

The latest developments in vehicle exhaust emission standards in Europe and especially the USA are being examined by the bodies named above with a view to the modification of existing ADRs and/or the promulgation of new ones.

To justify the introduction of more stringent standards the Government would need to be satisfied that the resultant improvement in air quality is such as to warrant the changes and manufacturers would need to be given sufficient lead time to adopt the new requirements with minimum cost.
The third part of the question asked by Senator Coulter concerned environmental impact as an element in the car plan.

The Passenger Motor Vehicle Assistance Arrangements were formulated with a view to increasing the industry's efficiency so that it could compete with imports at lower levels of Government assistance and provide Australian consumers with better quality cars at more affordable prices.

The most recent formulation of the Motor Vehicle Assistance Arrangements is that given in the industry statement Building a Competitive Australia 12 March 1991. Environmental issues are not directly addressed in the arrangements. The Motor Vehicle Assistance Arrangements build on the recommendations of the Industry Commission inquiry into the automotive industry tabled earlier this year.

The Industry Commission Act 1989 obliges the Industry Commission to report on the environmental implications of its recommendations. The specific terms of reference for the 1990 Industry Commission inquiry into the automotive industry did not include consideration of the environmental impacts of the industry. Following the requirements of the Industry Commission Act a very short discussion of some environmental aspects was included.

The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories input to the inquiry into the automotive industry pointed out the importance of environment matters and how these might be tackled in terms of the Industry Commission terms of reference, for example by using differential tariffs to encourage less polluting vehicles and other ways in which financial measures could be used to encourage the development of more `environmentally friendly' vehicles.

These arguments were not taken up in any explicit way in the resulting Industry Commission report, although it could perhaps be argued that an implicit assumption of the report and of the Motor Vehicle Assistance Arrangements is that modern cars will have to be cleaner and safer as a matter of course.

Senator Coulter's supplementary question concerned the role of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in setting environmental standards with respect to the car plan.

The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is involved in the setting of vehicle emission standards through the Australian Design Rule process already described. The Department provided a submission on these issues to the Industry Commission and provided advice to Ministers when the decisions on the Motor Vehicle Assistance Arrangements were being taken. The Government is conscious of the need to pursue the question of reducing pollution generally in respect of motor vehicles. This is one of the issues for the Ecologically Sustainable Development working group on Transport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator Vanstone asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, questions referring to the extent of child sex abuse and the relationship of that problem to women's refuges. She also asked for information that the Family Court of Australia might hold on the problem of child sex abuse. I have managed to get some answers, which I have shown to Senator Vanstone, and I seek leave to incorporate the answers in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows-
Senator VANSTONE asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs both in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice, on 29 May 1991:
I refer him to a report in the Australian of 8 April 1991 headed `Statistics hide extent of child sex abuse by women' which contains, among other things, the allegation that:
. . . certain women's refuges had become known as centres of child abuse but little had ever been done about them.

Given the funding through the Department of Community Services and Health for women's shelters and the Government's attitude to abuse of women and children, and given that these shelters should be where women and children can get what they seek, namely, refuge from such abuse, will the Minister tell the Senate what action his Government has taken to ascertain the veracity of this allegation? Will the Minister also indicate what level of concern his Government has about the number of allegation . . . the father?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Women's refuges are funded under the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP) which is a joint Commonwealth/State program. SAAP is administered on a day-to-day basis by the State Governments while the Commonwealth is involved in joint priority setting exercises, joint approval or revoking the approval of projects and other policy aspects aimed at improving program efficiency and service quality. However, as States have the responsibility for administering the program, it is their responsibility to investigate any allegations of misconduct in any service, including women's refuges.

The press article in The Australian to which the honourable senator refers discusses the under-reporting in our community of child abuse by mothers. The article does not say that child abuse by women is any higher in a women's refuge than in the community at large.

Should any cases of child abuse, or the abuse of any SAAP client, come to the attention of the Department of Community Services and Health, officers would be most vigilant in ensuring that the State Government instigated any such investigations. As Minister responsible for SAAP, I would be keen to ensure that natural justice prevailed and that should any improper behaviour or abuse be detected in any refuge (including a women's refuge), then I would trust that justice would prevail through our legal system in the same way that it would for anyone in the community. Should it be found that any practices of abuse also reflected the attitude of the service, or were condoned by that service, I recommend to my State counterpart that the approval for that service be transferred to a more appropriate body to ensure that a service for women in crisis continued to be provided.

I have asked the officers of my department to once again raise this issue with their State counterparts to reinforce the need to regularly review services and to follow-up any complaints of infringements of rights of SAAP clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 May 1991 Senator Vanstone asked me a question without notice concerning the incidence of allegations of child sexual abuse in separated families. I undertook to have inquiries made of the Family Court of Australia to see whether it has information on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Family Court has no direct statistics on the incidence of allegations of child sexual abuse in proceedings before the Court which involve children.

However between 1 April and 30 June 1987 a nationwide survey was conducted by the counselling services of all registries of the Family Court of Australia and the Family Court of Western Australia. The survey included all new cases where an allegation was raised. Counsellors recorded cases not previously seen in court counselling on where, if previous contact existed, there had been no allegation during counselling interviews.

The survey showed that allegations of abuse were made on average in 1.6% of all cases opened by the counselling services during the relevant period. Although accurate figures on the number of cases opened during that period is not available the figure is approximately 6100. In most cases the allegations were made against the father and in circumstances where the custodial mother was opposing access orders sought by the separated father.

It must be emphasised that the figure of 1.6% relates only to cases opened by the counselling services and not all cases involving children before the Court. In some cases allegations of child sexual abuse are not made to counsellors but are made in Order 24 conferences before Registrars and even first raised in defended hearings before Judges.

The amendments made by the Family Law Amendment Act 1991 will require notification of all future cases of child sexual abuse and this should result in better information being available in the future as to the incidence of this particularly degrading form of abuse of children.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May Senator Bishop asked me a question relating to the decision by the Speaker and me to ban smoking in Parliament House. As indicated, I table the advice provided by the Joint House Department. In tabling that advice, however, I would remind honourable senators that the Speaker and I, in reaching our decision to ban smoking in Parliament House, did not rely entirely on the advice provided by the Joint House Department.

INTERJECT.PARA: We took advice from a number of sources. We were mindful of practice in the five parliamentary departments and the wider Public Service as well as changing community standards towards tolerance of smoking. The matter was referred to an advisory group of senators and members for consideration. That group also recommended the adoption of a no smoking policy for Parliament House.

Our decision, therefore, was based on the common law duties of employers towards their employees, the provision of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 and the provisions of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. Under the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988, the Presiding Officers exercise control and management of the precincts. The Speaker and I consider that we have a responsibility to provide for the health and safety of persons legitimately within the precinct by providing a healthy and safe place of work.

In summary, a failure to limit employee exposure to smoke could be a breach of an employer's duty to `take all reasonably practicable steps to protect the health and safety at work of the employer's employees'. That quote is from the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. Senator Bishop asked me a number of specific questions to which I have answers and, because of the length of the response, I would ask that they be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Senator Bishop asked me a number of specific questions to which I provide the following answers. Because of the length of the response I will ask that they be incorporated.
* By whom was advice sought?
* By the Speaker and me.
* By whom was the advice given?
- As I have indicated, we took advice from a number of sources, including the JHD.
* Would you table the advice?
- I have tabled the Joint House Department advice.
* Would you explain under what authority the Usher of the Black Rod is acting to enrol Honourable Senators in behavioural courses to quit smoking
- The Usher of the Black Rod is not enrolling Honourable Senators in behavioural sources to quit smoking.
* What part of the building is included in the term ``totally ban''? Does it include Members' private offices and the Executive wing? What are the proposed penalties for breaching your orders?

- Under the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 6 (1) the Precincts (of Parliament House) are under the control and management of the Presiding Officers. In 6 (3) in respect of the Ministerial Wing in Parliament House the powers and functions given to the Presiding Officers by subsections (1) and (2) are subject to any limitations and conditions agreed between the Presiding Officers and the Minister. We will be discussing the Ministerial wing with the Minister (for Administrative Services). In relation to Members private offices I can only re-iterate that for the non-smoking policy to be successful, there needs to be a great degree of co-operation, voluntary restraint and the opprobrium towards smoking of fellow dwellers in this building. We cannot, we believe, set standards for one sector of the community and not set them for ourselves.

In relation to the supplementary question asked by Senator Bishop, I advise that the Speaker and I have appointed a group chaired by the Deputy President and the Deputy Speaker to assist us with the implementation of the policy.

The group comprises Senators and Members, representatives of other groups employed in the building such as the Press Gallery, staff of Ministers, Senators and Members, as well as parliamentary departmental staff and representatives of staff unions.
I hope that Senator Bishop will contact the group with any questions or suggestions.

PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
JOINT HOUSE DEPARTMENT
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600

Senior Adviser

SMOKING IN PARLIAMENT HOUSE
In your minute of 30 April you have sought further advice for the Presiding Officers on their legal position relating to tolerance of smoking in the bars and corridors.
This advice has been developed following consultation with the Department's Legal and Occupational Health and Safety Advisors.

The legal responsibility of the Presiding Officers in respect of occupants of and visitors to Parliament House is based on the common law duties of employers towards their employees, the provisions of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 (s.6) (see attached) and the provisions of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991.

In summary, a failure to limit employee exposure to smoke could be a breach of an employer's duty to ``take all reasonably practicable steps to protect the health and safety at work of the employer's employees'' (sub section 16 (1) (attached) of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991).
Smoking in bars
There are two groups of people who may be affected by smoking in bars-clients and staff.
The risks to staff have been discussed in previous submissions (see Minute attached).

Clients (or visitors) under the OH& legislation are also owed a duty in that when at, or near, a workplace under the control of the employer they are not to be exposed to risk to their health or safety (s.17).
There are two factors which would probably limit the effectiveness of an action by a client or visitor. Firstly, there is no compulsion for people (other than employees) to enter the bar areas.

The second factor is that the claimant would have to establish that the conditions in a Parliament House bar caused the injury. It is hard to envisage that casual users of the building could succeed with a claim. In addition, if that person were entering a number of similar environments, with similar frequency, it would be difficult for them to point to one particular location as being the cause of their injury.
Corridors

For smoking in corridors the factors outlined above also apply. Smoke generated in corridors would be subject to a greater dilution rate than that generated in a bar. This smoke, however, has the potential to infiltrate into more workplaces and cause exposure to a greater number of people. The `voluntary' entry aspects of a defence cannot apply in these circumstances. In some cases a corridor may constitute an individual's workplace. These employees, in being restricted to a workplace, generally have a longer term exposure with a consequential increased risk of injury or disease.

There should be no impact on members of the public as smoking is not permitted in areas accessed by this group. For `official' visitors the exposure would be limited and again that person would have to establish a causal relationship with the smoke inhaled at Parliament House.
Conclusion

Tolerance of smoking in the bars and in the corridors makes no difference to the Presiding Officers' legal position. The Commonwealth and the Presiding Officers may still be liable although the risks of a successful court action by occupants or visitors to Parliament House are minimal. With regard to bar staff where the risk is higher because of their higher exposure to cigarette smoke the Department is continuing to monitor any changes to industry standards.

PART 2-OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
Division 1-General duties relating to occupational health and safety
Duties of employers in relation to their employees etc.
16. (1) An employer must take all reasonably practicable steps to protect the health and safety at work of the employer's employees.
Penalty: in the case of a Government business enterprise-$100,000.
(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), an employer contravenes that subsection if the employer fails to take all reasonably practicable steps:
(a) to provide and maintain a working environment (including plant and systems of work):
(i) that is safe for the employer's employees and without risk to their health; and
(ii) that provides adequate facilities for their welfare at work; and
(b) in relation to any workplace under the employer's control, to:
(i) ensure the workplace is safe for the employees and without risk to their health; and
(ii) provide and maintain a means of access to, and egress from, the workplace that is safe for the employees and without risk to their health; and
(c) to ensure the safety at work of, and the absence of risks at work to the health of, the employees in connection with the use, handling, storage or transport of plant or of substances; and

(d) to develop, in consultation with any involved unions in relation to the employees of the employer, and with such other persons as the employer considers appropriate, a policy, relating to occupational health and safety, that will:
(i) enable effective co-operation between the employer and the employees in promoting and developing measures to ensure the employees' health, safety and welfare at work; and
(ii) provide adequate mechanisms for reviewing the effectiveness of the measures; and

(e) to provide to the employees, in appropriate languages, the information, instruction, training and supervision necessary to enable them to perform their work in a manner that is safe and without risk to their health.

(3) A policy relating to occupational health and safety of the kind referred to in paragraph (2) (d) that is developed in consultation with involved unions must provide for the making of an agreement between the employer and such involved unions that:
(a) provides appropriate mechanisms for continuing consultation, between the employer, such involved unions and the employees, on occupational health and safety matters; and
(b) provides for such other matters (if any) as are agreed between the employer and such involved unions.

(4) The obligations of an employer in respect of the employer's employees that are set out in subsections (1) and (2) apply also in respect of persons who are contractors of that employer but only in relation to:
(a) matters over which the employer has control; or

(b) matters over which the employer would have had control but for an express provision in an agreement made by the employer with such a contractor to the contrary, being matters over which the employer would, in the circumstances, usually be expected to have had control.

(5) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1) insofar as that section applies in relation to an employer's employees, the employer contravenes that subsection if the employer fails to take all reasonably practicable steps:
(a) to take appropriate action to monitor the employees' health and safety at work, and the conditions of the workplaces under the employer's control; or
(b) to maintain appropriate information and records relating to the employees' health and safety; or
(c) to provide appropriate medical and first aid services for the employees.
Duty of employers in relation to third parties

17. An employer must take all reasonably practicable steps to ensure that persons at or near a workplace under the employer's control who are not the employer's employees or contractors are not exposed to risk to their health or safety arising from the conduct of the employer's undertaking.

Ron Jackson
15 February 1991
Secretary
1 SMOKING IN PARLIAMENT HOUSE
2 FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA-AUST. FEDERATION OF CONSUMER ORGANISATIONS v TOBACCO INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALIA, 7 FEBRUARY 1991

The impact of the above decision has been considered in relation to Parliament House and outlined below are some general comments and responses specific to the information you requested in your Minute of 11 February 1991.
Background

In a recent decision of the Federal Court of Australia Morling J found that the Tobacco Institute of Australia had contravened the Trade Practices Act 1974 by publishing newspaper advertisements which misleadingly stated there was ``little evidence and nothing which proves scientifically that cigarette smoke causes disease in non-smokers''.

In the decision Morling J said that there is ``more than a little evidence, and indeed scientific evidence'' that cigarette smoke caused diseases such as lung cancer and respiratory problems, and caused some people to experience asthma attacks.
The decision is significant because it is one of the few occasions world wide that a link between passive smoking and disease has been established in a court of law.
The decision highlights a duty of care to non-smokers which an employer would owe to an employee in respect of the workplace.

An employer would only be negligent if it has breached the duty of care. The duty will only be breached if the employer has failed to take reasonable steps in all the circumstances to safeguard employees from risks.
* Effect of the decision

For the management of Joint House Department the decision will be of limited effect as you have recently issued an instruction to provide a smoke-free work environment. This will protect most employees except PCS and Functions staff where their workplace may be areas where smoking is permitted. (This latter aspect is further discussed in the Agenda Paper for the Presiding Officers' Advisory Group-Smoking in Parliament House).

The Presiding Officers pursuant to s. 6 of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 have a responsibility to provide for the health and safety of persons legitimately within the precincts. (This issue is discussed in another Agenda Paper for the Presiding Officers' Advisory Group-Parliamentary Departments' Interim Occupational Health and Safety Plan and associated submissions).
* Potential risks

Morling J held inter alia that the overwhelming preponderance of scientific evidence is that passive smoking is dangerous to health. The context in which this finding was made can be used to restrict its ambit.
In any subsequent actions plaintiffs will still have to prove that in the circumstances of their cases a causal relationship exists between passive smoking and their injuries.

Within Joint House Department PCS and Functions staff could be more able to prove such a causal relationship than other staff due to their greater exposure to the hazard. It is unlikely for the Department to be found to be in breach of its duty in any other areas of the Departments activities as long as the smoke-free work environment policy is enforced.

The Presiding Officers responsibilities are noted previously and in that context the comments made above directly relate to them as the employer and additionally in controlling and managing the Parliamentary Precincts.

The onus now appears to fall on employers and managers of facilities to take a more positive role in protecting non-smokers. A strategy to implement this role in Parliament House is outlined in the Advisory Group Agenda Paper Smoking in Parliament House.
* Presiding Officers' Advisory Group Agenda Papers

The papers Smoking in Parliament House and Parliamentary Departments' Interim Occupational Health and Safety Plan are with you for the purposes of the next meeting with the Group. The former paper had been updated to include information on the Federal Court Decision.

Also attached on the file are other recent papers including press articles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to the following motion: That the Senate condemns the Prime Minister and senior members of the Government for their demonstrated lack of integrity and disregard for the responsibilities of Government at a time when Australians suffer the impact of the worst recession in over 60 years.

Mr President, in particular, the motion that I am seeking that the Senate debate this afternoon is that the Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and senior members of the Government for their demonstrated lack of integrity and disregard for the responsibilities of government at a time when Australians suffer the impact of the worst recession in over 60 years. Mr President, let me remind you of the words of aspiring Prime Minister Keating just a short time ago on Special Broadcasting Service television when he said:

I think loyalty is the stuff of politics. Political parties are built on loyalty . . . Loyalty is the common thread, I think, which runs through the political organisation and organisation matters. It matters to me.

Mr President, it might be that Mr Keating was referring to the fact that he would be loyal to his mates but certainly the Prime Minister was not loyal to him. But what is more important is that neither was loyal to the Australian people because what occurred, we now learn, is that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, agreed to a secret deal. It was agreed that, at some time during the course of this term, the leadership and the Prime Ministership, if they still had it, would be passed over to Mr Keating.

Instead of being frank about that to the public, being frank about it to the Caucus, and being frank about it to the Cabinet, it was kept secret and the Prime Minister went to the Australian people undertaking that, if he was re-elected, he would serve out his whole term knowing, of course, that he had this secret arrangement that he had made with Mr Keating, an arrangement seconded and agreed to by witnesses to the deal Sir Peter Abeles, who has been mentioned a number of times in Question Time today, and Mr Kelty.

Mr Hawke clearly lied to the Australian people in that instance and has lied subsequently about his intentions. This special relationship which he claims to have with the Australian people-this relationship of trust-is but a fraud. The other part of the arrangement is that Mr Keating corroborated in this lie. He is as much a party to that fraud-that misrepresentation to the Australian people-as the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

It was not long after that that they did it to the Australian people again. That was after the then Treasurer's now notorious speech to the National Press Club in December 1990. After that speech, with Senator Richardson involved as usual, the Prime Minister and the then Treasurer got together-apparently the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and Senator Richardson were watching through some electronic system to see the looks on their faces-and came out of their meeting saying, `We have made up, and the Prime Minister will, of course, remain in office until the end of the term'. That was rapidly changed to `until the end of the following term' when it became politically embarrassing.

The point is that that was a fraud also because that was not what was intended. What was intended was that at a convenient time there would be a changeover to Mr Keating pursuant to the agreement that had been reached earlier. It was not going to become public until Mr Keating finally realised that Mr Hawke had reneged on the deal. Then, of course, it was Senator Richardson-the mate of both sides-who had to come in again and say to the Prime Minister, `Look, you can't do that, Bob, you have got to keep to your deal'. Mr Hawke said, `I am not going to keep to the deal because Mr Keating has been treacherous-the speech at the Press Club was an act of treachery'.

But that is not what he told the Australian people. After that, he said to the Australian people, `I am not, as distinct from some other people, one who carries bitterness because I regard bitterness and jealousy as the most corrosive elements in personal and public life. I appreciated the fact that Paul understood the hurt and damage that had been caused, he apologised unreservedly and I accepted it'.

What did he say last week? He said, `Mr Keating was treacherous and that enables me to breach the deal that I had; the deal that I kept secret from the Australian people that I would let him take over-not because he deserved it, not because he would be a better Prime Minister, but because it was his turn'. It would be his turn to take over-part of the spoils of office.

Of course, that is the way the Labor Party has to operate. It operates on factions, where factions join together to share the spoils of office, and it became Mr Keating's turn. What we have seen over this last weekend and today is another effort to share the spoils in a different way: the Centre Right joining with the Centre Left to take the spoils, this time, away from the Right and, of course, the Left, which deservedly has got its share.

Ask Mr Keating what he thinks of the Ministers of the Left. He knows why they are there. They are not there because of their ability, they are there because, apparently, they are entitled to a share of those offices because they have the numbers that make up Mr Hawke's future. It was a realignment of the shares of the spoils of office that this was all about, and nothing else. That is why, on behalf of the Australian people, we should be able to debate this motion today.
