SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the history of this. It started back in 1988, when the present Prime Minister and the past Treasurer (Mr Keating) got together to play with the leadership of this country. They came to a dirty deal. They trusted each other so much that they each brought in their own witnesses. That is the trust amongst the Labor factions. They each brought in their own witness. What happened? That billionaire, Abeles, came in representing the Prime Minister. Mr Kelty came in to give the past Treasurer a bit of support. What happened? They came to a deal that the Prime Minister would hand over the office to his mate the Treasurer halfway through what would be the next term.

But what did the Prime Minister tell the people? He told the people a deliberate lie. He said to the people of Australia, `I intend to stay there for the whole of the next term'. He knew that he had made the deal and the witnesses knew but nobody came out and told the people of Australia the truth-and the Democrats believe that that is all right. After all, the Left put in the Prime Minister, and who is more Left than the Left of the Labor Party but the Democrats. So they will support the Prime Minister today.

How did they get the vote to put the Prime Minister where he is? They got the vote in the Caucus by the Prime Minister, true to his union background, saying, `I do not trust one of you lot. I want a show of hands'. So what did we get? We got Mr Keating saying, `I am not in that. I want a secret ballot', because he did not trust his lot either. But that was a no go.

Bob Hawke made a mistake, so he called a meeting for 10 o'clock. We were all out at the airport, which was fog bound. The cars came out, collected them all and took them back for that meeting at 10 o'clock. But Senator Richardson-Brutus Richardson-left Parliament House and caught the plane home. He was not going to be part of that. He wanted a weekend to do a few deals around the place.

This morning another good union method was used-that of `We don't trust you to have a secret ballot. But, if we are forced to have a secret ballot, we will have the Labor Party secret ballot-you will vote and then you will show your neighbour'. The Queensland Right can intimidate the lot of you and say, `If you don't vote the way we tell you to vote, you will lose preselection'. This standard adopted by the Government is supported by the Democrats. The Democrats like the `hands up mates and if you have to go to a secret ballot, you show and tell' method. That is the sort of democracy they support. I will come back to Senator Ray. He should not try intimidation in here-it just will not work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It should be left to his Labor mates. He and Richo should work out between them who is the toughest.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Whoever is the toughest and wins will lead this place next year.
—Order! Senator Walters!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be supporting the proposed censure motion. I have never supported a censure motion in my years in this place because I do not believe in engaging in party game playing, which is what this exercise represents.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very saddened by the lying and deceit involved in the trading of the prime ministership of this country. I believe that neither Mr Hawke nor Mr Keating, the ex-Treasurer, deserves the respect of the Australian people.

Politicians are in disrepute all around this country. We have had example after example of this, State after State, and I feel very saddened to be part of that process. What we need now is a time of quiet reflection to consider how politics are conducted in this country. It is not only the Australian Labor Party that is suffering from this extraordinarily badly handled situation. All of us, as the people's representatives in this nation, are suffering. The whole democratic process has been tarnished by this very sad episode.

We need time to heal some of these wounds. I do not think this process will be helped by our shouting at each other across the chamber. I urge all honourable senators to calm down and to let things settle.

I believe that if the Australian people had a direct say on this matter right now-if they had to choose between Mr Hawke or Mr Keating as Prime Minister-they would say, `Neither; they are not to be trusted'. The display of the boys' ego in this unpardonable battle is quite disgraceful. But the situation will not be helped by us prolonging the agonies in here. So I will not be supporting the censure motion. I appeal to people to let time heal some of the wounds that are affecting all of us, not just the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hypocrisy is what we have heard in this place from the Government and the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australia Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bishop (from 422 citizens) and Newman (from 47 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bishop (from 14 citizens) and Newman (from 961 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

1. Dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's guidelines for classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which obtain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc. or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
2. Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
3. Implement the decision of all State Attorneys-General to have the distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution-'' Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . . ''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Farm
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That family farming and small business assets are unsuitable for inclusion in the assets test for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm and the assets of other small businesses from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Assistance for Isolated Children and other education allowances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security: Employment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
Your petitioners oppose the Social Security (JobSearch and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, and ask that you prevent it from becoming law.

Were it to become law it would further intimidate, humiliate and impoverish the unemployed who are already suffering because of the state of the economy. There are not enough jobs. The government needs to tackle the economy, not attack the unemployed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate I ask that the list be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
1. SMALL BUSINESS IN AUSTRALIA-First Annual Report January 1990 to March 1991-Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.
2. REPORT ON THE OPERATION OF THE WAR CRIMES ACT 1945-Report to June 1990-ERRATUM.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In the time available to consider the report Small Business in Australia by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, I wish to raise two main issues. Firstly, there is a desperate need for confidence to be returned to the business sector in Australia. The only way that will happen is if stability is returned to the Government of this country. Today's leadership crisis is only the tip of the iceberg of the uncertainty that surrounds this Government and consequently this country. Look at the haphazard way our exchange rate has fluctuated in the last couple of days.

Business is based on trust as well as on legal contractual arrangements. However, recent revelations and the actions of both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the former Treasurer have not been an inspiration to the community. In fact, people are appalled at what is happening in Canberra today. Business cannot succeed in such an environment of uncertainty and distress. It is not a great inspiration to the people of Australia.

This Government has produced difficult economic conditions, the like of which we have not seen since the Great Depression. In fact, a recent survey of over 15,500 small businesses in Australia by KPMG Peat Marwick has revealed a number of chronic situations. Demand within the economy has decreased dramatically. Business cash flows have been depleted. It is difficult for companies to borrow from trading banks, as lending criteria have been tightened in the crisis. There has been a reduction in property values, so the asset values of businesses have dropped dramatically and they cannot borrow nearly as much. There has been a definite reduction in business confidence to commence new undertakings. Finally, to top it off, there is now a reduced cash flow operating with the economy due to the reduced sales of the Christmas-New Year period. If stability were returned-I see the final solution to this being a change of government-the end result would be an improvement in the economy: business confidence would then be returned and encouraged.

I now turn to my second point-that is, what can be done? There is an urgent need for the new company tax arrangements to be modified. Last year, this Labor Government introduced what I see is a most damaging change to business, particularly the small business sector. The Government now requires small business to pay 85 per cent of its tax within one month of the end of the financial year. I urge the Government to take note of the submission given to it earlier this year regarding company tax payments and how they have affected small business in Australia, as well as the desperate need for transitional arrangements to be instituted to the new forward collection of the 85 per cent of tax. I call on the Government to take action immediately to relieve this chronic situation of the bringing forward of company tax collections. Otherwise, hundreds and thousands of small businesses will go to the wall unnecessarily as a result of this Government's desperate actions to collect even more tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the first annual report on small business in Australia by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, I endorse the comments of my colleague Senator Watson. I particularly wish to refer to a specific part of the report and, in doing so, I want to make the comment that I am rather disappointed with a number of aspects of this report because it contains some sweeping statements that do not mean one heck of a lot.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the matter of having confidence in the report, I refer to page 18 on bankruptcies. I want to compare that with the lack of support that was given by the Australian Democrats in this place to a motion to censure the Government. I am appalled by the position adopted by the Australian Democrats. Looking at the report, we find that it spells out clearly the position which has developed. I refer in particular to my State, Western Australia, which has had the greatest increase-97 per cent-in the number of bankruptcies in the past 12 months. I refer also to the other States: Victoria, 65 per cent; New South Wales, 62 per cent; Queensland, 56 per cent; and South Australia, 21 per cent.

If we put that alongside the unemployment figure that currently exists in Australia of 9.9 per cent-once again with Western Australia at 11.1 per cent-we can gauge the performance of this Government; yet a few minutes ago in this chamber the Democrats said that we did not need to debate that aspect of the Government's performance at this time. Of course, the Government has the economy in absolute disarray, which is highlighted by those figures.

The Government often refers to what occurred during the Fraser years. It is worth looking at the graph on page 19 of the report, which relates to performance across the board. We find an estimated figure for this coming year of 12,400 bankruptcies. Comparing that with 1982-83, when the figure was 5,100, we find that there has been a 2 1/2-fold increase. Looking at those figures across the board in the report, we find that in six out of the eight years the figure has been significantly higher than it was in 1982-83.

I want to highlight these figures because they clearly demonstrate the Government's inability to effectively address monetary, fiscal and industrial policies. These figures bring out the point that the level of bankruptcies in this country, alongside our unemployment figures, is a product of the Government's failure to address fiscal and monetary policies and unemployment.

In the few remaining moments I have left, I also want to highlight page 29 of the report, where it talks about taxation reform and the impact of a capital gains tax on complying with the taxation legislation. At page 31 under the heading `Regulation Reform' it highlights the cost of regulation-two areas that need to be addressed but which have not been touched upon.

I end my comments on what occurred here last Thursday night and just prior to this debate. At this time when small business is going down the drain in a way it has never done before, it was reported that Senator Cook was at the International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention. Senator McLean is also at that ILO convention-the first time that an Australian Democrat has been taken along to it. What deal has been done for that trip? Is it a deal to support the right to strike legislation? Is it a deal for the introduction of a labour court? Is it a deal to remove sections 45D and E and common law action in industrial matters? The Government should come clean on this; it should not behave in the way that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) behaved in the Hawke-Keating affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address briefly the first annual report on small business in Australia by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Before doing so in detail, I need to correct one or two statements made by Senator Crane. The Australian Democrats were not prepared to give half an hour or two hours, as the Opposition would have had if it had won its particular motion, to the leadership convulsions of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What is important is the economy, the state of unemployment and the state of small business. We believe that this House has a responsibility to address itself to these questions in substance and in detail and to find solutions, rather than to capitalise on a party political issue, which is no business of this House and certainly should not be used for this purpose.

The report before the Senate underlines the importance of small business by documenting that there are 692,700 small businesses in Australia and 65 per cent of Australians are employed, to the extent that they are currently employed, by small business. The report indicates a number of areas in which small business needs support badly; they are in capital and in training. The report does not address either of those and that is a matter of regret.

For some time now the Australian Democrats have been advocating a loan fund for small business at a rate which enables small business to compete with big business. The Government as yet has not supported this initiative. I trust that the new Treasurer may well look at that initiative. I trust that the Opposition parties may give up their distrust and dislike of targeted economic intervention and lend support to provide some capital to small business.

Even if we do not go to such a fund, there are two other measures at least that we could adopt. One of them is to put all banks under the Prices Surveillance Authority. It is clear that small business is paying 18, 19, 20, and even 22 per cent on the overdraft funds that it needs as working capital. The banks have had the cost of their funds reduced, yet they seem strangely reluctant to reduce their rates to borrowers. Perhaps it is not so strange because, after all, they need to recoup the losses that they have incurred by making irresponsible loans to some shaky paper entrepreneurs, and there is plenty of evidence of the bad debt problems. Small business should not be the sector that should carry this particular load.

The other area that we should look at is training. Currently there are 6,900 people who have been seeking places in tertiary institutions, but have not been able to find places. The Australian Democrats believe it is urgent that additional funds be made available to educational institutions to ensure that all Australian citizens who can contribute to making this indeed the clever country get an opportunity to do so.

There are a number of other areas on which the report touches, which I believe require specific action. One of them is the neglect of the trade practices legislation to protect small business against unconscionable conduct, for instance, by large shopping centre operators, due to the fact that section 46 adverts only to persons rather than corporations. It is one of the matters, I am pleased to say, which is now part of the trade practices inquiry which we have initiated, and which will be looked at by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

There are other matters which we should address in the area of small business. Small business should be given an opportunity to take part in our export development, which is an extremely important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Spindler's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that this Government has chosen to recognise the significance of small business at long last and that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has seen fit to produce this first annual report on small business in Australia. However, I am disappointed that it has cynically chosen this vehicle to try to justify its economic policies in delivering to us the recession which was planned, whereas the report should have been addressing more particularly the difficulties that small business faces in the light of those policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Nowhere, for instance, in this report are there any statistics on the number of bankruptcies that have been caused by this Government's policies. It uses statements such as:
The economic slowdown has reduced employment levels . . .
That is a nice polite way of saying it has created mass unemployment and that it is going to grow beyond 10 per cent. It makes statements such as:
While the downturn in economic activity has been more severe than anticipated-
that must be the understatement of the year-
Australia is beginning to experience the benefits of consistent policy in dealing with the inflation and current account problems of the late 1980s.

The people of Australia are feeling the benefits all right. They are feeling it in their inability to meet their mortgage payments or their lease payments, or to buy stock if they are in the business of retailing. They are suffering all right. The report then goes on to have the hide to say:
Despite the volatility in monthly current account figures, the result for the six months ended December 1990 showed an unambiguous improvement in the current account position.
Of course, what the figures that came out today show is an unambiguous position where we have a blow-out of $1.6 billion representing an increase of imports of at least 9 per cent.

I think it is quite significant that this report comes before the Senate straight after the Government and the Australian Democrats refused to debate our censure motion which was designed to bring the Senate's urgent attention to the disregard that this Government has for its responsibilities at a time when Australians are suffering the impact of the worst recession in over 60 years. I listened to the reasons that were given by the Government and by the Democrats as to why they would not entertain discussion on that motion to censure the Government. It was quite significant to listen to the matters which, for instance, Senator Button thought were important. First of all, he talked to us about the need for courtesy. I would have thought that, in the light of the past 48 hours, courtesy be the least--

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy-two, wasn't it?

—I think Senator Brownhill is right. In the light of the past 72 hours, courtesy was something that was furthest from the mind of any of the players. Secondly, he asked us to consider the state of the nation. That is exactly what we are doing. Thirdly, he told us that there was a desperate need to get the Appropriation Bills through and how terrible it was that we got up at half past one Friday morning and needed to go home. Well I think it is important that we examine on the record to see why it was that we had to get up and go home. Firstly, we had to get up and go home because Senator Bolkus was not available to come into the chamber because he was busy doing numbers.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I inquire of you, Madam Chair, as to how Senator Bishop's contribution to the Senate has anything to do with the topic of discussion before us at the moment.
—There is no point of order, Minister.
—Why not?
—There is no point of order, Minister. Senator Bishop will be relevant to the report, I am sure.

—Of course I will be relevant to the report. As I said right at the beginning when the Minister was probably not listening, it was indeed disappointing that the Government had been so cynical as to use this report to try to justify its economic policies. I went on to say how important the appropriations are to those policies and why the Minister was unable to be here at 1.30 in the morning of Friday-because he was doing numbers for the left wing for Mr Hawke. In fact, we had to have Estimates Committee E interposed in Estimates Committee D because the Minister could not be in the chamber.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is an enormously longbow that Senator Bishop is trying to pull here and I would ask you to bring her back to the report.
—Yes. Thank you, Senator Bishop.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I note that Senator Bolkus probably wants to interrupt my time and ability to speak by calling these points of order. But, as I said, we had to have Senate Estimates Committee E interposed in the middle of Estimates Committee D.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the first annual report of Small Business in Australia. It is a very serious report on the state of small business in Australia and, of course, it is very tragic that there are increased bankruptcies right across this country. It disturbs me that the burden of these increased bankruptcies has largely been borne by Western Australia which, as the report says, has the largest increase in total bankruptcies in the December 1990 quarter over the December 1989 quarter with 97 per cent. In the year to June 1990, total business bankruptcies rose by 41 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has a situation where we have increased bankruptcies; increased failures before businesses actually go into bankruptcy; increased unemployment; increased hardship; more farmers going to the wall; and increased taxation burdens, with the aid of the Australian Democrats because the Australian Democrats along with the Government are the tax junkies of this country, who will see anything and will tax it, yet not caring about what is happening, whether it is in the cities or whether it is in the country. We see so many farmers being forced off the land-they are small businesses-and the small businesses that are supporting them in the towns going to the wall. Yet what does this Government do? All it has is a leadership wrangle. All this is happening while Messrs Hawke and Keating and Senators Robert Ray and Richardson and many of their cronies are bickering about whose turn it is to run the country.

The whole problem that is causing the deck of cards to fall down around us in this country is second to all their leadership tussles and the acrimony that is going on from one side to the other. Where is the benefit to this country? What is going to be done by this Government to turn this situation around? Is it prepared to bring in some policies that will be beneficial to small business or is it to continue on the way it has gone in the past eight years and ensure that bankruptcies go up even further? I mean, 41 per cent total to the year ended June 1990 is something of which it should be totally and utterly ashamed.

Yet we have only two senators sitting in this chamber for this debate: one who does not understand it and the other who may or may not, depending on whether someone has written out an answer. Victoria has 65 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Apart from the unparliamentary reflections, I do alert you and Senator Knowles that there are in fact seven senators in here, eight in fact, and she ought to learn how to count.
—Yes. Senator Knowles, I feel sure that you will be relevant to the report.

—I am very pleased that Senator Bolkus actually took that point of order because, if I did say there were only two in here, I have now got the opportunity to clarify that it is only two Government senators who have seen fit to come in for an important debate on the future of small business. But I know that Senator Bolkus would not understand because someone has not written out a speech for him to be able to speak on small business. Senator Bolkus does not understand that small business is in real strife. Until such time as people on his front bench, both in this chamber and in that chamber, suddenly wake up to the fact that unemployment is absolutely rife out there while he is sitting in his cosy little seat--
—Counting heads.
—I thank Senator Newman. There are people out there who are hurting. Does Senator Bolkus care? No. Then Senator Bolkus has Senator Bonehead beside him who had the audacity to call us--
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that Senator Knowles withdraw that.
—Senator Knowles, I have to call on you to withdraw that please.

—Thank you very much. I will withdraw that because now that gives me an opportunity to explain why I did that. Senator Faulkner last Thursday night called us the boneheads of the Senate when, in fact, it was he, as Deputy Whip, who failed to be in the chamber to ensure that the Government could call a division. So I will leave it to the public of Australia to decide who the boneheads are.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is this country has a problem with small business. The Government is failing to address that problem. Heaven only knows that it will not do so in the next two years. It will then be out of government and, fortunately, a Hewson led government will be in power to restore small business to what it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The small business community has had a gutful of lip service paid to it. What we have in this first annual report of the Small Business Unit of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, entitled Small Business in Australia, is the culmination of the first year of the Hawke Labor Government's attempt to set the perception that it has a concern for small business. It created the Ministry of Small Business and Customs, trying to set the perception to the small business community that it was going to give consideration to its concerns, going to act upon its concerns and going to put in place a set of policies that responded to its concerns, but this report is nothing more than lip service to the small business community. It does not address or highlight the difficulties that it is facing.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote a couple of passages from speeches by the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall). He said, `Some issues clearly require more research and consultation and will have to be progressed over a longer time frame.' In other words, it is too difficult, we are going to act some time in the future but we can't and won't act now. There are overriding considerations and they are not the small business community, which happens to be this country's largest employer.

When we talk about small business people in this country we are talking about people who have mortgaged their own homes and invested their life savings in a business to try to give it a go, make a go of it and create wealth and job opportunities for other people. That is the motivation and incentive driving small businesses to risk their life savings and their homes in building up a structure for the future. What are we doing to them? At every turn we are putting obstacles and hurdles in the way such as the high interest regime of the Hawke Labor Government over the last couple of years that has starved small business of capital urgently required for maintaining stock levels.

We have seen small business having to put people off. I can assure members of the Government opposite that, having had some involvement in small business over the last 20 or 30 years, when it comes to a position of having no choice but to lay off a member of staff who has been with the business for 10, 15 or 20 years who, in turn, has a family to support, it is not a very easy thing to do-it is a heart breaking, heart wrenching thing to do. Over the last couple of years small businesses have been forced to take that course of action because they simply have no alternative.

Many of them have tried to stave off doing that. That is why there are the high bankruptcy levels throughout this country referred to not only in this report but also by other speakers. They are an indication of small businesses trying to hang on, trying to keep up staff levels, trying to keep businesses going and trying to save their life savings. But at the end of the day there is no alternative for them, and that is why they have had to succumb to bankruptcy and liquidation as a result of this Government's economic policies and direction.

Honourable senators should go out to some of the small country communities and see how businesses are surviving there. There are no job opportunities for young people in those communities any more because they have simply disappeared-they have gone. Honourable senators should have a look at the suburban streets and shopping centres with the `To let' and `For sale' signs up, and the small businesses that have closed. They are all a stark indication and signpost of this Government's economic policies that are ruining small business. The engine room of the economy of Australia is being starved and crippled by this Government's action and direction.

It is about time that, instead of paying lip service and attempting to set perceptions, the Government did something and had a concern for small business. Policies should be put in place to start to address the real problems of small business such as on costs and those areas of micro-economic reform that we keep talking about that need to be addressed-transport costs that affect small business people in country communities of Australia, who have to pay far more for their goods and services before they hit the shelves because of the high transport costs; and telecommunications costs that affect every small business operation which are so dependent upon telecommunications today. There are power costs, land tax, WorkCare and Workcover which, in some instances, were increased by 64 per cent. In WorkCare and Workcover we have too high, unsustainable benefits which pass on high premium costs to small businesses which simply cannot absorb those costs any more.

They are the areas that need to be addressed by governments rather than glossy productions. This is a good, glossy production but, at the end of the day, this first annual report goes nowhere near addressing the plight of small business. It does not identify the areas and gives no plan of action as to how this Government will attempt to look after small business in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I would also like to address the motion that the Senate take note of the first annual report of the Small Business Unit of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce titled Small Business in Australia. I agree with my colleagues that small business in Australia is desperate for help. It needs help in finance, paperwork and bankruptcies. I am glad that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) is in the chamber because I ask him to have a look at the document. It is a 55-page glossy document which would cost anything between $30 and $50 to produce out there in the real world, and what does it contain? Very little of any value to the small business community. This is a publication for the benefit of promoting this Government by a government that wants to stop public advertising, but is quite delighted to have a document like this sent around the business community attempting to promote this Government. When one analyses the document there is practically no substance to it.
—Order! The time for consideration of Government documents has expired.
—On behalf of Senator Beahan, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee D. The Committee is considering the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter that was dealt with in the Committee hearings, but there was an outstanding question at the time of the tabling of the report. It deals with the acquisition of a computer and computer services for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, specifically for the Australian Customs Service. This matter has been reported upon in various parts of the media illustrating the fact that people are quite appalled by the example of the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) joining in a consortium with IBM and Wizard Information Services and submitting a tender for evaluation to itself, such a tender process being ridiculous in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) whether he would tell me the state of that tender. It is my information that after I raised this matter in Estimates Committee A, and Senator Parer raised it in Estimates Committee D, somehow the tender was ruled out of time. That is despite the fact that reports had been made that the tender had been received and was being evaluated, and despite the fact that at the time that Julie Power wrote her article, which was published subsequently on 30 April, at least one of the partners with DAS did not know that its tender had been ruled out of order.

The Minister does not have a good record for dealing with tenders in his Department. I wonder whether he could tell me what is the current state of the tender on behalf of DAS, IBM and Wizard Information Services concerning the supply of a computer for the use of Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a short list announced on 16 May, the joint venture proposal was eliminated, primarily because the tender documentation lodged on the due date was considered incomplete. The Department had been advised some time before that of the fact that the tender was eliminated.

—I want to follow this process through detail by detail, because Mr Graham Bannister from the Australian Customs Service said at the end of April that the deadline for the bids was in January, and a press release listed the DAS consortia as one of the six groups tendering to provide a total solution. He said that there had been no other deadlines since and a meeting of the steering committee evaluating the project would meet on 10 May to decide on the choice. I want to know at what precise time it was decided that the tender was out of time, and then we will go into the details of what the Minister considered to be a definition of the tender.
—I am advised that it was on 28 March that the Department was advised by Customs that the tender would not be considered. I think that answers Senator Bishop's question.
—No, it does not. Can the Minister just repeat for me what happened on 28 March?
—The honourable senator asked me when the tender was ruled out, and I am advised that it was by correspondence dated 28 March that it was so ruled out.
—Between whom was the correspondence?
—The correspondence was between the Australian Customs Service and the Assistant General Manager of the relevant section of the Department of Administrative Services.
—What were the contents of that letter? Can we have the letter?
—No, the honourable senator cannot have the letter. It is marked very clearly `Commercial-in-confidence'.
—It is amazing how, when it is inconvenient for the Minister, he manages to find that excuse.
—I resent that inference.
—I am sure you do.
—Order! I think it is an imputation against the Minister. The Minister has quite clearly claimed that--
—Don't you point at me.
—Order!
—I would direct your attention, Mr Chairman, to the actions of the Minister.

—Order! The Minister has claimed that the letter contains confidential information, and I think that is all we should be speaking about this afternoon. I do not think we should be raising imputations about the Minister's attitude in relation to other areas. As far as pointing is concerned, it is probably not good form but it is about par for the course for something that happened earlier this afternoon.
—Excuse me, Mr Chairman, if you do not mind: the pointing was meant to be a threat, and I do not consider that to be parliamentary behaviour.
—I did not take it as a threat.
—Mr Chairman, I did, and I would ask him to withdraw.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Chairman. It seems extraordinary to me to suggest that gesticulations in the chamber are unparliamentary. We have just had a speech from Senator Walters, for example, whose hands went all around the world and back again, and I really think pointing is not unparliamentary. It is a preposterous suggestion by Senator Bishop.
—I ask the Minister whether he wants to make any response.
—I withdraw my finger, I suppose-but I withdraw.
—There is a clever retort to that, Minister, but I would not stoop to it.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I think what Senator Bishop was referring to was that the Minister has a habit of using intimidatory tactics, and that is one of them. It is a habit that he may well have practised over the past few days with the leadership struggle, but I think he should not bring it into this chamber.
—Senator Parer ought to be careful about what he says in points of order, and I do not regard it as intimidatory-not in this chamber. Goodness me-we quite often see things like that.

—The Minister has told us of a letter which we may not sight because he says it is commercial-in-confidence. He never gives us any reason why something is to be commercial-in-confidence; he simply indicates that it is inconvenient for him. I ask the Minister: what was the basis upon which the tender by the consortia of DAS, IBM and Wizard Information Systems was rejected?

—As I have already indicated in response to, I think, the first question that Senator Bishop asked, the proposal was eliminated primarily because, I am advised, the tender documentation lodged on the due date was considered incomplete.

—If that is so, and the date was January, why did it take the Minister until 28 March to advise only one partner to the consortium-and that was the Minister himself-and why did he not bother to tell the private sector parts of the consortium?
—The advising as to the eligibility or otherwise was made public, as I have said, on 16 May, and I believe that that advice was issued by the Australian Customs Service.

—I raised the matter of 23 April. It was written about in the Australian Financial Review on 30 April. We became aware that something went on as a result of the matter having been exposed. Let us go right back to tintacks. Let us go back to the initial lodging of the tender in January. Why did DAS consider it was at all conceivable or acceptable within the limits of correct behaviour that such a consortium and such a tender could ever be entertained?

—It is very much within the capacity of the Department of Administrative Services and within the role of DAS as a service provider to government departments to bid for government work. With the progression to more and more untying of government services, DAS approaches this role on a commercial basis. What was done here was not only very much within the role of DAS but also within the role of DAS in the broader context where, in submitting its bids to conduct work for arms of government, it has to be cost effective.

—The reasons given to justify the ludicrous situation we have been through with the Minister's inter-party machinations in the last 72 hours are not acceptable in relation to the Department: we cannot have DAS tendering to itself. The Minister cannot pretend that within his Department there are Chinese walls. It simply will not do. So, clearly, we have had incompetence, if not negligence. Why did it take from February until March for the Minister to tell himself that he could not do what he purported to do? Why was it not until May, after the matter had been aired in committee hearings, that he finally did something about it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Parer knows, there are very distinct arms of DAS. The diverse range of functions that are conducted by the Department in its constituent bodies are conducted in such a way that, quite often, one arm of the organisation seeks services advice or whatever on a commercial basis from other arms of the organisation. At the same time, there are areas of the Department which may be involved on a consultative basis with other arms of government but, in the same context, other arms of the Department providing services in relation to the same area of consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been indicated quite often, we are taking the Department-and the Department is doing this extremely well-through a transition stage, from a traditional public sector department to one which is geared towards having its constituent bodies operate on a financial basis. As a consequence, whether in the area of property, information technology, transport, or whatever, some arms of the Department have to bid for work from other arms on a competitive basis. This is the regimentation that is involved in making sure that government services are cost competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; that answer just will not do. I ask the Minister to give me one other example where DAS has tendered to itself.
—As indicated, asset services often tender to project services for minor construction work and that is one area that comes to mind.

—No, that will not do. I am asking about DAS itself joining in a consortium with two private sector people to tender to itself with the evaluation panel having somebody from the Minister's own Department. Give me another example where that has occurred.
—In my previous answer to Senator Bishop, I made it clear--
—I don't accept your Chinese walls.

—Senator Bishop can keep her Chinese wall. The point I am making is that the way DAS finds itself in one part bidding for work of another is as I have explained already. I do not think I need to answer questions that Senator Bishop puts up based on false premises. We are going through the Appropriations process here and Senator Bishop can seek information and consequently make some points arising from that. I have explained to her the way in which one arm of the Department finds itself bidding for work from other arms of the Department.
—Just so that I know what level of language to use, does the Minister understand the term `Chinese walls'?
—I am not quite sure that that is a proper question.
—I am asking that in a helpful way so that I can explain the term to Senator Bolkus if he does not understand it.
—I am not sure that that is a question in relation to the Estimates. Perhaps it is a question that would arise in relation to foreign affairs!

—It is to do with accountancy. It is a very well known term. It has nothing at all to do with foreign affairs. Perhaps we could find out whether Senator Bolkus is as familiar with the term as you are, or if he understands it.
—I would go on to the next question if I were Senator Bishop.
—Does the Minister understand the term?
—Of course I do.
—Tell me just so that I am sure.
—This question is totally out of order, for a start.

—I go back to January when this was received. If the Minister is claiming that he operates in his Department using Chinese walls, can he tell me what plans and strategies he puts in place to make sure those Chinese walls are effective?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of conflict of interest in this area is one that was raised in the context of this submission for tender. As I have already indicated publicly, we are in the process of developing a consolidated corporate policy for handling the question of conflict of interest and potential conflict of interest in all areas of administrative services. The policy will acknowledge that conflict of interest is an issue which faces most public and private sector organisations. Our policy for handling it consists of a clear statement of business ethics and the reinforcement of standards already covered in service-wide policy documents, such as the guidelines on official conduct of Commonwealth public servants and Commonwealth procurement guideline No. 3. The policy will also draw on other DAS policy documents such as the Department's code of ethics.

SPEECH.PARA: The underlying principles of the policy are, firstly, full disclosure-all DAS officers are obliged to alert the clients to any possible conflict of interest and negotiate a suitable resolution-and, secondly, organisational separation; that is, between those areas of the Department involved in the procurement process and those areas which may be in a position to bid for such work. In the information technology (IT) purchasing area, these principles are applied. The Standards and Contracts Branch of DAS maintains strict rules concerning the release of proprietary information elsewhere, including to the IT Services Branch. Further, DAS will not serve on any IT acquisition council where a current tender for services is being evaluated by that council. It should be noted that, as a result of recent Government decisions, heads of agencies are now fully accountable for all aspects of the IT acquisition process. As a department, we no longer control the tender process. I acknowledge that there is potential for conflict of interest in any line of business. We have a number of policies and practices in place for handling our own circumstances. As I say, policy is made on an interim basis. The consolidated departmental policy is being finalised to provide clear corporate direction as to how such conflicts are to be resolved within DAS.

TALK.START.PARA: —I go back to the January date when the tender was first submitted in answer to the request for tender (RFT). At what point did the evaluation committee-if it was the evaluation committee-decide that the tender as submitted pursuant to the RFT by the consortium was not complete and, therefore, subsequently the Minister ruled at a much later date that it was notionally outside the deadline?

—I would have to get advice from the Australian Customs Service on that matter. It has the evaluation committee within its Department. I will just clarify that while Senator Bishop asks a supplementary question.
—I would also like the name. I know that Professor Peter Thorne was a member of that evaluation committee. I would like to know the name of the person from DAS.
—The person from DAS was Mr Vladimir Shevchenko.
—What is his position?
—He is the Assistant General Manager, Standards and Contracts Branch, Department of Administrative Services.
—Is the Minister making headway with getting the rest of that information? How long do we have to wait for the answer to the last question?

—I presume that is the question as to the evaluation committee and when it made its decision. Obviously, I have not made any headway, as I have been answering Senator Bishop's questions. As soon as we can get the answer to it, we will forward it to the Committee or to the chamber. It has to come from the Australian Customs Service. My answer to Senator Bishop a few seconds ago in respect of its responsibility for the evaluation committee is correct.
—Is Mr Shevchenko with us?
—No.
—Is there any particular reason why he is not with us?

—I suppose the easy answer is that there are about 16,500 public servants in the Department and they are not all here. We have brought with us people responsible for the main areas and we have with us the person responsible for this particular area, who is higher up in the system than Mr Shevchenko.

—That is helpful. If Mr Taylor is the head of that particular exercise, perhaps he could supply the Minister with the answer as to the precise reason. It is an unusual case. It has attracted publicity and attention. I would have thought that was exactly the sort of matter that people would have been briefed on.

—I have already answered this question. I do not think it does the Committee any good for Senator Bishop to pursue it. I have made it clear that the evaluation committee is within the authority of the Australian Customs Service. If there is any further information that I can provide in the next few minutes, I will do so. But we have already taken note of the fact that, quite technically I suppose, I could say that all these questions that go to the evaluation committee's deliberations, decisions and timing should be directed to another Estimates committee. I am trying to be helpful; I wish Senator Bishop would understand that.

—The Minister did not answer my question. I want to know precisely the reasons upon which it was decided that the tender which was deemed to have been in time was subsequently deemed to be out of time. I want to know what steps took place and what involvement the departmental officer had in determining that the tender was in fact deemed to be out of time because the information was subsequently deemed to be insufficient.

—In respect of the first question, we have indicated that that information will be available. It may, subject to confirmation, have been at a meeting on 22 March. I will confirm that date because we need to get this information from the Australian Customs Service and, obviously, there is no-one here from that arm of government. In respect of the role my officer played on that body, I cannot indicate whether that person was there. I presume that he was and I will seek some information as to how he would have voted in respect of the tender if that is what Senator Bishop would like.

—What I would like is for the Minister to convey to the Senate the reasons that were given why a tender, which was received in time, was subsequently deemed to have been out of time because it was deemed that there was not sufficient information in the tender. I find that most curious as I would have thought that IBM Australia Ltd and Wizard were quite skilled in preparing tender documents.
—Was there a question in that?
—That was a recital of the questions upon which the Minister is required to give information.

—I will have to get some information for Senator Bishop as to what role the officer of the Department of Administrative Services played in the meeting which, to date, we presume took place on 22 March. As I have said, even that date has to be clarified because we are talking about the operation of a committee which is a part of another department.

—Thank you, and while the Minister is finding that information I wonder whether he could find out for me who put out the press release subsequent to the closing of the deadline for the tender in January saying that the DAS consortium was one of the six groups which were providing a total solution. Could we have a copy of the press release?
—I presume that the Australian Customs Service would have had the responsibility for doing so. I will attempt to get a copy of the press release for Senator Bishop.

—Perhaps I could help the Minister and tell him to ask Mr Graham Bannister. Going specifically to the method by which the tender was to be assessed, I stress that it was again one of these tenders where there was to be a four-stage process and criteria were to be established and then scores would be given against that set of criteria. One might say that it was a system of evaluation similar to the one which Senator Parer has drawn the Minister's attention to on a previous occasion and in which the Minister subsequently intervened and had an inquiry into. When the Minister finally released the document, which was a report of the manner in which that tendering process operated, the report said that the basket system of allocating points was deficient in some way. When the Minister is finding out the other information for me, could he find out how this tendering process differed from the one in which we know already the Minister intervened?

—Mr Chairman, what we are talking about here are two totally separate and different situations, but we will seek details from the Australian Customs Service as to the total evaluation process. To the extent that it is not commercial-in-confidence, I will make it available to the Committee.

—Prior to the subject which was covered by Senator Bishop, Senator Kemp referred to consultants. I refer the Chairman to question No. 33 `Ministerial consultants' which was hence a reservation in the report. I would like to ask the Minister a question about consultancies. How does he determine what is a consultancy in respect of Ministers or ministerial positions as compared with departments-where would departments get consultants as compared with Ministers?

—As the Committee knows and as we discussed last week, the question of consultants is one which has attracted some interest. Ministerial consultants are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. To give a full answer, each portfolio Minister may engage up to two consultants at any one time unless the Prime Minister approves otherwise. Proposals for the employment of consultants by Ministers are subject to approval by Cabinet. After scrutiny by the merit panel convened by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Industrial Relations provides advice on terms and conditions of employment. The consultants are engaged primarily to perform specified duties and if the merit panel were of the view that a proposed consultant was not qualified to perform specified duties it would recommend that the engagement not proceed. In essence, we have consultants or individuals providing advice and skills in respect of specified duties. I think Senator Parer asked further to that how that differed from consultants employed by the Department-is that correct?

—I was really asking what is the functional difference-or perhaps the mission statement, if you like-between a consultant who would be employed by a Minister and a consultant who would be employed by a department. In other words, what are the functional responsibilities? Would there be a clear difference in functions? Obviously, the consultants employed by Ministers have specific purposes in relation to the ministerial role of the Minister, whereas I would have imagined-I am not sure about this and I am seeking clarification-consultants employed by the departments would be simply related to departmental matters.

—I think I have already covered the area of ministerial consultants. When one looks at departmental consultants one is looking at the use of external consultants in a whole range of areas where specialist skills are required-for example, on the construction side where expertise is not available in-house. For instance, in this Department, Australian Construction Services is the largest user of consultancy services, and it uses them mainly for design and construction projects where the required skills and expertise are not available in-house. The Overseas Property Group is another major user for very much the same reasons. For example, there might be minor construction and maintenance project consultancies and legal services provided in both of those areas where those skills are not available within the Department. In respect of ministerial consultants, they play, primarily, very much an advisory role in terms of the administration of government.

—Would there be any occasions when consultants were employed by departments when they should really have been given a ministerial function? As the Minister mentioned, Ministers are allowed two consultants and need the Prime Minister's approval for more. Would there be a situation where, in fact, consultants were employed by departments when they really had no relationship to the departments, but, rather, were related to the ministerial role of the Ministers?

—I am advised that under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act there is capacity for the Secretary to a department to engage a consultant. I think Senator Parer is trying to imply that perhaps people are engaged by departments when they should be on the ministerial staff. I think in the instances where consultants have been employed by secretaries of departments, those consultants have been engaged in the development of policy advice and assessments of government services. I do not know, myself, of any instances where what the honourable senator has suggested takes place. Perhaps if he were to elaborate further we might be able to help him more.

—I thank the Minister; I will. I understand that the Department employs a media monitoring service. The aim of that monitoring service is to monitor the media and provide transcripts to the Minister of any political matters in relation to his own ministerial portfolio. I was just wondering whether the Minister would advise us of the name of that media monitoring consultant.

—Senator Parer is referring to a media monitoring service, the name of which I do not know. I think it is fair to say that all Ministers-and perhaps this applies at a State government level as well-have the service of media monitoring provided for them. I see that Senator Kemp is nodding his head. It is quite a useful service, as even honourable senators discover through the limited media monitoring services available here. I will find out the name of the media monitoring service and advise the Senate. I indicate that it is one of those services provided by the Department of Administrative Services for Ministers.
—When checking that out, would the Minister confirm whether the name of the company is Croll Communications (Australia) Pty Ltd?
—I think it is.

—I will ask several questions together, because I know that we are all keen to complete the Appropriations. Would the Minister advise whether the average monthly charge for the service, simply for the Minister, has been $8,000 to $9,000 a month; whether the Department picks up the tab for the cost of this service, which is simply a service for the Minister and has nothing to do with the Department; and whether, in recent months, because of the increasing press attention mainly in regard to the Bill on the banning of advertising, the cost of this service has increased to about $18,000 a month? The question I am asking is whether this is simply a political media monitoring service which really has nothing to do with the Department. If so, why is it within the Department and thus not in the list given in response to Senator Kemp's request for the names of all consultants who were employed by Ministers?

—The first distinction to draw is that what we are talking about here is the provision of a service. Departments often contract out. The service that is in question is provided as a matter of course by all departments to all ministerial offices. The aim of such a service is to keep Ministers informed as to the news all over the country at that particular moment. In terms of the actual costs and the figures that Senator Parer indicates, I have no firm figures in my mind about normal or other rates being charged, but we will get that information for Senator Parer.
—I would just like to clarify this: did the Minister say that this particular media monitoring service was for all departments or simply for the Minister himself? Also, what exactly does it provide?

—It provides clippings of newspapers on the morning of their issue. I said that my understanding is that all departments provide such a service for their Ministers rather than this particular service being provided for everyone. Of course, different areas are covered in newspapers. For instance, the Department of Employment, Education and Training would have a different focus to a department such as Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. So the clippings would keep people alerted to issues and community interest in activities as reflected in newspapers on a particular day. I think Senator Parer asked another question in respect of this, but probably both of us have forgotten it.

—I think the Minister has clarified one question, that is, that all departments do this. What surprises me about that is that I thought that was the role of the National Media Liaison Service. What we are finding now is an entirely different group of media-aNiMaLS-which in fact is paid for by the Department for what is really a personal, ministerial or political measure. The Minister talked about clippings from newspapers.

—Can I just respond to that point. It was the point I had missed. It is my understanding, though it may not be totally true, that all departments do provide such a service. In terms of the service being a consultancy, it is fair to say that this sort of service is available to both the public and private sectors. We are talking about a private sector organisation, or a number of private sector organisations, which have as their primary role of business activity the provision of such information.

—The Minister mentioned that it was simply a clipping or newspaper service. I wonder whether he could advise me as to the sudden increase in the monthly charge from $8,000 or $9,000 to $18,000, or something or that order. I think this is an incredible figure, in view of the fact that there is already a media liaison service which acts for the Government. Incidentally, I think confirmation is being sought as to what the current figure is. Does that service include transcripts of all media, including radio and television, or simply the newspaper clipping service?

—It is primarily a clipping service, but it is a service which also has the capacity, on request and sometimes without request, to provide transcripts of particular interviews for discussion. That is a role that it performs from time to time, depending on whether or not the issues involved have any currency. If an issue has no currency on the airwaves, there is obviously no need for transcription. But quite often one needs to know what point of view is being expressed in order to take it into account one way or the other.

—It seems to me that we are getting to the point of saying that this service is purely for political purposes. The question I ask is the same as the one I raised in the initial stages of this committee stage of the Appropriations: what has it to do at all with the Department?

—One of the roles of the service provided by the Department, as I say, ensures that the views of people across the country are taken into consideration by government almost instantaneously. As a consequence, the policy direction and administration of government can be effected by inputs, ideas and whatever is picked up through the clipping and transcript service. Although Senator Parer may choose to see it as purely political, it does have a very useful role in alerting government to the adequacies or inadequacies of its policies. As to who else may have access to this particular service, I will also ascertain that information for Senator Parer.

—I think this is a fairly important matter because the questions that were raised in Estimates, mainly by my colleague Senator Kemp, requested a list of consultants that the Government uses in its ministerial area as compared to the departments. Senator Bolkus has pointed out that all departments do this. As far as I can see, this brings a whole new ball game into play.

—Just before Senator Parer goes any further, I might help him. As I said, I did not know to whom it was circulated. But I am advised, as I suspected might be the case, that the news clippings are in fact circulated to senior Department of Administrative Services staff. They are not just for the Minister. That is the practice that I would expect happens in other departments as well. They are of use not only to a ministerial office but also to senior management of departments to ensure that that management is on top of the administration of departments as well.

—But from what the Minister has said, it sounds like a secondary purpose. The primary purpose is to keep the Minister abreast of any criticisms that I might make of him in my particular role or the criticisms that any other shadow Minister might make of a Minister in regard to other departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not draw that inference. In terms of the role of the clippings and how they are used both by Ministers and public servants, it is very easy for us here to have a purely political perspective of the role of Ministers. Obviously, there is a job to do in terms of administering a department as well. It should be recognised that those clips are useful to Ministers as well as to senior public servants in the administration of departments.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, Senator Parer may have taken one perspective of it. But I suppose, as in all areas of activity, one needs to know what is going on within a department or an enterprise with which one is involved. These clips are quite useful to that extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two more questions in respect of this. Do all transcripts of all media-which I understand is the reason for the sudden increase in the cost of this-go to the Department? The other question, to which I referred earlier, was asked by Senator Kemp. We thought the answers we got covered all the consultants and the National Media Liaison Service. As I have pointed out, it seems that we have a brand new ball game here and that hidden away in departments within their budgets is another, but externally contracted, national media liaison service-which probably makes the National Media Liaison Service look pretty attractive. As the Minister is responsible for providing the answers in regard to ministerial consultants, can he advise us to what extent this practice exists in every other department of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is pretty easy to build sandcastles in debates such as this. The first point to make is that, from my understanding of the definition of the word, we are not talking about consultants to Ministers; we are talking about the provision of services. There are a number of services provided to Ministers by departments and provided jointly for both Ministers and departments. This is one of them. We are not talking about a parallel National Media Liaison Service; we are talking about a privately contracted service to the process of government.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of other departments, it is not something that is paid for by the Department of Administrative Services. I think probably the best thing that Senator Parer could do is to take the matter up with other responsible Ministers. I would not draw from this any suggestion that we are talking about organisations such as Croll, Monitair and others as being on a consultant arrangement with government; they provide a service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a question earlier about whether the average cost was $8,000 to $9,000. When can the Minister provide that information to me? Also, can he tell me whether in the past couple of months-say, March and April-it has risen from $8,000 a month to $18,000 a month? When does the Minister expect to be able to provide this information?
—I will try to get it today.

—I wish to pursue one or two questions relating to consultants, a topic that was discussed by Senator Parer. On the last day that this matter was debated, the Minister promised to obtain some figures on the total amount of money paid to consultants over a number of years. I would just like to see what the status of those figures is. It would help if we could have them on hand.
—I am advised that that information is not as yet available but I have asked that we have it at least by as late as tomorrow.

—I have one final question on the issue of consultants. In respect of the 30 or so consultants that the Minister has listed in answer to my question, is it possible to make any general comment on whether the contractual arrangement with these people is typically for one year, three years, or is there no typical contractual arrangement?

—I am advised that there is a maximum prescription in the Act, in terms of the employment of service, of two years. I am also advised that that is the average as well. I do not think I have anything further on that.
