—If the Government were to lose office, what would happen to those contracts? Presumably they would be finished. I think the Minister responded in that way to a question I put to him before. Are the contracts then paid out for the remaining amount of the term which is unused?

—I am advised that there are termination provisions but I would expect that they are not common to all contracts. But contracts do terminate at the termination of government. I am advised that if a contract terminated because of the termination of the Government, there are no such special termination provisions. I will ensure that is checked out to ensure that the answer is correct.

—To help the Minister with his response, I think we on this side would be concerned if two-year contracts, or even longer term contracts, were signed with consultants to Ministers when perhaps the remaining term of the Government could be substantially less than that period. If the Government lost office, obviously we on this side would be particularly concerned if the full amount of the contract had to be paid out. That is the nub of the question that I put to the Minister and I look forward to receiving the results.

—I take the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to page D34 of the Hansard report-that is, matters standing in my name in relation to three overseas trips recently undertaken by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). Could the Minister table the guidelines on ministerial overseas travel?
—I wonder whether Senator Alston might proceed to his next question while I am getting that information for him.
—Certainly. Could the Minister for Administrative Services also table copies of all relevant documents and receipts relating to each of the three trips in question undertaken by the Minister?

—I have Ministers' overseas travel financial arrangements guidelines and procedures, which I think have been tabled quite often before, so I have no trouble in tabling them. In terms of Senator Alston's more specific question about tabling other documents, I do not have them here. I will have to get some advice as to when, how and whether I can table them. I will also try to do that while Senator Alston proceeds with his next question.

—I might indicate to the Minister that on other occasions such documentation has been made available through various processes-Estimates committees and otherwise. There is certainly ample precedent for the documentation being made available. So I presume that there is not a problem on that score.

—I suspect that the only problem is to check it to ensure that it is accurate. I would expect that that would not be available today or tomorrow. But there will be no deviation from the normal practice of providing information.

—In respect of inaccuracies, the Minister will be aware of certain matters which the Minister for Social Security took exception to at Question Time on this subject. In particular, a figure of $2,000 was claimed for one trip, which he disputed. He also disputed what was disclosed in the answers provided to Estimates Committee D, which was that $4,473 had been incurred in respect of phone calls, which the Minister then said related to car hire. He also said that that related to five or six days in Ireland, whereas the documentation suggests once again that it was only a two or three day period. I would be grateful if the Minister could advise how these mistakes came to be made and, firstly, whether the documents are checked within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade when they return to Australia; secondly, whether they are checked in the Department of Administrative Services; and, thirdly, whether they are expected to be checked in the relevant Minister's office.

—I do not know what checking the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade conducts. I must admit that this important national issue seems to have missed me in the last week or so, so I am not up to date with any running battle Senator Alston might have had with Senator Richardson on it. It might have been because I was out of the country for some time while this was going on. In terms of the checking process, normally a check is done between my Department and the relevant Minister's office involved. It is my understanding that the checks in this case may not have taken place. That may explain why there was some misunderstanding between Senator Alston and Senator Richardson on this matter.

—I am proceeding on the basis of statements made by Senator Richardson in Question Time about the discrepancies, so I do not think there is any argument about that. It is a question of how they came to be made and at what various stages these matters are or ought to be checked.

—As I have already indicated, I think while Senator Alston was talking to one of his staff, in this case I am advised that the normal consultative process to check these things out had not taken place before information was made available. That could be the cause of the problem in this area.

—Why did it take eight months for Senator Richardson to receive the bills in respect of his September 1990 trip? What is the usual delay that occurs in relation to the provision of such accounts from the Minister's Department to the relevant Minister's office?

—I am advised that there is no normal period-and that is also something I know from my experience. The longest period taken to get accounts over, through and settled was in respect of a trip that Mr Malcolm Fraser took in 1983. Those details were settled in 1986. It depends, for instance, on the post and the complexity of some of the accounts involved. But eight months is not totally out of the ordinary.

—Perhaps we could get an indication or, better still, a calculation of the average in respect of all travel-in particular, all travel since the last election-and, more precisely, travel to Europe, which is where each of these trips was to. I ask: what is the average time taken for documentation to find its way to the Minister's office in respect of trips to Europe? That might be a little more helpful.

—We will attempt to get that information, but I am sure that Senator Alston appreciates that we are now talking about quite a number of trips. It may take some time to get the information and it might cause some difficulties, but we will attempt to get as much as possible as soon as possible.
—Are Ministers required to pay interest on expenses charged to the Department of Administrative Services whilst overseas?
—No.
—Has anything been repaid to the Department in respect of any of the three trips under consideration?

—We will need to check before we give an answer to this question. I also indicate-and Senator Alston would appreciate this-that quite often when Ministers go on trips like this they incur their own expenses, which can be claimable. In doing so, they cannot also claim the interest that they might have to pay on those bills, so it probably balances out in the end. In terms of whether anything has been paid back at this stage, we have no accurate information for Senator Alston, but we will endeavour to get that quickly.

—Can the Minister indicate-not right here and now-what other amounts have been repaid by other Ministers since the last election? Can we have details of any amounts repaid by any other Ministers over that period?

—We can endeavour to do that. If Senator Alston means repaid in terms of bills that have arrived and are paid by the Department of Administrative Services but where Ministers have taken the decision that they are personal costs rather than official costs, I am sure we can do that.
—Is it correct that the amount a Minister may spend overseas on accommodation or any other expenses is unlimited?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that, particularly in respect of accommodation, the practice that has applied consistently over decades is that Ministers take the advice of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and those posts in respect of whatever accommodation they find themselves in. That advice is normally taken. There are reasons for this. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade quite often takes the view that one should stay at certain residences or hotels because of, amongst other things, security aspects and the proximity to appointments. Of course, the Department does look at a certain level of accommodation below which it would recommend people not stay.

SPEECH.PARA: The short answer to Senator Alston's question is that accommodation is booked on advice. Quite often that advice is given for a number of reasons. One cannot say that when Ministers go overseas they should pay only up to $200 per night for accommodation because in some parts of the world-particularly in places such as New York, other parts of the United States and Europe-that accommodation is quite often not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that there are no guidelines or any other informal indications as to what is reasonable in a particular place?

—There are informal guidelines which quite often relate to lists that are kept by posts overseas as to where they would normally recommend Ministers, travelling members of Parliament, delegations and whatever to stay. But there is no one set, centrally located document which can be called `Guidelines for Accommodation Overseas'.
—Does that mean that, in the instance of these trips, the post would have made it known to the Minister's office where the Minister might stay if he were to be within those broad guidelines?

—Quite often the post would make it available or the post would advise against staying in certain places, but it is very much on a consultative basis. Senator Alston should remember that we are talking-not specifically on this issue but generally-about all countries throughout the world. All sorts of different considerations apply wherever one goes, including, of course, security.

—There are some well-worn tracks to London, even on the antique circuit. Can the Minister indicate whether Senator Richardson's office or any member of staff was made aware of any particular advice or guidelines in relation to any of the accommodation on these three trips?

—It is very much within the capacity of Senator Richardson and his staff to answer that. Sometimes I would love to know what contacts Senator Richardson does have. I cannot claim to know that for a whole range of reasons, including conversations they may have had with overseas posts as to where they should stay.
—In other words, the Department of Administrative Services is not interested in knowing whether guidelines are brought to the attention of travelling Ministers.

—As has been the practice over several decades, the Department pays the bills. Ultimately, one has responsibility in this place as well as within the general guidelines-which the honourable senator asked for earlier-governing ministerial travel overseas and what sorts of things can and cannot be paid for by government. But we do not have a determining role on where people stay when they are overseas.

—I am more concerned about whether the Minister has an interest in making sure that Ministers are aware. Is there any system for requiring the Minister or his staff, in the first instance, to ensure that any bookings that are made comply with the guidelines? Secondly, is there any obligation on the part of the Minister or staff to make themselves aware of the cost of services before they depart? In other words, do they have to check out personally? Does that mean that they would be aware of the costs incurred?

—As I have indicated, there is no central role for Administrative Services to police where Ministers stay and whom they talk to before they make a judgment as to where they stay. Quite often, the Department for whom the Minister has responsibility and the Minister's office consult with and get advice from posts overseas, but we do not dictate that in any way at all. Nor has this Department in any of its previous incarnations had a role of doing so over the last three or four decades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to change the topic and ask a few brief questions about Comcar. I refer to some of the questions unanswered as at 6 May which I believe are related because they talk about the cars purchased under contract and so on. I understand that recently there has been a change of direction within Comcar in respect of self-drive cars and I would like some clarification. Just by way of explanation, up until now honourable senators have had the opportunity in capital cities, as well in the Australian Capital Territory, to take a self-drive car, which I understand costs somewhere in the order of $35 a day, compared with the use of a chauffeur driven Comcar at $70 an hour. My understanding is that that particular service has now been cut out. There may be very good reasons for it and there may have been some abuse, of which I am not aware.

SPEECH.PARA: Just by way of example, over the weekend I was in Perth undertaking my shadow ministerial duties. I sought to have a self-drive car, which I understand would have saved the taxpayer an awful lot of money, but I was prevented from doing so because I was advised that I had to use the Comcar service. In fact, as it turned out in one instance, Comcar was required to engage a private vehicle hire rather than my being able to drive myself at considerable saving to the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, on the information Senator Parer has given us, the officers involved gave him the wrong advice and he should have been entitled to a self-drive car. I will raise this with the people involved and make sure that the honourable senator gets a direct explanation as to why it happened.

—It is just coincidental that it happened to me this weekend, but the matter was raised with me by other senators, particularly with respect to the ACT. A fairly good example would be those senators from Western Australia who, instead of going home for the cost of an air fare of some $1,700 or $1,800-whatever the extraordinary fare is between here and Perth-could have a self-drive car to use around Canberra when they want to go places, instead of paying $70 an hour. That would represent a saving to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer's point was raised with me privately by Senator Knowles last week. I am sure she does not mind my mentioning that. There is an inconsistency in terms of the costs incurred if one were to fly back to one's home base as opposed to staying in Canberra for a weekend. I understand that it would be more attractive to stay here if one had the mobility to get around.

SPEECH.PARA: Access to motor vehicles, in the circumstances outlined by Senator Parer, does depend on Remuneration Tribunal determinations which govern the service that can be made available to members of parliament in such circumstances. From my understanding, the Remuneration Tribunal does not provide for unlimited free-range use of self-drive cars whilst in Canberra. That issue is something that we can examine and take up with the Tribunal to see whether there is any way of having a satisfactory service provided that is adequately monitored.

In terms of the first question, self-drive has been a long held entitlement in terms of driving from point to point for long distances and on official business. If Senator Parer were to drive around Perth on official business, he would be able to get a self-drive car. My first answer was accurate. We will follow up and give some attention to the second question with respect to the use of cars whilst in Canberra. I thought that I would do so after Senator Knowles raised the question last week to see whether there is any way in which we can get the Remuneration Tribunal to come up with a more flexible determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised this matter because there were rumours, which do circulate around this place, as the Minister would be aware, that because of the continuing loss of Comcar, which is running at $4m to $6m a year-bearing in mind that we are a captive audience; it is a monopoly as far as we are concerned-this was a method of reducing that loss by demanding that members and senators use the Comcar at a cost of $70 an hour.
—Do you want an answer?
—It was a story I heard and the Minister might like to take it on board.
—Yes.

—I would like to move to unanswered question No. 14 as at 6 May with respect to the tender for computer consumables. The Minister will be aware that our concern about this relates to his apparent interference in a tender that was let. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that I have already applied under freedom of information legislation for the letter that sparked this all off. In answers to questions in this place, the Minister indicated that he received this letter from the tenderer which was unsuccessful but which was subsequently put back on the successful tender list; that company being Nashua Australia Pty Ltd. To some extent, we could short-circuit the line of questioning that I intend to take on this if the Minister were prepared to make that letter available.
—Not at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to the contract for what is generally termed computer consumables; that is, computer diskettes, magnetic tapes and associated products. I understand that tenders were called some time prior to September 1990 and that tenders closed in September or within a month or so of that time.

SPEECH.PARA: There were 24 tenderers and after a lengthy evaluation, on or about 23 February, eight tenderers were advised of their success. The contract was for two years from 1 February 1991. Was the method of calling and letting tenders in accordance with accepted and established practice?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already indicated to the Senate quite often, when we did go back to assess the evaluation methodology, the decision was made departmentally that the evaluation process was flawed. But Senator Parer's question went to the calling of tenders and to the--
—And the letting.
—And the letting of tenders. To the extent that the evaluation process was flawed then the letting of tenders does have problems within it.

—The question is: were they in accordance with established practice? In other words, was the method of letting those tenders the same as had occurred in previous years? This was not a new type of tender; it had happened before. If the process was flawed, which I will come to because I have doubts about that, was it flawed over all previous years when computer consumables were purchased?
—I will have to double-check to see that it was in accordance with the preceding practice. But the general response is that we think that it was.
—Were the Commonwealth's procurement guidelines and the requirements of the Department of Finance regulations and directions complied with?

—In respect of Finance regulations, I do not think there has been any suggestion that they have been infringed. In respect of procurement guidelines, that is a matter for discussion and debate, and this is a debate that we have had in this place and in the media for some time.
—My understanding of the response from the Department is that procurement guidelines were complied with. If they were not complied with, in what respect were they not complied with?

—There is advice to me from the Department; I am just trying to find the date of that advice-it was some time in April-indicating that Finance regulations and directions and Commonwealth procurement guidelines were complied with. I do not know what Senator Parer is trying to do here. The documents that go to this case have been released to the extent that any commercial information has been removed from them. The whole question of Government procurement policy and the adequacy of its application in this area was subject to intense debate.

—I understand it was intense debate. I was trying to establish that the procurement guidelines and the requirements of Finance regulations and directions were complied with, and I think the Minister agreed with that. Prior to the letting of this contract-bearing in mind that similar contracts had been let in years gone by-were any complaints received from any of the tenderers? Did any of the tenderers seek any additional or clarifying information between the calling of the tenders and the letting of the contract?

—There was discussion with some of the tenderers to clarify aspects of the requirements in the tenders. In terms of procurement guidelines, if we look at the interim report of officers conducting evaluation of this area, as well as others, and particularly the fifth page of that report, we find that the comments in respect of the evaluation and its adequacy as part of the process go towards answering the problems Senator Parer had about the guidelines being satisfied. The preceding two or three pages all cover aspects that are integral in the procurement of the items involved. They reflect on the adequacy of the procurement guidelines being satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we look at the interim report which, as I understand it, is the internal report, we find that the final recommendation was to leave the tender the way it was, as the Minister would be aware. It was only subsequently that events led to a change. As the Minister has touched on that, which I did not intend to do at this stage, let me go over what I understand to be the position.

SPEECH.PARA: On the review it was pointed out that, while all these guidelines had been adhered to, perhaps in the evaluation, rather than using a basket of commodities, single items should have been addressed. If my memory is correct-the Minister could verify this-the unsuccessful tenderer, Nashua, was put back on the contract because if the particular items were separated out, Nashua was competitive in the area of 3 1/2-inch diskettes. I should like confirmation of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —From memory, it was in relation to the 5 1/4-inch diskettes as well as the 3 1/2-inch diskettes.

—The large item of the tender is the 3 1/2-inch diskette. The Minister, in replies in this place to questions I have raised, pointed out that one of the reasons why this company was put back on-and I cannot accept this within the tender process because it goes to the heart of the principles of tendering-was that this company was an Australian manufacturer. I am going ahead of myself when I get onto this but the Minister raised the issue, so it is an appropriate time to clarify it. Let us not debate whether it is an Australian company. That does not matter. `Australian manufactured' means to me probably the same as it does to others. Irrespective of its origins, if a product is manufactured in Australia we could probably term it `Australian manufactured'.

SPEECH.PARA: But I should like to touch on this question of manufacturing. The 5 1/4-inch diskettes are old technology. The Minister has answered these questions in a most unsatisfactory way in Question Time, saying that the reason he called the product `Australian manufactured' is that the company is allowed to put the `Australian made' logo on the box.

Is it not a fact that all 3 1/2-inch diskettes are totally imported and that is the big ticket item? Is it not also a fact that the 5 1/4-inch diskettes are simply folded and wrapped and there is not one locally manufactured component within them?

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the 5 1/4-inch diskette, Nashua Australia Pty Ltd, I think, came third in pricing and, in respect of the 3 1/2-inch diskettes, it came seventh. There are practices that apply to make a judgment as to what constitutes Australian content. I think that Senator Parer mentions that particular process. He may very well be right. If he is right now, it is a definition that has applied in any event across the board, from my understanding of the area. While Senator Parer is asking the next question, I will get some further clarification for him.

—What made me refer to those particular items is that my understanding is that there is not one 3 1/2-inch diskette manufactured in Australia by anyone. If the methodology had been used rather than the basket of products, Verbatim Australia Pty Ltd, which is, in fact, a bigger manufacturer than Nashua if we take Australian content into account, would have been excluded on the contract for 3 1/2-inch diskettes-the big ticket item-while Nashua Australia Pty Ltd would have been included on the 3 1/2-inch, which are totally imported and a special type of the 5 1/4-inch, namely, 48 TPI DSDD supplied in bulk.

—I am advised, and as I think Senator Parer indicates, there are all sorts of 3 1/2-inch and 5 1/4-inch diskettes. In respect to the main one, Verbatim Australia Pty Ltd would have still qualified, although Nashua would have as well. It is not as simple as one 3 1/2-inch or one 5 1/4-inch diskette, as we have all managed to learn through this process.

—The only reason I raise that is that on page 2 of a letter of 6 May from Mr Palywoda to the Minister, it is specifically pointed out that, if that methodology had been used, Verbatim Australia Pty Ltd would have been off the contract. There is a bit of a conflict there in that information.

—I think we can get the jigsaw together. They would have been off the contract for some but not for all of the 3 1/2-inch diskettes. I am advised that it would be on the contract for the main 3 1/2-inch diskettes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have been trying to determine, and the argument put now-whether it was put by Nashua Australia Pty Ltd itself and the Minister accepted, I do not know-is that this was an Australian manufacture and hence, I would dispute, as the Minister knows, a reason for putting them back on the contract really in respect of an Australian manufacturer leaves a lot to be desired. There are no 3 1/2-inch diskettes manufactured in this country. To some degree, on the 5 1/4-inch diskette, it is just simply a folding and wrapping exercise. I will not go into the details now. I just believe that it is a labelling and packing job, with no manufacture of any of the components.

SPEECH.PARA: Just moving along from that, I would like to know the rules relating to Australian content in the letting of contracts. Are they not just limited to ensuring that Australian suppliers are given the opportunity to quote? Were there any Australian suppliers which were not given that opportunity to quote for this particular tender?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in this particular case the two Australian suppliers, Verbatim Australia Pty Ltd and Nashua Australia Pty Ltd, did, in fact, tender. There are no rules, for instance, that would make it a prerequisite that they will tender. In this case they did. What we do have within the purchase Australia guidelines is our encouragement for officers to actively seek out the Australian supplier or the Australian product.

—So it cannot be argued that the Australian suppliers that were there were never given the opportunity to tender; they were given every opportunity? I understand that, on 23 February, successful tenderers were notified after which time it could be assumed-I think this was drawn out in the initial letter to the Minister-that the successful tenderer's prices would have become common knowledge. Some time between the letting of the tenders and 4 March, the Minister was contacted by Nashua Australia Pty Ltd. I think that I asked the question before and I would just like it verified here. What sort of contact was it? Did it come through a lobby group? Was it by letter? Was it by telephone or was it by some sort of representation? The Minister confirmed that it was by letter. I would just like his confirmation of that.

—Senator Parer says that I have confirmed that it came by letter. I know that there was a representation from Nashua Australia Pty Ltd and I think that was correspondence on 12 February and, of course, it was complaining about its non-inclusion in the contracts.

—I would just like to clarify that because it was on 23 February that successful tenderers were notified. I wonder whether I could seek clarification from the officials because on my understanding it was on 23 February whereas the Minister is referring to a letter of 12 February.
—That is right. I will clarify that information for Senator Parer to see whether the correspondence, in fact, was from an earlier date or what contact there was on an earlier date.
—So there was contact before the tenderers were notified?
—What I have said is that I will clarify it to ensure that we get a precise date of initial contact by correspondence from Nashua Australia Pty Ltd.

—I understand that the successful tenderers were notified by letter on that date but it could well be, of course, that it is not unusual that tenderers were notified by the Department of Administrative Services. I would just like a bit of clarification to get the chronological order right.
—To get it right, the chronology of events that I have indicates that on 25 January successful and unsuccessful tenderers were advised.

—I have already asked the Minister to table a copy of the letter. The concern I have is that, if the Minister is not prepared to reveal the contents of that letter which goes to the core of this problem, does he not agree that we in the Senate and the public are entitled to be suspicious that what subsequently occurred may have entailed an element of corrupt practice?

—No. I do not concur. I would expect that the Opposition would be suspicious but this is the first time that the allegation of corruption has been tossed across the table on this particular issue and it is one that I find to be totally unfounded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go to the material that is on the record. I want to go, first of all, to the Commonwealth procurement guideline No. 12 dated 1990, Australian and New Zealand supplies. The Minister is familiar with that document, I take it. I would like to go to page 2 of that document where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: SUMMARY
The ANZ supplies policy aims to maximise competitive opportunities for ANZ suppliers in Commonwealth procurement.
It then goes on to say:
It does not involve discriminating against foreign suppliers.
It asks that potential ANZ suppliers be actively sought, and so on, but the bottom line is:
. . . buy supplies on the basis of value for money after considering all relevant factors and evaluating offers against requirements-

Value for money was the criterion set out when the new procurement guidelines were brought in. I turn to the Government's own report-the one that was originally commercial-in-confidence-of the inquiry into the goings on behind these decisions. It deals with the various methods that were employed by the Department and in the part dealing with market knowledge, specification and staged procurement, under the heading `Staged Procurement', it says:

The public tender process was employed. No advantage was seen by officers in employing any other option. There were many suppliers, the products were off-the-shelf and there were no discernible issues of quality differentiation. Therefore, what was contemplated was a competition on price for readily available items. In the circumstances, and providing the market was properly informed of other necessary conditions of proper competition, this may be seen as a reasonable decision.

The Government's own inquiry determined that that was a reasonable decision. We have established, firstly, that we ought to find an Australian made product, but in determining the criteria and the information to hand, the bottom line is value for money. The Government's own evaluation of the process used says that the process used was reasonable and that competition on price was to be an important factor. I now refer the Minister to his own letter to Mr Terry Fewtrell, the Acting General Manager, Purchasing and Sales, regarding the tender from Nashua Australia Pty Ltd for the contract. The letter states:
Following representations from Nashua, and the offer of a new price list, it would seem that Nashua have-
not `might have', but `have'-
unfortunately hurt their own case by not submitting their best price at the time of the tender.

In other words, at the time of the tender Nashua submitted a price which met the criteria laid down in the various publications concerning procurement, the Government's own evaluation of the system used says that the criteria it used was reasonable, yet the Minister chose to intervene and say, `Hey fellas, they've got a new price-seeing they have seen the other prices-and I want them to get part of the action'. The Minister is saying that he is favouring this company and giving it the benefit of having seen everybody else's price and retendering, and he is telling the Department it is to be included. Would the Minister tell the Committee where that line of logic is incorrect?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have looked at what Senator Bishop quoted from the interim report and my letter. I think it is fair to indicate, as I have indicated already a number of times, that I was concerned about a number of aspects of this particular tender-the seeking out of Australian suppliers being one and the question of costs being another.

SPEECH.PARA: The correspondence that Senator Bishop referred to is one of a number of communications-some verbal-between my office and the Department on this particular issue. I refer Senator Bishop to the page that she quoted from. In respect of the cost issue and the question of negotiation, the report indicates as follows:

In keeping with more traditional public service practice no provision was made for post offer negotiations. With the benefit of hindsight this process could have benefited from having this facility available.

That, of course, is one concern that the report raises which is, and was, quite valid to my mind. The next page of the report is also important in respect of this question of prices. It goes to the question of evaluation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that Minister; stick with what we are dealing with.

—I will answer the question in the way that I want to answer it. Senator Bishop can ask the question in the way that she wants to ask it. Maybe I am reading her mind or maybe I am jumping the gun, but I will go to that point now to give her a full answer. Her tolerance would be appreciated. On the question of evaluation, the point is made that this process resulted in some low priced offers and individual items not being accepted. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A clearer idea of the supply and demand sides of market would have enabled earlier publication of evaluation method.

The bottom line to all of this is that I had a number of concerns, the report of the Department emphasises those and that report was to senior officers. They, in their advice to me, made a very clear recommendation on the basis of not including Nashua's revised price offering. It is one that I accept. The advice from the General Manager of the area, which was agreed to by more senior departmental officers, was as follows:

Maintaining the status quo is not appropriate. Our review has pointed to some major deficiencies in the process. Whilst there is no suggestion of bias in the process, by not deciding and notifying in advance the criteria to be used and the relative weights that might be applied in the evaluation, potential bidders did not know clearly and consistently how the evaluation process was to be conducted. This could have affected their price offering. Furthermore, the application of the ``basket approach'' does not give best ``value for money'' in every case.
That was the--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a cover-up!

—If I were Senator Parer, I would withdraw that. There is absolutely no reason why he should accuse anyone in my Department of attempting to cover this up. This is advice from senior departmental officers dated 6 May. Senator Parer has had this advice for months and he has had a chance to analyse it, for him to make the suggestion that this is a cover-up is totally out of order. It is a scurrilous allegation to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. He did not tell me where the logic that I exercised was incorrect. To recap, this report says that the system of procurement employed concerning this particular procurement was found to be a correct method and that Nashua was to comply with the ANZ policy for procurement, but the bottom line in the Government's own publication says that value for money is to be the criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take the Minister to other publications dealing with the Government's benchmarks, and he should always understand that when it comes to dealing with procurement the basic requirement is to comply with Finance Regulation 44A and Finance Regulation 43. Those finance regulations are delegated legislation and have the force of law. They must be obeyed. Once they have been followed, the various other guidelines that are laid down are followed.

The point that I was making very strongly to the Minister, and where Senator Parer used the term `cover-up' in a legitimate sense, is the Government's evaluation report under the heading `Future of Contract', which states:

The issue arises as to the future of this contract bearing in mind the current controversy. As a general principle processes like this should not be overturned on the protest of a loser in a competition. To do so would tend to bring the purchasing process into disrepute and invite protest on every occasion. There are only two conditions on which re-opening should be seriously contemplated.
It should be noted that it says `re-opening'-not picking one's favourite and sticking him in, but `re-opening' the process. It continues:
These relate to the circumstances in which there is sufficient violence to equity and/or probity . . .
That is not a company putting in a price which is too high and, having lost out, putting in the lower price. That is a violence on equity and probity. To recap, this is the reason:

These relate to the circumstances in which there is sufficient violence to equity and/or probity as to warrant this course of action. A weaker case could be made out for re-opening a process which resulted in an unsound business proposition.
I point out again that it refers to re-opening, not adding in one's favourite. The document continues:

In exercising judgment, however, care needs to be exercised to take into account whether the violence done outweighs the damage that could be done to the Commonwealth's contracting processes at large. In our opinion, there was not sufficient violence to outweigh the damage that could occur. We are of the opinion, therefore, that the arrangement should stand as it is.
We should read this document as a whole, as is the proper way to read a document. I refer to the section that the Minister referred to earlier, where the report says:

The evaluation method for this purchase suffered from a number of deficiencies. First, the detailed method appears not to have been determined until well into the process. Second, industry was not sufficiently advised of the method at the time offers were invited. Third, the prospective size of the panel was not clearly in the minds of officers.
And so it goes on. It states further:

A clear idea of the supply and demand sides of market should have enabled earlier publication of the evaluation method. Fourth, a more defensive system of weightings, particularly with regard to decisions having to do with ranges of goods and the turnover value of different items could-
not `should', but `could'-
have been employed had better product use information been available from previous contract.

We can take that with the statement that the Minister read out earlier, dealing with negotiation, stating that traditional Public Service practice had been followed, that it had not been elected to use the post-offer negotiation system, and, further, that with the benefit of hindsight this process could have-using the subjunctive, implying doubt-not `would have', benefited from this facility having been available. Despite all of that, the Department says at the end of the day:
In the interests of the integrity-
and that has been a much misused term in this Parliament in recent times-
of the Commonwealth's procurement process the arrangement should stand as is.

The report says that the violence done to the equity and probity does not outweigh the damage that could be done to the Commonwealth's contracting processes. That is a pretty stern, deliberative and absolute statement for that committee to make. In the light of that finding, I go back to the Minister's letter, which states:
Following representations from Nashua-
and that can be interpreted, `At the end of the day when we did not get our share of the contract we are ringing you to complain'-
and the offer of a new price list-
that is, `We have seen the prices and we put in one that is too high; having seen the competition we will now put in a cheaper price'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A commercial mistake.
—Not a mistake; an error of judgment, and one pays for that commercially. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be seen that Nashua have unfortunately hurt their own case . . .
They hurt it all right; they made the wrong judgment. The Minister then continues:

It concerns me that an established and satisfactory supplier to the Government can be put off the contract without the Department wanting to satisfy itself that it has not unfairly treated the company.

A good reading of the whole of this document shows quite clearly that the departmental people had gone through it in a quite proper and satisfactory way. Everything about it was proper. The only thing that was not proper was the Minister's intervention. He made a decision that it was wrong that the supplier was put off the contract. The Minister said:
Indeed, we should be making every effort to satisfy ourselves that Australian suppliers have put forward their best offer.
Let us go back to the guidelines. Does the Minister remember these-put out by his Department, things he should be familiar with? What do they say the Minister should do? They say:
The policy relies on sound purchasing practices to develop an ANZ supply base.
They say nothing about `preferential'; they say `sound'. They continue:
Commonwealth buyers (see some definitions on this page) should actively seek out potential ANZ supplies and suppliers.
The question asked was whether the Department did that, and the answer was yes, with a tick. The second question was:
Communicate and build relationships with ANZ suppliers . . .
Had the Department done that? The answer was yes, with a tick. The next question was whether the Department had:
. . . planned procurement and informed the market in time to give ANZ suppliers the opportunity to meet requirements or the requirements of prime contractors.
Did the Department do that? Yes, tick. The next was:
Eliminate practices which may favour foreign suppliers over ANZ suppliers in any stage of procurement and encourage suppliers to do the same.
Was there a problem? No. Did the Department favour foreigners in an unfair way? No, it complied. The next was:
Decide what to buy and not let individual suppliers dictate procurement decisions.
Well, the Department did not do so, but the Minister most certainly did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. Senator Bishop seems to be debating the issue rather than doing what we would normally be doing at this stage, and I ask you to rule on that. Following that, I would like to take this opportunity to move to allow Senator Walters to raise an issue before the suspension of the sitting for dinner.
—Senator Bishop, have you nearly finished? Do you have a question for the Minister?
—Madam Chairman, I have many questions for the Minister and I am a long way from finished, but I am happy for the Committee to deal first with Senator Walters's matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the gracious way that Senator Bishop has conceded to Senator Walters.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That further consideration of the report of Estimates Committee D be postponed.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus)-by leave-agreed to:
That the estimates examined by Estimates Committee A, as they relate to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, be reconsidered without any question before the Chair.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for allowing me to reconvene consideration of the report of Estimates Committee A. The question I asked previously, to which an incorrect answer was given, was: have there been any Customs officers on any trips apart from the New Zealand, Antarctica and Hobart trip? Evidently there have been. Can the Minister tell me what those trips were?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the honourable senator for the delay in obtaining instructions, but I am advised that it is impossible to give details because it is a longstanding practice that has been going on for many years, under which Customs collaborates with the tourist authorities in order to facilitate the processing in the way with which we are familiar.
—Was a Customs officer on the recent trip to the Antarctic from Hobart?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to confirm this with Senator Walters, but the answer is that I believe so. If I am wrong, I will write to Senator Walters and advise her of that, but I think the answer is yes.
—I believe that that is the case too. Can the Minister tell me the purpose of a Customs officer going on that particular trip to Antarctica?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of other nationals went to the Antarctic area administered by Australia-mainly New Zealanders. Customs would send an officer in that circumstance to make sure that there was compliance with normal Customs business and also as an agent, as it were, for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, which is responsible for the administration of the Territory. In respect of that Department, there are a number of wildlife and other environmental considerations which have to be taken into account in relation to non-nationals.

—I am sure that the Minister would agree that it is not normally a Customs officer's job to do that sort of thing. Can the Minister tell me who sought the involvement of the Customs officer on that trip? As the expedition left the Antarctic, what was the Customs officer seeking? Were people buying things in Antarctica that the Customs officer was meant to be overseeing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the owner of the ship and an organisation called Society Expeditions, which was responsible for the expedition, sought the presence of a Customs officer. I guess that was to facilitate their operation in terms of it all being above board with the Commonwealth's requirements for the administration of the Territory. I mentioned earlier that the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is responsible for the administration of the Territory. There are a number of concerns for that Department, as well as legitimate concerns for Customs. Of course, one does not normally go to the Antarctic to make purchases and I do not think that anybody did; it was essentially a tourist expedition.

—The normal procedure for a Customs officer is as the Minister has already explained to me. I am certainly pleased to hear that. The Customs officer really had no business on that trip because there was nothing bought or sold in Antarctica and any Customs officer's job would have been done at the Hobart end of that trip. I was interested to hear that Society Expeditions sought to have a Customs officer on board the ship. I still cannot imagine why it would seek the presence of a Customs officer. I can understand that it would perhaps seek someone from the wildlife department, but it is quite beyond my imagination as to why a Customs officer would be required. Can the Minister find out why the shipping company and Society Expeditions required a Customs officer for that trip?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Commonwealth agencies often collaborate with one another in the discharge of their functions; I make that point as a general observation. Sometimes agencies collaborate on wildlife protection issues or things of that kind. Customs has a general function of controlling and supervising the entry of non-Australian nationals into Australian territory. Macquarie Island is not a proclaimed port, so there are no port regulations in respect of Macquarie Island. However, for the purpose of the exercise of Commonwealth functions, it is an Australian Territory. Anybody going there is subject to the control exercised by Customs in respect of Australian Territories generally.

—One of the answers I got that was incorrect, I presume, was that the Customs officer was paid by the Customs department. To save taxpayers' money, would it not have been possible for the Customs officer to have discharged his or her duties from the base in Hobart-both when the New Zealanders departed Hobart and returned to Hobart-particularly as nothing could possibly have been bought in the Antarctic?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the functions which I have already described, the Customs function is to control the passengers, the vessel and the crew in so far as it and they enter Australian territory. I am advised that that function could not be discharged from Hobart; it had to be at the point of entry into any new territory.
—Can the Minister tell me what control a Customs officer has over the passengers going to the Antarctic?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there are people who are stationed on Macquarie Island. Passengers or crew could take goods or other things which are not permissible in ports to Macquarie Island and these things could be made available to residents-albeit non-permanent residents-of Macquarie Island. As I said, that would not necessarily include goods but other things which may, for example, be damaging to the environment of Macquarie Island.

—Has this ever happened? How often does this happen? Is there a Customs officer on board every Antarctic ship, every passenger ship, to make sure passengers do not take anything to Macquarie Island and the Antarctic?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has happened before, particularly, I am advised, in relation to quarantine matters.
—But does it always happen on the Antarctic ships and the tourist vessels?
—It does not happen if a vessel goes into Hobart first but, if it does not go into Hobart first, the answer to the question is yes.
—But I understood that this ship left Hobart; in other words, it was in Hobart.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The understanding is that it left Wellington. If that is wrong, the point is still made that it is an overseas vessel entering Australian territory-Macquarie Island on this occasion-and it is at the point of entry that Customs functions, particularly in relation to quarantine, have to be discharged.

—My first question was whether there was a ship leaving Hobart going to the Antarctic and I thought that the Minister's answer was yes. The Minister's answer seems to have turned around; he now says that it left from New Zealand.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain about this vessel. I think Senator Walters has already been supplied with a written answer to these questions. I am advised that the officers involved were on a cruise from New Zealand to Macquarie Island.
—That was the answer I received the other day which was wrong.
—Antarctica and Hobart later from 8 December to 23 December 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister will find that he is repeating the incorrect answer which I received previously and which was corrected when I received the letter which I have in front of me. I asked whether there had been any Customs officers on any other trips, apart from the New Zealand, Antarctica and Hobart trip? The officers said no. But they came back and said, `I am sorry, that answer was wrong; it is yes'.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry, but I am still getting very confused answers and the matter has gone around in circles. Could the Minister find out the truth of the matter and let me know? My basic point is: if a ship leaves Hobart, travels to the Antarctic and has to take a Customs officer with it in order to-according to the original answer I got-`facilitate passengers arrival in Hobart and to ensure their connections are made on international flights', I believe that can be done from the Hobart end. It seems a ridiculous reason for sending a Customs officer all the way to the Antarctic and back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that observation. I will check the facts about this, as I undertook to do for the honourable senator the other day. If, in fact, the ship did leave from Hobart-which I am advised at the moment is not the position-the point still remains about quarantine functions, in particular at the point where the ship enters the port at Macquarie Island.
—Will you find out whether this is a usual occurrence?
—Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The reconsideration of the Estimates of Committee A as they relate to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is now concluded.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.32 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee will return to the Estimates examined by Estimates Committee D. The Committee is considering the Estimates of the Department of Administrative Services. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we allowed Senator Walters to deal with some questions pertaining to Estimates Committee A, we were going through the dot points which are required to be satisfied by a department engaged in procurement in accordance with Commonwealth procurement guideline No. 12, December 1990, for Australia and New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers. We had just gone through the first five points, which it is suggested that the Department of Administrative Services ought to follow, and we had discovered that the Department had complied with all of them.

SPEECH.PARA: There are only three other requirements aside from that most important requirement, the overriding one, which is that all procurement must be on the basis of value for money. The three remaining ones, very quickly, are that there must be an adequate description of requirements in functional and performance terms where possible; that it is necessary to specify performance in terms of actual need to consider the advantages which new or less well known ANZ suppliers may offer; and, finally, that it is necessary to debrief ANZ suppliers. But the most important one is that they must buy supplies on the basis of value for money after considering all relevant factors and evaluating offers against requirements.

We were going through that because I was referring to Senator Bolkus's quite extraordinary letter whereby he instructed the `a/g', and I presume that stands for `acting', general manager in purchasing and sales to include Nashua in a contract for which, by the proper evaluation process-I use the word `proper' because that is the final finding of the report which was commissioned into the whole process-these people, who obviously had some sort of relationship that enabled them to be added onto the list, were so added. They were added as a result of the highly unusually letter from the Minister for Administrative Services.

I had been quoting from the letter, and I think it is necessary in terms of someone reading Hansard that we place all this on the record. I had been making the point that the Nashua people had put in a poor price. They had not put in their best price. They had made a commercial judgment and had been excluded. The Minister for Administrative Services, when he got a new price list, said that they must be put back into the contract. We were looking at the requirements under the procurements for Australia and New Zealand suppliers' guidelines, because in the Minister's letter he said:
My view is that we should be actively seeking out competitive Australian suppliers to put on the common use contracts and elsewhere, in line with purchase Australia campaign.

That is exactly why I went through all those dot points-because the Department in fact complied with that. So we were back to the question of value for money. I said earlier that in fact the most important requirements with which any procurement officer has to comply are indeed finance regulations, which have the force of law. They are delegated legislation. I mentioned finance regulation 44a, finance regulation 43 and, of course, also I am going to add finance regulation 44b. I think it is important that we put on the record what that requirement is. I read again from one of Senator Bolkus's own publications. This time I am reading from Commonwealth procurement guidelines, September 1989. The whole section is called `Getting value for money' and the introduction very simply says:

The prime objective of Commonwealth procurement is to support government programs through obtaining value for money in the acquisition of supplies. To meet this objective, we should direct close attention to the issue of quality, cost and timeliness. Finance regulation 44a requires officers approving proposals to satisfy themselves that the proposed expenditure will make efficient and effective use of public moneys. Finance regulation 44b requires that persons entering into financial commitments should be satisfied after reasonable inquiry that in all the circumstances the Commonwealth could not obtain better value for the expenditure. This guideline sets out considerations that are relevant to assessing effectiveness and value in the procurement context.

So all this material is set out. When we read this document, which is the interim report, the `Review of Common Use Contracting Based on Three Case Studies', all stamped commercial-in-confidence but subsequently released after much debate, we see that the Department went through all the procedures that were necessary. Again, so that we have it on the record, I read from the Minister's own guidelines:
Value for money is well understood in commercial procurement.

The Nashua people had often been engaged with government contracts. They knew the guidelines about value for money. They knew that price remains important unless there are good reasons for price not to be the dominant factor. I read again from the instructions:
To achieve and assess it-
this is value for money-
we have to consider all of the price and non-price factors that are significant in any individual procurement following, but not limited to:
1. Fitness for purpose;
2. Whole of life costs;
3. Fair market prices;
4. Timely delivery;
5. Post delivery support;
6. Effective warranties;
7. Reasonableness; and
8. Commonsense must be important in our approach.
It says:

Getting value for money means ensuring that benefits are commensurate with costs, that least cost choice should not be followed automatically if there is a clear and reasoned justification for not doing so.

The fact of the matter is that the price that was quoted was not the best price so, to justify the price argument, the Minister, by his own guidelines, would have to show that there is clear and reasoned justification for not making the decision based on price. But the really untenable fact in all of this is that this great pile of regulations has been followed and the new procurement guidelines have been followed, but what has occurred is after the event. The company has complained to the Minister, and the Minister has intervened and instructed his Department not to reopen the tendering process because the tendering process was defective in accordance with all those guidelines. But the Minister said, and I quote his letter:
It would seem that Nashua have unfortunately hurt their own case by not submitting their best price at the time of tender.

So the Minister took it upon himself to direct his Department to give preferential treatment to that tenderer. That is just not acceptable. In the words of his own commissioned report-and I go through these words again because they are not only salient but they are integral to the integrity of the tendering process:

As a general rule, a general principal, the processes such as these should not be overturned on the protest of a loser in a competition. To do so would tend to bring the purchasing process into disrepute and invite protest on every occasion. The only basis for reopening the tender-

It is to reopen the whole process, not to force the Minister's choice or the Minister's directive upon the Department and that was a violence to equity and probity. The report concludes that, on balance, the damage done to the integrity of the tendering process is not outweighed by any violence against equity or probity. I am afraid that the Minister's actions stand condemned by his own report.

The fact that it took so long to get this report and the fact that the Minister seemed to be unfamiliar with his own guidelines causes one to have great concerns about the method by which all tendering is to be treated.
