—By whom?

—I had a meeting with the Secretary, Mr Hillier, Mr McAlister and Mr Palywoda. If Senator Bishop really wants to know who advised me what, the first three gentlemen advised me to do what I finally did, on those grounds that I spelt out in my answer in this place on the first occasion. In respect to Mr Palywoda, it is fair to say-and I have his permission to say it-he was more inclined to cancel the standing offer and call for fresh tenders. The senior officers who gave the advice were: the Secretary, the General Manager, Supply and Distribution and the Executive General Manager, Sales and Services Program. The latter two people, together with the Secretary, had a very firm view of what I should do, and that was the advice that I took.
—In regard to this advice that was given to the Minister, what is the basis of it and is it written and, if it is written, may we please have a copy of it?
—I think that I made it clear to any person who can think that it was not written; it was advice at a meeting.
—When that advice was given, did those gentlemen pay heed to that section which is blacked out in this report headed `Legal Position'?

—I am sure that those gentlemen would have read the whole report, as well as the advice that was given to me. I am obviously not in a position to cross-examine them as to the part to which they paid more attention than the others. From my recollection of the meeting, the legal position was discussed as well.

—I have a final question. I do not know whether it is final or not because that really depends on the Minister to some extent. I did raise it a couple of times and I said that we could probably bring this matter to conclusion if the Minister would show us or table the letter that Nashua Australia Pty Ltd wrote to him. It is also a letter that I have applied for under the Freedom of Information Act, which I was under the impression may well come forward. If the Minister is correct in what he says, why will he not table that letter?

—I think that I have answered this question about six times already this evening. The last concession that I made was to Senator Bishop and I said that I would have another look at it to see whether it can be made available. I am concerned about the commercial nature of it, obviously.

—What aspects of a commercial nature is the Minister worried about because he will recall that, when he agreed to table the other documents which were seen by Senator Hill and me, we agreed that areas within them which were blacked out and which we read were commercial-in-confidence. Using the same principles, is he prepared to show us that letter?

—I will make an assessment of the letter in the light of those principles and that practice we took and see whether it can or should be made available. I have already said that a million times and, as I made clear to Senator Parer, I am not going to budge from that position.

—I asked the Minister whether the advice that was given to him in that meeting was related to the legal position which is blanked out in my copy of this sanitised advice. The reason I ask the Minister for that--
—You asked me whether the legal advice was taken into consideration and I said that it had been.

—Good. I think that is important because if I were looking at this question, the sort of legal advice that might be contained in this document would have been that, if the tender had been cancelled, the Commonwealth could have been rendered liable in damages for negligence. The Minister, in fact, could have exposed the Commonwealth to more or less than the $270,000, which is the figure that is cited as a cost that was incurred with regard to option (ii). What option (ii) does not say is whether or not that figure is an assessment of the likelihood of a settlement that might ensue. So the Minister, by saying to us that he was advised in that meeting that the best option for him was to add people into the contract does not really canvass the whole picture, the whole truth. The reason for that advice could well have been because otherwise the Minister and his Department would expose the taxpayer to a greater expenditure by reason of negligence.

—The paragraph where the $270,000 figure is mentioned says that an indicative cost in retendering is $270,000. That would have been the cost to industry of going through a new tendering process, some small part of that cost I think being incurred by the Department. That was a consideration that was taken into account. What we have done is in accordance with the legal advice and that advice is that we are not liable for anything because of the change in the process. Let me also say a better understanding of this contract, the nature of it, and what it means by way of common use contract, is quite important when one makes a legal assessment of one's liability. As I say, we have acted on advice that we would not be liable.

—I thank the Minister for that-whatever it was. It did not really address the point I raised. I ask him whether he would provide me with a break down by his Department of that $270,000 and how that sum was arrived at because I think it is very pertinent that the advice that was given, the decision that was made and the fact that the Minister intervened put the integrity of the tendering process not just at risk but also demeaned it.
—We will get some indicative figures for Senator Bishop.

—I just have some general questions that I would add to that. In accordance with the new procurement methods it is required that the Secretary of the Minister's Department publish guidelines for procurement by his Department. Have those guidelines, in fact, been written and published?
—The imperative is for us to produce a purchasing reform plan. That has been done.

—It is more than a purchasing reform plan; it is a manual that sets out how officers are to comply with the finance regulations and how they are to interpret various publications that have been made available. I have seen guidelines prepared by other departments. I wonder whether we could see the Minister's?

—The Secretary has, in fact, produced his accounting and administrative directions which do cover all those finance regulations that I think Senator Bishop is concerned about. They have been published.

—I am sure the Minister will be interested to know that, under the new procurement system, the responsibility for procurement by his Department falls upon him personally. He, the Minister, is personally responsible. I am most interested that he had to ask his officers whether or not those guidelines had, in fact, been produced. He personally is responsible and he did not know. He did not even know what the word `publishing' in this context means. The guidelines are not subject to tabling and disallowance. They are not subject to being published in the general sense. They are available to officers who have the authority to publish in the Minister's Department; officers on whom that is devolved. The Minister personally is responsible for the integrity of his purchasing officers. I would ask that a copy of those guidelines, or by whatever name the Minister's Department has named them, be made available to the Senate. If I can have a yes for that, I will then go on to ask the Minister about internal audit.
—We should be able to do so. I would suggest that, rather than have them printed or incorporated, I produce a copy of them. I think they are quite a hefty volume and we will produce them.

—I thank the Minister. I would ask him what provision he has made in his Department for internal audit and how he has followed his own guidelines, published by him and his Department, concerning a proper audit of procurement within his Department.

—We do have within the Department a special branch called the Performance Review and Audit Branch. At the last recall, there were about 50 people involved in that section with the responsibilities of concern to Senator Bishop.
—I am very pleased the Minister has all these people there to perform an audit function. Would he tell me how his Department conducts internal audits and how those internal audits are dealt with?
—Given the diversity of functions within the Department, we should probably provide for the Senate, and Senator Bishop, a framework document which gives an overview of how internal audits are done.
—Senator Bishop, perhaps you can help the Chair again by informing me of the reservation you are referring to.
—I am still referring to question No. 14 of unanswered questions at the time of the tabling of the contract.
—I think you have strayed a little from that area.

—Not really, because this documentation ought to have related in some way to internal audit procedures. There is a recommendation in the Minister's own guidelines that there should be an audit function of procurement. I think it is important, in view of the controversy of this document, that we understand whether or not there is an internal audit function which is being paid heed to. I remind you, Mr Chairman, that the officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which also had an internal audit system, for years simply ignored the internal audits until such time as those awful people-the whistle blowers-made them available and pressure was bought to bear by the Senate.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I can understand why you, like me, wondered how we got on to this particular aspect. If Senator Bishop is concerned about whether the internal audit section was in any way involved in this process, let me assure her that the chief internal auditor led the review that reported to Mr Palywoda and others.
—Who was that?
—Mr Perry.
—His position?
—I have just been through that. I do not know whether he has any other titles, but chief internal auditor was one that I had. He is the Assistant General Manager, Performance Review and Audit.
—I have one final question. Would the Minister tell me when the Auditor-General last conducted an efficiency audit on the Department of Administrative Services.
—As has been suggested, we have had a number of them. It is probably best if we can give the Senate, and particularly Senator Bishop, a table setting out some of the more recent ones.

—I would like to wrap this up as far as I am concerned, but I think I should make some comments. We have attempted at great length to find out from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) why he intervened in a contract some time after it had been let. He has consistently refused to give a direct answer to those questions. He does refer to subsequent events but, from his own letter, he intervened in a contract at the time because he believed the tenderer had put in a price which, at that time, militated against the tenderer because it was too high. He has refused to table a letter from Nashua Australia Pty Ltd which may well clear up the matter. He leaves in our minds a serious doubt as to the motives for that intervention. They may well be innocent, I do not know. It leaves us no option but to pursue this matter by other means at our disposal at another time.

—There is one fact that needs to be on the record in light of Senator Parer's remarks, and that is the dates. It is very significant to note that Senator Bolkus's letter instructing his Department to put these people on the tender-that is, his intervention-is dated 4 March 1991, and the date of the advice upon which he said he acted at 4 p.m. is 6 May 1991. It is significant to place on the record that Senator Bolkus acted of his own volition without any further advice or consultation and subsequently sought to justify it.
—There being no further questions, the Committee will proceed to an examination of the estimates of the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

—The Austudy threshold of earnings for the spouse of an independent student was reduced from $18,150 to $12,150, while the parental income was increased from $18,150 to $19,350 in line with the consumer price index. Could the Minister explain the reason for this?
—I would like to know under what reservation Senator Walters asks her question.
—I made a reservation about Austudy.

—I am advised that the decrease was to bring the tests more in line with unemployment benefits, although it should be noted that it is more generous than unemployment benefits. I am advised that the parental income increase was in accordance with indexation.

—The Minister's advisers missed part of what I said, if that was their advice to him. I pointed out that the independent student could well have been the spouse of someone earning $12,150, and I wondered why it had been decreased while the child's parents' income was increased. The independent student would not have been on unemployment benefits-it is the spouse's income.
—I think Senator Walters is alluding to a case where the applicant could be an independent student spouse. Is that what the honourable senator is suggesting?

—Yes. I am referring to an independent, full time university student whose spouse was earning $18,150. He was then in line with the son of two parents whose income was $18,150, but the Government has increased the parental income limit but lowered the permissible income limit of the independent student spouse.

—The first answer I gave Senator Walters goes very much to the reasons why those adjustments were made in those two major categories. I will obtain further advice. The advice is that it was anticipated that students would have more reliance on the income of a spouse than the income of a parent. That is the rationale behind the adjustment that was made. Does that go some way towards answering the question? We have a problem on this side of the chamber in trying to grapple with the core of Senator Walters's question.

—I shall give the example of the student who came to see me. He is a full time university student. He is married, and his wife was earning the $18,150. The limit was decreased to $12,150, which meant that he was no longer eligible for Austudy. He compared himself to a friend of his whose parents were on an income of $18,150 and the limit for whom went up to $19,350. He asked me about the justice of the case.

—The other aspect of the answer is that, in respect of a spouse situation, it would be expected that one person who would have reliance on the spouse's income, that is, the other spouse, while in relation to a family situation it is quite probable that there would be more than one student with some reliance on the family income. Senator Walters can shake her head, but she has asked for the rationale and I have given it to her. She may disagree with it-and I expect that she does-but that is the rationale. In the case of parents it is likely that there will be more than one student dependent on the income. That is why the adjustment was made-to be more beneficial there.

—I ask the Minister to please take the following question on notice: a widowed mother of a full time university student has an income of $18,150, the limit for the student has now been increased to $19,150 and her son is still able to get Austudy, so her income is looking after only her and her son; whereas the spouse of an independent student was on $18,150 and the limit has now been reduced to $12,150, the income of the spouse still looking after just the spouse and the independent student. Can the Minister tell me the justice of the increase in one situation and the decrease in the other?
—We shall take that question on notice.
—Can the Minister let me know when I could possibly get the answer to that?
—Hopefully, tomorrow or the day after.

—I refer first to a question which was taken on notice during the Estimates hearings but which still remains unanswered. I refer to a variation in costs under the item client services that amounted to over $11m and included testing, interpretative services, decentralisation of Austudy and paying people under an efficiency principle. I asked for a breakdown of this figure of $11m into the components just mentioned, and was informed by Mr Power from the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) that a breakdown would be forthcoming. Are these figures now available? If so, can they be incorporated in Hansard? I also ask whether a more detailed cost breakdown can be provided in the Estimates in future on diverse items such as those listed under client services.

—I have just discussed with the officers, as Senator Tierney would have noticed, whether information is available right now. It is not, and I will seek to get it for the honourable senator as soon as possible.
—Can the Minister tell me when that might be available, and can I have an answer to the last part of my question also?
—I am told tomorrow in respect of the first part of the question, and we will get the answer for the second part of the question at the same time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates hearing I also referred to a recent report from the Department of Defence concerning the expenditure of $350,000 on recruiting overseas for engineers. This recruitment drive was subsequently aborted by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which confirmed its policy that people with appropriate qualifications seeking employment in Australia must be considered prior to overseas recruitment and that deviations from this policy would be considered only on a case by case basis. I asked the Department for details of the basis on which the Department of Employment, Education and Training acted to abort the Department of Defence overseas recruitment program. I asked for the actual grounds and the rationale for the action by the Department. I have received an answer, but I ask the Minister for some clarification of the answer that was provided. In the answer I was told that the Department of Employment, Education and Training--
—I wonder whether Senator Tierney can refer us to the specific question or the item?

—I am referring to item 32, entitled engineering recruitment from abroad. It is dealt with on page 72 of the Hansard for Estimates Committee D. In the answer I was told that the Department of Employment, Education and Training had not advised the Department of Defence that it could not recruit overseas. According to the answer, DEET did not become involved in this matter of the recruitment of engineers until 2 January 1991. At that stage DEET was invited to discuss a possible labour agreement with the Department of Defence on the entry of British engineers. The answer went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The DEET officers advised the Department of Defence of the standard requirements of all labour agreements.
I now ask: what are the standard requirements for these labour agreements?

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of those labour agreements, Senator Tierney referred to page D72, I have not been able to find reference to the labour agreements mentioned in his initial question. Can he give me some more assistance in that respect and explain where they are?

—What came back was the fact that these agreements include steps to test local labour markets before commencing recruitment. I was of the understanding that the Department of Defence had already done this but, even though it had tested the local labour market and found that people who had adequate training in this field for engineering for defence were not available, it was not allowed to go ahead with recruitment overseas. Seeing it was stopped by the requirements of the labour agreement from DEET, I ask: what are the standard requirements?

—The impact of this loose arrangement would be that DEET would check with the Commonwealth Employment Service as to the availability of the skills being sought within Australia. To the extent that those skills are available in Australia, we would not advertise overseas for them. From the advice I have been given, we do not see it as anything more formal than that sort of working arrangement, and that would be what Senator Tierney would see as a loose agreement.

—Following on from that, in relation to the skills of people available in Australia, which evidently the Department of Defence has found lacking, I also asked in the Estimates hearing about upgrading the skills of Australian engineers to meet the requirements of the Department of Defence. Can the Minister provide information about the availability and the qualifications of engineers in Australia in relation to the requirements of the Department of Defence? For instance, are there courses already existing in Australia which could produce suitably qualified engineers for the purposes of the Department of Defence and, if not, are there any proposals to establish courses so that costly recruiting programs from overseas might be avoided?

—The short answer is that this Department would check the vacancy market to find out whether the skills were generally available. In terms of the other parts of Senator Tierney's question, such information would not be held within DEET. It might be more appropriate to approach Defence, but I think that even it would not necessarily have a compendium of those skills that Senator Tierney requests.
—Does the Minister have any details on the costs incurred recently when the Department of Defence readvertised for these engineers in Australia?
—That is very much within the province of the Department of Defence; it is not within the province of DEET.

—I am aware that Senator Newman asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) last Wednesday night about the recruitment of engineers and asked for a progress report. On that occasion, the Minister for Defence was unable to provide any information about this, but I was hoping that Minister Bolkus might be able to provide information today, since he has been given notice of the concerns of his Estimates Committee of the high cost, firstly, of recruiting overseas and, secondly, of readvertising locally because of the advice given by DEET. Does the Minister have any further information about the recruitment of engineers by the Department of Defence?

—As I have already stated, that is very much outside the parameters of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and this Committee; it is a matter that could be better pursued with the Department of Defence.

—I thank the Minister for the answers on that series of questions, but I would have thought that, as we put this question on notice and there was an indication in the list that we would probably ask questions, we would have been able to obtain that information.

—Just because an indication is put on a list, all honourable senators know, or they find out very soon after coming into this place, that the Estimates Committee that handles the Department of Employment, Education and Training does not handle the Department of Defence and those questions are better directed to that Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will move on to another item. Under the item entitled `General Matters' in the report of Estimates Committee D there is reference to points raised about the scope of questioning in Additional Estimates. Senator Kemp referred to this item in the report last Thursday, but I want to take the matter further. The Minister kept referring to Standing Orders to confine questioning of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to only those specific items included in the Additional Estimates and to preclude general questions. The report of Estimates Committee D notes that:

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct of hearings, so far as questioning is concerned, is governed more by convention than by Standing Orders, which are silent on the distinction between questions permitted when the main Appropriation Bills are being examined and those permitted in the additional Estimates.
However, the Minister was making a very clear distinction between Budget Estimates and Additional Estimates. He said:
You know the rules of the game and I am sorry that is the way we have got to play it. Estimates committees-
I take it that he meant Budget Estimates-

are different. At Estimates committees you can go through, as I have gone through, and ask whatever you like on the whole portfolio. This is Additional Estimates, and we know that the Standing Orders provide for specific questions.

However, that is not correct. The Standing Orders make absolutely no distinction between Budget Estimates and Additional Estimates. In the hearing, I placed it on record that the Minister was allowing a very narrow range of latitude in questioning. There came a stage during the hearing when Senator Teague requested an adjournment to a private meeting to reach a compromise with the Minister over the scope of questioning, but some members of the Committee continued to express concerns about the Minister's restrictions on the Committee's questions.

I raise this matter because the report concluded that the Senate should provide clarification on the scope of questions to be permitted at Additional Estimates, bearing in mind that there is no distinction in the Standing Orders between annual Estimates and Additional Estimates. I ask the Minister to explain why he kept referring to Standing Orders to insist upon a distinction between annual Estimates and Additional Estimates when the Standing Orders clearly make no such distinction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did refer to Standing Orders. If one goes back to the Hansard of that day, one will find that I even alluded to some specific standing orders. The basic point is that we are considering Additional Estimates and, by their very definition, we are looking at the additional estimates of departments. As a consequence, we would be looking at those extra expenditure items. When one compares that with Estimates, the distinction is quite clear. I did allude to specific standing orders during the discussions at the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point before that I am not the only person who has held this view. There was, apparently, in Estimates Committee A on 16 April a similar dispute when the Chairman of that Committee came down the wrong way and allowed a greater degree of latitude than what I think should have been the case. Senator Bishop raised the point that I raised at our Committee. For the record I quote what she said:

Mr Chairman, with respect, Senator Schacht just asked the Clerk whether this was being paid out of the Additional Estimates. He answered that, no, it was coming out of existing appropriations. Therefore, presumably it is not relevant to this inquiry.

On the same point of order, Senator Walsh interjected. As I say, I share Senator Bishop's view on the reading of the guidelines that should control Additional Estimates and, in doing so, reject the position that was adopted in Estimates A which allows a broader area of examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote again from the report of Estimates Committee D:

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct of the hearings, so far as questioning is concerned, is governed more by convention than by the Standing Orders, which are silent on the distinction between questions permitted when the main Appropriation Bills are being examined and those permitted in the additional Estimates.

In his answer the Minister is still trying to draw this distinction between annual Estimates and Additional Estimates which just does not exist. I think it is important to have this clarified so that we have a proper scope of questioning in Additional Estimates in the future. If the Minister is so convinced that it is covered by Standing Orders, could he please tell us upon which standing order he is making this judgment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to perhaps elucidate a little here. There is latitude given, but the point I think perhaps the honourable senator is missing is that on this occasion we have before us only the supplementary appropriations. When we meet for the full Estimates we have the total appropriations before us. On this occasion the supplementary appropriations contain only a range of issues, unlike the full appropriations which contain every issue that you can possibly imagine within all of the portfolios. That is the distinction which is, quite rightly, being insisted upon within the Senate. In other words, this report is only partially correct.

—Thank you, Madam Chair, for that advice. But I again make the point that the Minister made his point based on Standing Orders, claiming that there was a distinction between the Additional Estimates and the main Appropriation Bills. In the Standing Orders there is no such distinction, so I ask again: what standing order is the Minister referring to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I missed some of your contribution because I was between my room and here while you were speaking, so you may have covered the points I am about to raise. I think there is no real problem with the Standing Orders, but I think the honourable senator may be missing some points, which is I think what you said, Madam Chair. Standing order 26 (1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: At the commencement of each Parliament, Estimates Committees shall be appointed, and shall be called Estimates Committees A, B, C, D, E, and F.
I always thought that that was not very creative, but I could not think of anything better to call them. That is probably beside the point, but let us look-

TALK.START.PARA: —Which subclause?
—Subclause (1). Let us have a look at 26 (2). It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The annual estimates, contained in the documents presenting the particulars of proposed expenditure, and the additional estimates, contained in the documents presenting the particulars of proposed provision for additional expenditure, shall on motion be referred to the Committees for examination and report.

That means that when we have the Budget Estimates we have before us estimates for virtually every part of each department. I suppose the only reason why we would not have any estimates would be if a particular program had stopped and was no longer in existence so there would not be any proposed expenditure.

I think this is what the Minister was probably getting at-he will probably indicate to me if I am wrong. Because in the annual Estimates we have estimates for all parts of the departments-because every part of the departments are getting expenditure-it is very easy to range wide in one's questions. But when we come to the additional expenditure that is normally needed at about this time of the year, we are talking about Additional Estimates. Not every part of the departments require additional expenditure. Although I have never seen it, one might find one department which does not require any additional expenditure at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity the whole lot didn't.
—It would be rather unusual, but it is possible. One may find that only certain parts of the departments require additional expenditure. Subsection (12) says:

SPEECH.PARA: When a Committee considers the estimates, the Chairman shall, without motion, call on items of expenditure in the order decided upon and declare the proposed expenditure open for examination.

In the Additional Estimates the Chairman can bring on only those areas where additional expenditure is required. At that stage one can range far less than one can range in the Budget Estimates. I think that is what the Minister is trying to get at. He might tell me in a moment whether I am correct in outlining what he was saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support Senator Tierney and, in particular, oppose the limited view of the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, who is not only the duty Minister here in the Senate, but who was also the active Minister in Estimates Committee D. I believe he has been more restrictive than any other Minister of this Labor Government. None of his colleagues in the Ministry has given the kind of limited guidelines that he gave to Senate Estimates Committee D on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly oppose Senator Bolkus in his rulings and the way in which he conducted himself in this Committee. The Committee retired and on this occasion-and I support Senator Tierney in these remarks-we differed from the Minister. It is the closest we have come to a motion of no confidence in a Minister conducting Estimates committees. The Minister is a senator for my home State of South Australia. He is also a left wing Minister who happens to be a supporter of the present Government and I think he supported Prime Minister Hawke in this present situation. Despite what Senator Colston says, I do not believe these points of loyalty on the Minister's behalf are consistent with the Standing Orders which I have in front of me.

The publication Standing Orders and Other Orders of the Senate which is before me has been quoted from by Senator Colston at subsections (1) and (2), but I wish to quote it at subsection (12). Subsection (12) says:
When a Committee considers the estimates, the Chairman shall-
in this case the Chairman was Senator Zakharov-
without motion, call on items of expenditure in the order decided upon and declare the proposed expenditure open for examination.

When standing order 26(12) says `declare the proposed expenditure open for examination'-and I believe that is the form that honourable senators have been used to over the last decade at least-it means that we can ask any question under the first item which relates to expenditure for salaries and other direct expenditures of the Department.

Senator Kemp and Senator Tierney have rightly said that this is without limits. I believe that it is appropriate that, under standing order 26 (12), which is on Estimates committees, questions are not restricted in the way that Senator Bolkus idiosyncratically, subjectively and quite singularly has ruled in his conduct of that Committee. I believe that this is a matter of importance not only for this present temporary period of the Labor Government but also for us when we are in government. We should see honourable senators of this chamber being able to ask questions on any matter. It is a quite important matter, and I think Senator Tierney is correct when he says that we should be able to ask a question that relates to the expenditure of government moneys under Additional Estimates.

The Minister, Senator Bolkus, when he was in Estimates Committee D, gave a limited meaning to the questions that we were able to be asked in the Committee. It was the first time in 26 Estimates committees that I had experienced this kind of limitation. When a new honourable senator, Senator Tierney, rightly interpreting the Standing Orders, said that he could ask any question, he was restricted by the Minister in the Estimates Committee. I believe that Senator Tierney was correct.

I can only say that this is a matter of importance to the Senate as a whole because we ought to be able to ask questions that relate to the decisions of this Government at a time when the Senate is interested in examining the expenditure of the Government of the day. I quote subclause (12) again:
When a Committee considers the estimates, the Chairman shall, without motion, call on items of expenditure in the order decided upon and declare the proposed expenditure open for examination.

There is no limitation on that question, and I would like the Committee of the Whole to rule that it is appropriate in the Additional Estimates for questions to be put on any matter that is of concern to an honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —As there is obviously a difference of opinion in relation to the Standing Orders I, as Chairman of Committees, shall refer the matter, probably tomorrow, to the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure for examination. I will couch the letter in the following terms. There seems to be a difference of opinion. Does the Procedure Committee have any difficulty? If there is any difficulty there, should there be some alteration to the standing order to make it more clear? I undertake to do that tomorrow. Perhaps I will do it even tonight if I get time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for doing that, Mr Chairman, and I thank you for your advice on subclauses (2), (3) and (12). When this does go to the Committee, would you have it look also at subsection (13), where it is said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committees may ask for explanations from Ministers of State in the Senate, or officers, relating to the items of proposed expenditure.

Given that we have established fairly clearly tonight that the Standing Orders make no distinction between the Additional Estimates and the Estimates and that there is a convention to allow a wide range of latitude, the Minister was clearly wrong in trying to draw a distinction between Estimates and Additional Estimates on the basis of the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I welcome your taking this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure, but I ask you to do it also in the context that, as Senator Tierney said, items of expenditure should be referred to. Can I draw your attention to page 16--
—Is this a matter that you raised with me the other night?

—Yes, but the specific matter is in fact far more significant than the matter I raised the other night. I draw your attention to page 16 of the explanatory notes for the Department of Employment, Education and Training, relating to running costs. That deals with an item of $715,700 not allocated to function and not allocated to program. The attitude of the Minister for Administrative Services in Senate Estimates means that we are precluded from raising the expenditure of almost three-quarters of a million dollars in Senate Estimates because of this Minister's determination to limit the rights of honourable senators to ask questions. That is absolutely intolerable. That goes across the whole range of the activities of the Department of Administrative Services. It relates in this case to salary increases. In other words, there were additional funding requirements for elements of this Department that this Minister sought to prevent us from asking questions about.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very determined and insistent on this point because, when I raised it the other day with you, it related to a much smaller item. I put to you that three-quarters of a million dollars is an amount which may well merit investigation by honourable senators in an appropriations committee. I think it attempts to muzzle honourable senators on that score. It is an absolute disgrace, but I am not surprised at this coming from this Minister.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure that I would have to take that matter to the Procedure Committee. I might be able to work out something. If I cannot, I shall take it to the Procedure Committee as well. I remember the particular item that you raised, Senator Baume. TALK.START.PARA: —As there are no matters to be raised in respect of the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Committee will consider the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to move to unanswered questions. On 18 April, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Why does Western Australia have to remain with a city book and three country phone books?

I was told that this was because of calling patterns and all of that sort of thing. The main argument was that calling patterns showed that the percentage of calls between the three current directory areas is very small-in other words, 3 per cent. I ask: would that not also apply, say, from Wanneroo to Rockingham? Would not that sort of criteria apply?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Rockyroo?
—Wanneroo-from the northern extremities to the southern extremities of the city. Would not that also apply?

—It well might but I have to say that I know absolutely nothing about it. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, is on his way down and the officers are on their way in. The honourable senator would be able to get a comprehensive response from them. Obviously, the answer to Senator Panizza's question is that it might. I am not sure what political point Senator Panizza is trying to make.
—Mr Chairman, should I wait until Senator Collins and the departmental officers are present? Obviously, no-one can answer the question, except to say that it might well be.
—Senator Panizza, just hold on a minute. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has arrived. Could I ask the Minister whether his officers are in Parliament House.
—Mr Chairman, I checked 10 minutes ago and was told that this Department would not be on for another hour. I do not know who is doing the organisation but I will inquire now.
—I think Senator Collins will return very shortly. The questions that relate to industrial relations cannot be handled by Senator McMullan.

—We are dealing with the Department of Transport and Communications. Estimates Committee F has been called on. There were no questions in relation to the Department of Industrial Relations. The Committee proceeded to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and questions were not asked. The Committee then proceeded to the Department of Transport and Com- munications.
—I thought we were on Industrial Relations.
—Minister, what is the position in respect of the departmental officers?
—They are on their way.
—Senator Collins, when you say that the officers are on their way, does that mean that they are in the building?
—As far as I know, they are. As I say, I inquired 10 minutes ago as to my own attendance and was told that it would be at least an hour before I would be required.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. There is evidently confusion in the chamber which has emerged because the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs did not become the subject of any kind of lengthy debate on the Appropriations. As a result of that, both the Ministry and the Opposition are not in fact ready to go on with the next item in the Appropriations. The appropriations of the Department of Industrial Relations have accidentally been dealt with although senators on both sides were not ready to proceed.
—Yes, they were. They were.

—The Government was ready to proceed; we were not. Now we are in a situation which is exactly the reverse where the Government is not ready to proceed and we are. To even this difficulty out, is it possible to go back to Industrial Relations and deal with it? We are prepared to make arrangements or to handle the matter of the Minister not having his advisers available because of some confusion. I think it might be a nice quid pro quo if the Government might meet us halfway on this matter and let us deal with a few questions in relation to Industrial Relations which is part of the report of Estimates Committee F. Mr Chairman, perhaps you could assist me: can I move a motion to allow consideration of Industrial Relations? Is there some appropriate way in which we can resolve this matter? Do I need to ask for leave?

—The Chair will make a decision. There has obviously been some confusion. I think we should go back to the Department of Industrial Relations. My only concern is that the officers may have seen that there were no questions for them and therefore have gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers from the Department of Industrial Relations may well have left. We are trying to check whether any are still in the building. Certainly some have left. Of course, we are not keen to reopen a long discussion on an issue that has been properly dealt with and finalised. We also do not want to be stupid about it. If there is the capacity to deal with one or two matters quickly, we will try to do it because of the point Senator Michael Baume made with regard to the Department of Transport and Communications and our situation with regard to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Though you, Mr Chairman, may be able to exercise some discretion, the difficulty is that one cannot give leave to go back to it for five minutes. Once we go back to it, we will have to reopen it. If there is some agreed time limit relating to our going back to that Department, that is something we might be prepared to look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty.
—Might I also say for your information, Mr Chairman, that only three reservations for this entire portfolio have been listed in any case, and they are all Senator Panizza's.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a suggestion from the Chair which I hope will be accepted. If it is not accepted, I will make a direction. The point is that we still have in front of us the report of Estimates Committee F. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted. I do not want honourable senators to miss out on making a contribution because of misadventure, and that is what has happened on this occasion. We will go back to the Department of Industrial Relations. I would like those honourable senators who are going to make a contribution to be aware that there may not be officers here because the officers had thought that that part of the Estimates had concluded. I ask them to take that into consideration when asking their questions.

INTERJECT.PARA: We will do the same for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy when we come to it. Again, if officers have left, I trust that honourable senators will take that into account. The Committee will go back to the Department of Industrial Relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the Department of Industrial Relations in a relatively brief manner. I refer to the report of Estimates Committee F to this chamber with particular regard to the reference which was made to the inquiry into and detailed examination by the Estimates Committee of the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, particularly the examination in committee of the relationship between the Department's portfolio mission statement and the various performance standards and indicators for each program area. While it would be fair to say that in examination of the Department we accepted that there were some difficulties in developing various measures of effectiveness with regard to performance standards in the Department, it is still important to place on record my particular disappointment with the standard of the Department's annual report and what would appear to be a somewhat contemptuous attitude by it to the processes of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the Committee hearings, I believe that the report of the Department is inadequate in terms of giving an explanation of the Department's focus, direction and accomplishments for the past year and that the mission statement itself represents little more than a litany of glib motherhood statements and optimistic ideals. Each of the five points referred to in that mission statement really lacks substance when analysed in any detail. They are little more than nice, calming comments which might look very attractive and appealing for the uninitiated but offer little more than dogma. I believe that the Department ought to offer us better than it has in that annual report. The report generally lacks both specific and concrete explanations and background information. For a department the mission of which is to achieve its industrial relations and wider economic and social objectives, I believe that the report is completely inadequate.

At the Committee hearings, the Deputy Secretary of the Department, Mr Bob Marshman, when questioned on the report's mission statement, did not even have a copy available to refer to. I believe that it is somewhat extraordinary for a public servant of Mr Marshman's seniority and experience in the processes of Senate Estimates hearings-a deputy secretary of his level and an old and experienced hand with regard to Estimates committees-not to have such a document available. It simply reinforces what I regard as the inadequate attitude of this Department to the parliamentary processes.

I recall that at the hearings the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, remarked that he was disappointed that I found a lack of substance in the Department's report because he regarded it as adequate. As he saw it, it set out the functions and duties of the portfolio. I suppose that one would expect that sort of comment from the Minister. It is his duty to defend his portfolio, but I believe, as I said earlier, that it is important that this Department make a better effort in terms of its annual reports in the future. I contrast that example-as I will later when we move on-with what I regard as a very comprehensive and adequate report from the Department of Transport and Communications. A comparison of the reports of those two departments, both of which were examined by Estimates Committee F, serves to underline the shortcomings in the report that has been put out by the Department of Industrial Relations.

One issue I raised, again in relation to the annual report and the mission statement, was the statement in the report to the effect that it was the role of the Department to ensure a fair wages outcome. When asked what was meant by a fair wages outcome, I again do not believe that the officers of the Department were able to answer the question. But the Minister intervened to the effect that fair wages were those determined by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In other words, the Department and the Government assume that wage determinations made only by the Industrial Relations Commission are fair and equitable. Therefore, they in effect claim or assert that wages determined in any other manner are not fair. Wages determined by genuine enterprise bargaining, by voluntary agreements entered into by employers and employees, by definition of this Department, are not fair outcomes in terms of wages and conditions. I strongly contest that contention. I say in conclusion that, if that is the modus operandi for this Department, it will have a lot to learn within the next couple of years when it has to serve a future coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a couple of points in relation to this report. In doing so, I will pick up Senator Collins's comments about reservations at the start of this debate, because there certainly was confusion in terms of the starting point. The points that I wish to raise in terms of this matter have all been identified in the report that was brought down. I understand that we can raise issues arising out of the report that was presented to this chamber by the Chairman of the Committee.
—It is a different portfolio.
—We do not have to put an individual reservation on each and every point we want to raise if, in fact, they are included in the report. That is correct, is it not?
—Yes.

—I just wanted to clarify that. The point I raise in terms of the report-it is along similar lines to that made by Senator Chapman-is that the industrial relations report left a lot to be desired, particularly in terms of the detail that I believe is required for us to make a reasonable assessment. I want to talk about the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, its functions and its cost, as I did at the Estimates Committee hearing. I mention the lack of accountability in terms of the various functions that the Industrial Relations Commission has carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: It was quite obvious from the questions that I and other senators asked that the Department of Industrial Relations had no idea, and nor did the Minister himself-although in fairness I think he was somewhat surprised about this-about the costs associated with the various hearings and functions of the Commission. I found this quite extraordinary, particularly when we look at the Commission's budget and see that this year the costs have increased by 10 per cent.

At that time I put some questions on notice-and I am now preparing a list for inclusion in a letter-about the cost of some of the hearings and functions being carried out by the Industrial Relations Commission. I put it to Senator McMullan, who is at the table in the absence of Senator Cook, that the Commission, in performing its functions, should be able to identify the various costs in the different processes which it goes through. I will proceed with those questions in detail in the letter which I have not completed yet.

Tonight I refer to the Harrison inquiry and I ask: what has been the cost of that inquiry? After that inquiry had almost completed its task-I understand from Commissioner Harrison that there were only three days of hearings left to go-we found that both the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union walked out of the inquiry. This inquiry, in fact, came about at the request of the ACTU to endeavour to find a process by which the problems in the meat industry in this country could be overcome. I intend to finalise my further questions in writing. However, can the Minister give us some advice now as to the cost of the Harrison inquiry? It would certainly appear that the hearing could have been sabotaged and it might well turn out to have cost an enormous amount of money. There was even an overseas trip to examine what occurs in the meat industry in other countries, such as killing charges, processing and all the other things that go with it, although the situation which exists in other countries is well known and well documented here in Australia. So it was not necessary, in terms of formulating what we hoped would come out of that inquiry, for that cost to accrue. Can the Minister give us some idea of the cost of the Harrison inquiry to this point?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding to that question, I indicate that there are some things I want to say in response to Senator Chapman's and Senator Crane's more general remarks, but I will do that in one go at the end after everybody has raised individual matters. I do not have a particular costing with regard to the Harrison inquiry. I was aware that Senator Crane raised the cost breakdown issue generally during the Estimates Committee hearing and that we were expecting more detailed questions to be forwarded from him-to which he just referred. It is not going to be an easy process of disaggregation because there are some fixed costs involved in maintaining an industrial relations commission. The question of effectively apportioning them to individual proceedings is going to require some division between fixed costs and the marginal costs added by extra functions. There will be a need for some disaggregation and that will not be straightforward.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one other general remark about the cost breakdowns of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, just to put on the record for the Committee of the Whole that which I am sure Senator Crane is already aware of but which needs to be stated to make the answer comprehensive. The Industrial Relations Commission is an independent statutory body. Its administrative wing, the Australian Industrial Registry, is based in Melbourne and issues its own annual report. This is a separate document from the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations. We need to bear in mind that that is a separate statutory authority with its own reporting arrangements. With regard to the Harrison inquiry, I will get some information for the honourable senator if I reasonably can but, as he would be aware, the officers are not here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that answer. I understand that the officers are not here so I am not seeking details. I fully understand that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is a separate statutory authority but, in terms of preparing its annual report and its costings, the Commission should have to go into the same sort of detail and provide the same sort of information that other statutory authorities provide, so that when one looks at the annual report one can ascertain in much more detail where the money is going.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, when one looks at the annual reports of many other statutory authorities, one can identify, within reason-and I am not asking for every cent to be identified-where the money has gone. One can certainly identify the individual functions to which that money has gone. It is very important for there to be an undertaking that in future the way in which the money is spent in the operation of the Commission will be identified with the various hearings and functions that it carries out. I make the point that there are some incremental costs or overheads which go across the full spectrum. But I believe that there has to be capacity, in terms of integrity and accountability, for a much better financial reporting system for the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —An issue which I omitted to raise in my earlier remarks concerns that part of the report which refers to the expression of concern by the Committee about the failure of the Department of Industrial Relations to monitor the movement of executive salaries in government business enterprises. This is the second time that I have raised the issue. I first raised it at the Estimates Committee with regard to the 1990-91 Budget and then again at these Supplementary Estimates. But the Government is still unable to provide the answers to those questions on the basis that it is not the responsibility of this Department to monitor those salaries. In fact, as I pointed out in those hearings, it is the responsibility of the various government business enterprises to advise the Remuneration Tribunal of their intentions with regard to executive salaries, and of course the Remuneration Tribunal comes within the responsibility of this Department.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that this Department has information with regard to the salary packages paid to executives in government business enterprises and is, therefore, obligated to make that information available to this Committee on request. This is even more important now with the introduction of performance pay for Senior Executive Service officers. So I would urge the Government to ensure that, if not immediately but certainly by the time of the next Estimates Committee hearings, I can be provided with that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to respond briefly to the comments of Senator Crane and Senator Chapman. I indicate firstly, to follow on from that which Senator Crane said earlier and subsequently, that the Government is not resisting the general question that the Industrial Relations Commission has to be accountable in its expenditure and ought to report as comprehensively and in as detailed a manner as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In every area of accountability there is a balance between the comprehensiveness of the information for the purpose of accountability and the cost of compiling and providing that information. There is, on each occasion, a balance that has to be struck and there will be a balance that has to be struck again. But as a matter of general principle we do not challenge the requirement that it should be accountable as are other bodies which spend the taxpayers' money.

I should add to my previous remarks about the Harrison inquiry to indicate that it is a very atypical example-a special case. The inquiry is essentially comprised only of Commissioner Greg Harrison, who is doing the work as an addition to that of his own panel of industries for which he is responsible as a commissioner. I provide that piece of information for the record.

With regard to the question of executive remuneration, we do have devolution, which means that the reporting requirements of government business enterprises are those required of comparable private sector business enterprises in terms of the disclosure required by the Companies Act. Those disclosures are provided in the same form, in that tabular form, and they will continue to be provided in that way. That seems to me to be the appropriate way.

I want to respond briefly to the more generalised critique. Certainly to the extent I have had a chance to study the papers of the Committee, I shared the general view that the question of performance standards and indicators is important across the whole of the public sector. If the Committee was unanimously of the view that there needs to be more effort in developing more effective measures of outcomes as opposed to measures of activity, I point out that it is more difficult for a department of this type, but in general that is in keeping with the trend in public sector reform. I do not have an argument with it.

We need to temper that, what seems on the face of it to be a very proper recommendation, with a recognition of the quality and quantity of the work done by the officers in their Department. I would not want the record to indicate that the criticisms that have been made-some of which may well have some element of merit in them-are the only views that are held in the Senate about either the quality or the quantity of the work provided by very many of the excellent officers working on behalf of the taxpayers in that Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Does that complete the questioning for the Department of Industrial Relations? The Committee will now proceed to the Estimates for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is reference in the report of Estimates Committee F to whole farm planning in regard to the Government's Landcare program. This again was a follow-up from questions that were asked in the Estimates Committee in the Budget session last year about the difficulty which a number of land-holders were having in obtaining access to the scheme because at that stage the full details had not been finalised and because the requirement to have the scheme approved by a designated officer meant that there was difficulty in obtaining the time from those designated officers in order to gain approval.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulties in that regard are referred to again in this report. As the report indicates, we are expecting legislation that will increase substantially the number of agencies that can approve whole farm plans. Also, there is to be some modification to the actual requirement and no longer will a whole farm plan be required to be approved to obtain the appropriate tax deduction for Landcare on rural properties. Can the Minister advise the Committee what is proposed in that regard?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is proposed that there will be a Government amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) which is in the Senate at the moment. Discussions are under way at the moment between the office of the Minister and the representatives of the Opposition. It will be in the general direction that Senator Chapman referred to. The detail is under some discussion and receiving finetuning at the moment. I expect it to be introduced into the Senate any day now. Discussions are going on and I am confident-and representatives of the Opposition have indicated to me they share the confidence-we will get an agreed outcome on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) this whole farm plan concept and the changes that are occurring. I wish to raise the mechanism by which a farm plan or a part farm plan may be approved. In terms of tax deduction, why do we need a bureaucracy to be established to approve this system? Why can we not have what occurs in other areas-self assessment for taxation?

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Minister recognise the difficulty involved in getting people who have more expertise and knowledge about the situation than the farmer himself? The plan is being designed and set up for what are essentially conservation purposes to minimise, as far as one can, land degradation, which is in everybody's interests. Why do we have to set up a group of people around the country, in an area where there is an enormous lack of expertise? Would such people be any better or have more expertise than the individual farmer in designing and planning, whether it be for contour banks or putting in trees or whatever, to perform a water drainage function?

Why do we have to go past the planning expertise of the farmer and have other people giving that particular plan a tick or a signature, when it is most unlikely that very many of those giving that signature would have as much knowledge of the property and its requirements as the farmer or the land user himself?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are, in the administration of tax and tax concessions, always the competing pressures of ensuring that the requirements of the law are properly being complied with and that the concession is being used for the purpose for which it was originally intended on the one hand and, on the other, the benefit that essentially flows from the move to self-assessment across the Income Tax Act as a whole, which says that we do not want unreasonably to put requirements on taxpayers to have to undergo expense or difficulty in discharging their obligation. How the balance is struck on every occasion is always a matter for judgment. But I would have thought that in this area there was a second element, without straining my limited expertise in this area and consistent with what I said to Senator Chapman about moving towards what I think will be an agreed and modified position, and there is also--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under session order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is also the distinct possibility in these sorts of circumstances that some farmers at least will gain significant benefit from the advice or what I guess at least can be called a second opinion. Many farmers do have great expertise and they are perfectly entitled to prepare their farm plan for the purpose of the new tax arrangements but if claims are to be made for the cost of fencing to prevent that degradation, the plan will need to be approved by an authorised officer or consultant.

SPEECH.PARA: That may not strike the balance perfectly and, even with the changes that are envisaged, we may need to make further modifications as it goes along. I think it is a move in the right direction. I think we are trying to strike the balance between protecting the revenue and not imposing unreasonable burdens on the taxpayers. We are trying also in discussions with interested parties and the Opposition to come to a workable arrangement balancing those two pressures.

If, as it develops, we find we have not struck the balance as best we might, we will have to continue to look at it over time. I think at the moment, having had more experience from my own point of view in looking at this in comparison with other amendments to the Income Tax Act that we have made rather than come to it as one with a particular expertise about the issues to which this particular deduction relates, the balance does not seem to me to be unreasonable but we will certainly need to keep our eye on it as it develops. I agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a follow-up to the Minister's answer, for which I thank him, my question is in the terms of that answer. I understand that what the Minister is getting at but I do not believe the practicality of the situation, which exists on the ground, is going to suffice. We have to go back to the Budget of last year, since this move was introduced. A farmer can prepare his own farm plan but he has to get it endorsed. In the case that currently exists in Western Australia in terms of this, there is a process for approving farm plans but he has to wait one, two, three years, or currently the provision can be up to five years, before he can get that plan endorsed. If he proceeds with it and it is endorsed sometime down the track after he has carried out some of the work which is involved in that particular farm plan, will, in fact, that work be accepted because it was done before the signature was placed on the approval of it as an acceptable farm plan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I think this is a matter better pursued in the debate about Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), not in the debate on the report of this Estimates Committee. We will be coming to that in the next week or so in the Senate, and I would be happy to enter into that discussion then, when more of these details will have been worked out and we will have a concrete proposal before us, and the implications of it will be able to be debated here in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not really relate to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Senator Crane is really now talking about a question of the administration of the Income Tax Act. That is a question which will be properly dealt with when we deal with that Bill, when the officers from the Australian Taxation Office will be here, when we have the final proposal before us and when we can pursue it in detail in the committee stage in this chamber or, if by some mischance we do not get agreement and it goes off to a committee, we can pursue it there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Committee's attention to the issue that I raised in the Estimates Committee hearing on 18 April, the joint venture fishing operations from Groote Eylandt in the Northern Territory. Anyone who takes an interest in the Hansard of 18 April will know that I specifically raised this matter with regard to the harvesting trepang and the venture being a cooperative one between the local Aboriginal interests of Groote Eylandt, the Kailis fishing enterprise which operates out of Bartalumba Bay on Groote Eylandt and a negotiated venture with Indonesian interests.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that this matter has been commented on, on page 7 of the report of Estimates Committee F and that some concern has been expressed by the Committee with regard to the ongoing management of such an important joint venture fishery arrangement. However, I am concerned that the question taken on notice and then answered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy appears to have been misinterpreted. My question was specifically with regard to the harvesting of trepang. The answer is in the context of the harvesting of trochus shell.

I hope the issue can be clarified. The subsequent details given in the answer do, in fact, relate to trepang as opposed to trochus shell.The two are quite distinctly different, as I think anyone involved in fisheries would be well aware. Trochus shells, of course, are basically harvested, taken to various Asian places and are used primarily in the production of various paint products and have a different appeal whereas trepang, of course, is a delicacy particularly in the cuisine of many Asian areas. There is a great potential to develop the trepang industry out of Groote Eylandt. I am certainly aware from discussions that I have had recently on the island that the Aboriginal owners in the area are keen to pursue the joint venture arrangements. I am also aware that the Kailis fishing interests which have had a long association in that area are also keen to pursue the matter.

My first question is whether the specific answer that was given with regard to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service related to trepang as opposed to trochus and, secondly, I would ask what discussions the Department has had with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service which I understand has frustrated the development of this important joint venture arrangement between the Aboriginal people, the local fishing interests and the Indonesian interests, by insisting that a very detailed management fishery plan will have to be developed because of the nature of trepang harvesting.

From my discussions with officers of the fishing industry in the Northern Territory, and specifically with the Kailis operators at Groote Eylandt, I understand that the trepang proposed to be harvested is very common. Unfortunately, for whatever reason, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has included this particular common species in its list of endangered species and, therefore, it is precluding the issue of an appropriate fisheries licence by the Northern Territory authorities.

Given that there is a demonstrated market-I believe that Chinese buyers have shown an interest in taking some 40 tonnes a month-I am concerned that the answer given to me with regard to quarantine may, in fact, not be the correct one and that other agencies of the Federal Government are frustrating this important industry and project from getting off the ground.

I understand that there are other species of trepang that could more appropriately need to be protected. It is surprising that they are not listed on the Australian National Parks and Wildlife list of endangered species. I seek clarification that there is every intention to have this matter resolved quickly and promptly so that all interests can gain appropriate benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to Senator Tambling's first point, on the face of it, the answer looks as if it should follow logically from the queries that he raised, but I note the odd misstatement about trochus shells as against trepang. I will have to get someone to confirm whether that is correct or not. It seems to follow logically from the questions Senator Tambling raised, and probably does, but I will certainly get that confirmed for him.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter raised about the National Parks and Wildlife Service is a new one and not one that I or the officers present were previously aware of. All I can say is that we note that Senator Tambling has raised it and we will get someone to examine it and report to him. If it is a continuing problem, we will make sure that it is drawn to the attention of the Minister and action taken to get the outcome expedited.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further questions, we will move to the Department of Transport and Communications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go back to where I started last time--
—It would help me if you did because I was not here.
—I asked the following question at the Estimates Committee hearing:

SPEECH.PARA: Why does Western Australia have to remain with a city book and three country phone books?
Amongst other things, I was given the following written answer:
Calling patterns (see Attached 2)-
I will get to that in a minute-
show that the percentage of calls between the three current directory areas is very small-less than 3%.

Using that argument, could not the Minister say the same about the extremities of a city which still has one book? Taking the northern end and the southern end, Perth would have exactly the same situation. Would that be any more or less than three per cent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That point is not particularly relevant to the reason why-as Telecom explained, frankly, I think, very reasonably-there are three regional telephone books instead of one consolidated book. That is, principally, that the production of one consolidated book would require an additional 250 tonnes of paper to doing it in the way that it is currently done. Secondly, around half a million dollars in unnecessary expenditure would be incurred by doing it that way as well. Further to that, it provides a more convenient and less expensive service for advertisers to be able to target their advertising more appropriately to regional directories than to have to carry advertising in one single directory to cover almost the whole of the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, they are cogent reasons why it is sensible-both environmentally and economically-for Telecom to produce the books in the way it does. Further to that, Telecom has pointed out that, to the extent of the figures that Senator Panizza has just mentioned-that is, the 3 per cent crossover between the three directories-a free dial-in information service is, in any case, available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. Information other than phone numbers is available in the book. As the Minister said, that service is free. I make the point in passing that those 260 tonnes of extra paper could probably be recycled for use at some other time.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to the research results on the next page which just show how the questions are asked. There is a question on directory satisfaction which shows that the numbers of satisfied residential customers is 72 per cent, and business customers 51 per cent. I understand that the numbers are down on the business customers and nowhere near those of residential customers. That means that 49 per cent of customers are not satisfied. They certainly have not been taken into consideration very much.

In the bottom section there is a question on preference. The number of business customers who express a preference for one country phone book is 73 per cent, and it is 59 per cent of residential customers. Would the Minister agree with me that the preference of country business users and residential customers may not have been very well adhered to?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not agree. The reason I do not agree is that the research identified that the need for users and business users to have more than one regional telephone directory is understood. A service is provided and advertised by Telecom that allows these people to readily obtain copies of the telephone directories they require by accessing a free call to Telecom. I have to say that saving 260 tonnes of unnecessary paper, half a million dollars in unnecessary expenditure-the research demonstrates that there is only a small crossover between the books-and, in addition, providing a free service by providing additional books for whoever requires them, is a pretty responsible approach by Telecom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to the National Rail Freight Corporation on which I asked a question at the time and put questions in writing. I asked various questions, and I will give the Minister a brief run-down of them. With less than three months to go before the promised starting date of the National Rail Freight Corporation, I asked what decisions had been made about the headquarters site, the chief executive and things such as signalling and shareholding.
