The answer at the time was that these matters would be subject to consideration by the Government, and further negotiations and meetings of the relevant Commonwealth and States transport Ministers in mid-June 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: With what has been going on lately in two States the Minister probably has not had that meeting, but the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made certain announcements last year-and I certainly agree-that this venture with the National Rail Freight Corporation will provide a lot in improving rail transport. This will put rail in a much better competitive position next year. Could the Minister tell me what is going on at the present moment? I asked the Minister a question in this place about five weeks ago, and he told me that certain things had not been put in place but progression was at hand. Yet we were able to read what someone from an inquiry had to say to the National Farmers Federation which was, more or less, an outline of a program, and the Minister did not seem to know quite what was going on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing to add to the previous answers that I have given on this matter. The matter still revolves around-unsurprisingly, I might say-a disagreement between the Federal Government and the States as to the extent of the equity that each of those constituent parties to this agreement will contribute. It requires an agreement of all the governments to reach a conclusion in relation to national rail freight, and the current disagreement revolves around the amount of money that is going to be contributed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government remains committed to this extremely important initiative. But to get an agreement we must have the compliance of all the parties. The information that I provided to Senator Panizza still stands correct. A meeting is scheduled for this month to continue the process. It is a difficult process. I am sure that eventually it will be resolved. However, very largely it comes down to the question of the relative balance between the amounts of money to be contributed by the States and the amount of money that has been offered-that is, $150m-by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer and I hope that we will see some progress in the near future. The next question I asked, on the land transport side of things, was:

SPEECH.PARA: Has any agreement been reached on a charging regime for heavy vehicles? Is there any indication of the likely solution?
The answer was:

The report of the special Premiers' Conference Overarching Group on Land Transport contains a package of road transport reform measures for Heads of Government to consider, including a more equitable system of charges based on the costs heavy vehicles impose on the nation's road system.

What system of calculation does the Government use? What does it take into consideration in arriving at that figure? Later on I will be asking about the results of that inquiry. Does the Government take into consideration a fuel levy that is already paid, sales tax paid on a vehicle, sales tax paid on tyres, sales tax paid on oil and grease and licence fees already paid? Will those figures be taken into consideration in what is described by the Minister as a more equitable system of recovering costs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, all of those costs will be taken into consideration. I say by way of explanation that the reason the matter has not yet been resolved is that the Government is responding positively to the representations that have been received from remote Australia. Indeed, a significant amount of lobbying has been going on. I have been personally involved in that, as has the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, and there have been some ineffectual efforts from outside the fence by Senator Tambling, who is waving at me across the chamber. More particularly, as a result of a commitment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave to truck operators in Mount Isa, a meeting was recently convened which I attended, along with the Federal member for the Northern Territory and, I must say, a very effective group of industry lobbyists-whom Senator Tambling probably would have met, because a number of them were certainly present at the conference in Alice Springs that he attended-and representations were made to the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister gave commitments that those industry representatives would have an opportunity to become directly involved in the process by being involved in actual meetings of the officers' committee that is determining this issue now. He also gave an absolute commitment to them, which I think was repeated publicly-and the only confusion I have over this is that I certainly heard it publicly said, but I cannot recall whether it was by the Prime Minister himself or the representatives of that group, who would quite properly have made it public-that the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission's report at this point would not be proceeded with. In fact, I think the exact words he used were that they were history. I was there when that was said. He said that the Premiers Conference procedure would be taking over and research would be carried out, and that this group would continue to be consulted. I know that the process has not yet been concluded. The reason that it has not been concluded, I am thankful to say, is that the Government is responding positively to the representations from industry that it is continuing to receive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. He has just answered my next question: he cannot tell me the results of the special Premiers Conference. That has come and gone. I take the point that he does not have the result of those further considerations. Moving on in the same area, I refer to the introduction of B-doubles in all of Australia. I understand that some work has been done on calculating what sort of charging, on an Australia-wide basis, will apply to the B-doubles, I understand at a special rate. Can the Minister give us an indication of what that rate will be? Can he say why tonne for tonne it should be more, if that it is the case, than that which applies to the standard configurations that we have now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot. In fact, I have just answered that question. The process is ongoing. Again, I am thankful to say that those final rates have not yet been set, and the matter is continuing to be discussed with industry and the Government. Just for my own information, I ask Senator Panizza, because these matters have not been the subject of reservations, to which part of the report he is referring.
—I am further examining an answer to question 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister a couple of questions on the same issue, relating specifically to the conference on the transport needs of people living in the remote and rural areas of Australia, which was held earlier this year and which both the Minister and I attended in Alice Springs. During the Estimates process I placed a question on notice asking when the report of that conference would be publicly released and whether a copy could be made available to the appropriate Senate Estimates Committee. The reply given to me in the Committee was:

SPEECH.PARA: The report is scheduled to be publicly released by 31 May 1991 and will be available to the committee.

Why have we not yet received a copy of that report and, given that 31 May has now come and gone, why are delays being experienced? What issues will the report specifically address arising from the conference and will any special recommendations be made to the Government as part of the process that the Minister described in his answer to Senator Panizza? This is a most important issue for people living in the remote parts of Australia. I am glad to note the Minister's acknowledgment that the recommendations of the earlier Butcher report have been superseded by events. I also ask whether the Minister is in any position to indicate the likely increases. There were phenomenal increases proposed, particularly with regard to truck registration fees. I think the figures being bandied around at the time that the Butcher report came out were that a number of transport operators who would normally have been expected to pay about $4,000 per annum could be up for liabilities of between $60,000 and $70,000. If this matter is now being reviewed, is the Minister now able to indicate, as a result of the report that we were due to see on 31 May or any work going forward to the Premiers Conference or through the Department for this year's Budget, just how far in advance of the former registration fees or what proportion the increases are likely to be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Tambling's first question is that the report will certainly be published. Its production is imminent; it is in the final stages of preparation. It involves coordination between two departments-my own Department and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy-and I am advised that it will be released very shortly and will certainly be made public.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer to Senator Tambling's second question is no; I cannot give that information yet. Representations have been made by Senator Tambling, myself and others in this process, and I thought they were made very effectively by the industry group at the meeting with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In remote Australia, a trucking company services particular clients on a regular basis almost exclusively over roads which would, without argument, not receive any particular benefit from any increased charges that might be paid by the truck operators that use them. Indeed, the principals of the companies that have made representations to us say that they do not realistically or reasonably expect-because of the very limited use that the roads have-that they would be massively upgraded. Indeed, that is not a demand that they are making. That is one problem with a universally imposed charge which is currently being reconsidered by the Government.

I also make the obvious point that the Inter-State Commission's report to the Government is precisely that; it is a report to the Government. It does not indicate Government policy. It is simply the result of what I think is fundamentally very good research by the Inter-State Commission, which has clearly raised problems in particular areas involving remote Australia which the Government, to its credit, is now giving very sympathetic consideration to. That consideration is not yet concluded, I am pleased to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the estimates for the Department of Transport and Communications, in contrast to my somewhat critical remarks with regard to the Department of Industrial Relations, I found the annual report of this Department a very good one, in terms of its attention to detail and the explanations given, its design and presentation and the relatively fair way in which it dealt with transport and communication issues. I commend the Department on its report. I hope that the Department of Industrial Relations will take a leaf out of this Department's book in the future when preparing its reports. However, there are a couple of issues I wish to raise with regard to questions that I left on notice with the Department which I consider have been answered completely inadequately subsequent to the hearings of the Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The first was a question I asked in relation to the fringe benefits tax for various bodies under the responsibility of the Department of Transport and Communications. That question was to the effect:
What were the total sums paid in each of (a) 1988-89 and (b) 1989-90, in fringe benefits taxes by the following:
Australian National Line Ltd
AUSSAT Pty Ltd
Australian Airlines Ltd
ABC
Australian Broadcasting Tribunal
Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board
Australian National Railways Commission
Australian Postal Corporation (Australia Post)
Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Council
Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL)
Telecom
Australian Transport Advisory Council
Broadcasting Council
Civil Aviation Authority
Federal Airports Corporation
Independent Airfares Committee
Inter-State Commission
Maritime Services Advisory Committee
OTC Ltd
Promotions and Appeals Boards of the Department of Communications
Qantas
Railway Industry Council
SBS
Transport Industries Advisory Council
The written reply I received to that question referred to an apparently similar question which had been asked by a colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Rocher. The answer was:
Mr Rocher asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley a similar question in the House of Representatives on 19 November 1990.
It then simply reproduced Mr Beazley's answer which was to the effect:
The answer to the Honourable member's question is as follows:
The total FBT payments made on behalf of all State Offices and Central Office for the Department of Transport and Communications was as follows:
The answer continued:

I am not prepared to ask statutory and other bodies under my portfolio responsibility to commit the resources to obtaining the information requested, particularly when the information is regarded as ``Commercial-in-Confidence'' for those bodies involved in commercial activities.

I regard that response as totally inadequate. It is a legitimate question for this Estimates Committee to ask the Minister and the Department the specific details of fringe benefits tax paid by authorities within the control of the Department. Certainly, the Australian Taxation Office requires similar information from every other commercial operation in the country. I believe the responsibilities which this Estimates Committee has to fulfil require that a question such as this be answered. I ask the Minister whether he will provide an answer to that question.

The second issue I want to raise is this: I asked a question about the funding of share dealings of Qantas Airways Ltd, particularly its purchase and the purchase of other commercial bodies of shares in Air New Zealand. I have received the answer to that question only in the past 24 hours. I have not had the opportunity to do any further investigation of the answer. In respect of the answers that were provided, in each case the answer was annotated as provided by Qantas. I wonder whether that indicates that the Department itself has some reservations as to the satisfactory nature of the answers provided in that it was not prepared to put its own imprimatur on those answers and whether some additional information might be forthcoming in the future in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I answer that question, I will provide some additional information to Senator Tambling in respect of his previous question, which I am sure he will be pleased about, which I did not know about. In respect of the consultation issue, which I recall very vividly was raised at the Alice Springs conference by the road transport industry in the Northern Territory, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) responded, prior to the release of the report, positively to that issue being raised at the Alice Springs conference and has appointed Jim Cooper, who Senator Tambling knows, from the Northern Territory to the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I have examined the answer provided to the question on notice by Senator Chapman and I can add nothing to it at this point. The information is indeed as Senator Chapman has described it, with the aggregate amounts given. All I can undertake to do is to raise with Mr Beazley, who provided the answer, Senator Chapman's dissatisfaction with it and ask Mr Beazley whether he is in a position to provide further detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Estimates, I asked for a copy of the terms of reference with regard to the greenhouse gas emissions report, or proposed report, and I have received one. The document is broken into three parts. The preliminary part A says that a forecast will have been prepared for consideration by the working group and that a final forecast will be available in early May. Then it says that questions under parts B and C will be determined by the technical group in early May. I ask: is that report by the working group available? If so, when will we be able to get a copy of it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The information I have been provided with is that, yes, the report will be available this month and it will be published specifically to invite public comment on it. So the honourable senator will have an opportunity to do that.
—I want to follow up on questions B and C. Will the report by the technical group in early May also be made available?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have been given by the Department is that the officers cannot be absolutely certain about it, but they think the answer is yes. We will chase that up for Senator Crane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to move to a series of questions that I asked with regard to the Auditor-General's report. These relate, firstly, to the reporting functions of the fixed assets of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), the audit of the Civil Aviation Authority's Treasury activities and also control over flight records after the Auditor-General had identified problems in the levying of aviation charges. I must say that the answers I have been given are, at best, very general. I guess they might cover a fairly broad area. In view of these answers-and I note that the Auditor-General was somewhat critical of the reporting functions of a number of these authorities-I ask what action has been taken by the Government in terms of making sure that their reporting functions are improved and that there is more detail provided? I would particularly like to draw attention to that part of the Auditor-General's report which identifies the problems in the levying of aviation charges where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of missing flights is being addressed by greater emphasis in the Avcharges Centre . . .

It then goes on to say that it is almost impossible to overcome the particular problems that exist as far as that reporting function and the levying are concerned. Could I have an explanation in the answer to the general question I asked as to why that is difficult, because it seems to me that it should be a fairly straightforward bookkeeping exercise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Crane's first question, a full stocktake will be completed during this current financial year-that is, by the end of this month.
—Could the Minister answer the second part of my question which concerned the aviation charges?
—I am sorry, could you repeat that question?
—My question was with regard to the levying of aviation charges. It says that it is almost impossible--
—This is not an SBS question, then?
—No.
—It is a bit hard jumping division by division.
—I could ask my questions individually, but for the sake of time I combined the three questions together.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I now understand what is happening. It makes it a little difficult, particularly for the officers present, if we leap from one division to another-from the Civil Aviation Authority to the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). I have just hauled the SBS people into the chamber. If we could deal with it in a routine manner it would help.

—I could perhaps make a helpful suggestion. I know Senator Panizza wants to complete the line of questioning that he was dealing with. I, too, have some questions on the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) which I am happy to deal with at the same time as Senator Crane. I also have some questions about the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and I know that Senator Tambling has some too. I also have some questions about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). Perhaps if we can complete Senator Panizza's line of questioning and then move to either the FAC or the SBS and ABC we might be able to deal with the officers sensibly.
—That would be helpful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to return to the area of land transport. I direct the Minister to question F103 about the black spots program. I asked whether we could have a list of projects funded in 1991 under the black spots program. I notice that, to date, about $36m has been allocated to each State-roughly $14m to New South Wales, $11m to Victoria and so on. I know that the Minister has said that other allocations are to be made to Queensland, Western Australia and even the Northern Territory, but it seems to me that there is no rhyme or reason in the figures as they appear for the money allocated to those States.

SPEECH.PARA: Could the Minister give me some indication as to how the figures might finish up and whether there is a reasonable balance between the States? Could he also indicate what is likely to be the total allocation in the financial year 1990-91? The Prime Minister announced that it would be $100m, but we must bear in mind that the tax which was going to fund it, the luxury car tax, was taken away. I do not know what the Minister is shaking his head about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not making much sense to either myself or the officers. What does the honourable senator mean when he says can I give him some idea how it will finish up? What does he mean precisely?
—What will be the total allocation in 1990-91, because the Prime Minister--
—For what, Senator?
—For the black spots program. Did you not understand that from the beginning, Minister?
—No, Senator.

—I am asking what is likely to be the total amount of money allocated to each State under the black spots program-if that will be somehow evened up in view of population-bearing in mind that the source of those funds, which was supposed to be $100m from the luxury car tax, has been cut off.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we do not have those figures here now. We can get them, but they are contained in the Budget Papers and they will be as laid out in the Budget.
—I certainly disagree that the total concept was laid out in the Budget. These funds were going to be allocated according to submissions which were to be put forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct, but the total amount of money allocated to that program is contained in the Budget Papers.
—Where is the rest of the money coming from? Is it coming out of Consolidated Revenue, because the Government did budget that it was going to raise $100m from the luxury car tax?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, the source of the funds is not relevant-that is, where the money is gained from is not relevant to the amount of money which has been allocated to the program. An amount of money has been allocated and it will be disbursed, irrespective of where we have got it from.

—That is what I asked, and I finally have my answer. I will move to the land transport question on uniform road rules. In question F103 I asked: has any agreement been reached on uniform road rules and regulations? This was tied up with the Australian traffic code, concerning heavy vehicles, et cetera. We know that we will not be able to get the heavy vehicle legislation in place. That was to be considered at the Premiers Conference. I was wondering whether the issue of the uniform code for road rules was settled at the Premiers Conference last Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer that I gave earlier in respect of charges stands in respect of this matter as well. The whole process of the report and recommendations of the Inter-State Commission has been taken over to some extent by the process of the Special Premiers Conference, which was an initiative of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and was taken up by the Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: That matter is still under way but, irrespective of arguments about equity-about money, for example, that is to go into the national rail freight system-or about charges that are to be levied under the system for uniform registration, there remains a commitment to the early establishment of a uniform national code of regulation. But it is still subject to the process of the Special Premiers Conference, and that process, as I say, is currently responding to representations it is continuing to receive, now directly, from industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that conclude the road transport questions? Are there any questions on aviation-Federal Airports Corporation?

—It seems sensible to complete transport before we move to communications. The questions that I wish to ask relate to the answers that were provided to the questions that I asked during the Estimates Committee hearings which were not answered at the time of the tabling of the report. Thus, I refer to the questions that I asked specifically concerning baggage handling equipment at Sydney Airport. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) may remember that I was concerned about why the contract was awarded to a German company. At first instance, I ask: what was the date on which the contract was in fact awarded?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a detailed response to some questions which were asked during the Committee. They are listed here from (a) to (e). There are five questions, but the date that the contract was awarded is not in the response. I will see whether I can find that information. With respect, might I say that the position, as I reiterated at the Committee and as I do so again now, is that the Federal Airports Corporation is a body which has its own commercial charter and which conducts its business in terms of whom it awards its-Senator Bishop is shaking her head. I can assure her that that is the case.
—That is not the point, though.

—With respect, it is the point I am making, which does not relate directly to Senator Bishop's question about dates but which is in relation to the whole line of questioning that was run on a German firm getting the contract. I must say that this approach stands in stark contrast to the attitude that has been demonstrated with some particular virulence on the Opposition benches for some weeks with respect to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and the outrageous hide he had, presumably, in intervening on behalf of Australian companies. Presumably, Senator Bishop is now demanding to know why I did not do the same, having complained about it with respect to Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister almost has a touch of clairvoyance. I was intending to refer to those discussions that we had earlier and to be absolutely consistent in the attitude that I have. My objection to the actions of Senator Bolkus had nothing to do with whether or not it was an Australian company or otherwise; it was his intervention in the tendering process, which was improper.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case I intend to ask whether or not the Federal Airports Corporation followed the procurement guidelines. Despite the fact that there is a tendency by this Government to push operations off-budget, whilst it is in the public sector and it is public money it is accountable to this Parliament. If the Minister wants to push it off-budget totally, then he should privatise it. Until such time as he does, it is still in the public arena and as such accountable here. What was the method of procurement that was used? Did the team that determined that method of procurement follow the ANZ Bank's procurement guidelines?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Bishop's assertion, this is public money and properly subject to these processes. As Senator Bishop knows full well, it is certainly appropriate to examine this matter in the full Estimates process, but it is not appropriate-it was done only out of courtesy to Senator Bishop; I was chided for it during the Committee hearings by the Chairman of the Committee-to have officers present, at considerable expense and inconvenience, of organisations for which there is no appropriation whatever in the supplementary Estimates. I simply make that point; there is none. That also includes the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service.

SPEECH.PARA: I perhaps will have to take a different view on this in the future, in the sense that a number of newspaper articles were recently published, which frankly I agreed with, expressing what was considered to be a scandalous procedure in terms of the Estimates Committee procedures of this Senate. The articles related to having rafts of highly paid officers swanning around Parliament-I think the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation was mentioned; an occasion which I have witnessed myself in respect of the Australian Bureau of Statistics-for days at a time, finally to present themselves to the Committee and be asked no questions at all.
It may well be, and indeed is, a proper matter for full debate in the full Estimates process. It is no good Senator Bishop banging her desk in exasperation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just get on with it.

—Coming from Senator Bishop, that is cute, as any reader of the Hansard of this Committee will attest. It is a bit tedious when all these issues were canvassed at the Estimates Committee and subsequently followed up in answers given--
—No, they were not.
—Does Senator Bishop not have these answers?
—Indeed I have, right here.
—These issues have been again raised in the Committee of the Whole when these organisations do not have a cent in supplementary estimates even being provided to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the Minister: enough is enough. When we sat here on Thursday evening we were in the middle of Estimates Committee D. We had to take on Estimates Committee E at 8 o'clock because Senator Bolkus was required for a numbers exercise. We had to have Senator Tate because nobody wanted Senator Tate and he was irrelevant to the Government's processes. We sat here until half past one in the morning. We could have sat here until half past three in the morning or 4 o'clock, if necessary, to have finished the business, but Senator Bolkus had to be out there getting numbers for Mr Hawke. He was getting numbers and doing deals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister should not talk to me about keeping swathes of people outside whilst we are conducting the business of the Committee when he put party political numbers in front of what is going on in the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, we are dealing with the Supplementary Estimates. The matter under consideration is the Department of Transport and Communications. I would be grateful if you would restrict your remarks to the relevance of the matter before the Committee.
—Madam Temporary Chairman, I would be delighted if you would have an even-handed ruling on that matter.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask that Senator Bishop withdraw that comment. It is an insult to the Chair and this chamber to talk about a lack of even-handedness on the part of the Chair. I believe that Senator Bishop ought to apologise and withdraw that remark.

—On the point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: the reflection was that I required a ruling with regard to the intervention of Minister Collins. I was not reflecting on your ruling; I was simply reflecting on the fact that he had gone on at great length about time that is wasted in this place by other people when it was the business of putting numbers together in his Party's faction fighting that caused us to have rafts of public servants waiting outside.
—Senator Bishop, will you return to the matter before the Committee?

—Indeed, I will, Madam Temporary Chairman. If Minister Collins recalls a letter written by Minister Beazley dealing with what would be dealt with and what would not be dealt with in the Supplementary Estimates, he will remember that he said that not only was it a question of an appropriation but indeed any CSO that was involved. If he is going to tell me that there is no CSO for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Special Broadcasting Service and, I would imagine, the Federal Airports Corporation, I would be sad.
—No Supplementary Estimates is what I said.
—According to the interpretation of Senator Collins's senior Minister, in the Supplementary Estimates CSOs are important because they amount to the same as an appropriation.
—To quote you yourself, why do not you just get on with it?
—I intend to get on with it, but there are certain things that require to be put on--
—Well, get on with it.

—In that case, will the Minister, firstly, find out for me the date of the contract; secondly, tell me the nature of the system of procurement; and, thirdly, tell me who evaluated the tenders and what the level of expertise in the tenders was? Will he then relate that to answer (e), which says that the FAC project manager, Mr Ross Carlton, travelled to Europe in November and December in order to attend a series of design review meetings of the German works because-heaven forbid!-he had never seen the operation of an automatic baggage system before? Therefore, as we can see from his itinerary, he popped off all around Europe to have a look at some. He went to Zurich, Milan and Changi Airport in Singapore. Will the Minister tell me whether this is the man who was part of the evaluation process-this man who had never seen a system in operation? What is the level of expertise of the evaluation system that was used?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was excellent. As a result of some sensible, and I must say, reasonable--
—Stand up when you are going to talk.
—I beg your pardon, Senator Macdonald?
—Why don't you stand up when you want to talk?
—I ask the Minister to ignore that interjection.
—I think Senator Macdonald should usually be ignored. I thought that was a question, actually.
—You are treating the chamber with contempt.
—Senator MacGibbon should talk to his colleague. I now realise what he said.
—Why do you not stand up?
—Why do you not stop being a smart arse?
—It is better than being a loudmouth.

—This is not assisting the process at all. If Senator Macdonald wants to assist, why does he not go away where he can do something useful? As a result of some sensible inquiries I received from some sensible members of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, I did make some inquiries of the FAC.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Macdonald has obviously had a long dinner. I did make some inquiries and I received an exhaustive briefing on the processes that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) went into. I was satisfied that it had scrupulously provided for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport-and that was the purpose of the exercise-the best equipment which in its view was available.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Bishop's rage about going overseas, these baggage systems are in the process of enormous recent technological change. The bar codes and the kind of equipment being provided internationally is state of the art. Indeed many airports around the world-I understand currently only three or four in the United States; that is how new it is-are installing this kind of equipment. The bar code systems are not simply important for shifting the bags, the principal concern these days in providing this kind of technology is security. It was entirely appropriate to send an officer to examine systems in place overseas, which currently do not exist in any airport in Australia, of the state of the art equipment the FAC is planning to install at the new international terminal at Sydney.

I have looked at the answers given to the questions without notice raised by Senator Bishop during the Estimates Committee hearing and I am perfectly satisfied with the detail provided. At this stage we cannot ascertain the date on which the contract was awarded; I do not imagine the world hangs on that, but we will certainly obtain that information. However, the rest of the information provided for the remainder of the questions the honourable senator actually asked is more than adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I asked the date is fairly simple: did Mr Charlton go overseas to inspect these baggage handling systems, which I might add had been in existence overseas for years, before or after the contract was awarded? Was he part of the evaluation of the tender? If so, what expertise did he have to exercise in evaluation if he had never seen such things in operation? That is the point of the date of the contract.

SPEECH.PARA: We can then go to the question of subcontracts. It was only when I received these answers that we knew that the awarding of the subcontract worth $1.3m, not to the Australian company which tendered for $1m, was a question not for the Federal Airports Corporation but for the prime contractor. Fairly legitimately I am interested to know these salient points.

In addition, I want to know why no attention was paid to the procurement of the Australia and New Zealand equipment at the subcontracting level when the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is able to tell me that he believes there will be a component of 60 per cent. How does he know that if he did not inquire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, one has to be careful when one personally intervenes in tender processes.
—Ask Senator Bolkus.

—My point is that one has to be careful, because making even a simple inquiry, as I found in this case, of the process results in direct representations being made, as they were to me, by every one of the failed tenderers, expecting some direct consideration from the Government about why they did not get their bid up. That is not an unusual situation to be involved in, but one has to be careful about being involved in it in order to ensure that people understand that it is the responsibility of the Federal Airports Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will undertake to get answers for the additional questions Senator Bishop wants answered. The officers present cannot provide them, although they have provided quite detailed answers to the questions on baggage handling contracts, which I think are adequate.

I have been provided with an additional piece of information that the contract documentation, which I will read out precisely because it may not be the precise answer to Senator Bishop's question, was `signed under seal with the company and announced on 7 October 1990'. It is no good Senator Bishop grinning like the Cheshire Cat; in fact, she does not look a bit like the Cheshire Cat-come to think of it, he was quite a lovable creature-so I will withdraw that remark.

I do not know, but the officer concerned may well have gone to examine these systems, which are, I assure Senator Bishop, state of the art-in fact the bar codes they use have only recently been introduced-because he wanted to familiarise himself with the introduction of the systems in the process of having them installed at Sydney Airport. I will inquire about that and provide an answer to Senator Bishop as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to that answer from an observer's point of view, people will understand why people asking questions get frustrated. I have no idea what Cheshire cats have got to do with answering facts regarding the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). My concern is this: it was Senator Bolkus who was intervening in a contract; the questions I am asking the Minister are not for the purposes of requesting him to intervene. I simply want to know whether or not proper procedures were followed in accordance with laid-down procurement guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: My interest is that in the future we get better results. Never ever have I suggested that the Minister, or anybody else, ought to intervene in a contract. What I am saying is that I want the Minister to satisfy this Parliament that the FAC has exercised its procurement on the basis of best value for money and in accordance with the ANZ guidelines. These are fairly simple, straightforward questions that could be answered in a simple, straightforward answer, without all the snide innuendo that the Minister seems to enjoy indulging in.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already said twice-perhaps Senator Bishop was not listening so I will say it for the third time in direct answer to her question-yes, I examined the procedure in response to representations I received from members of the Opposition in the House of Representatives. Yes-I will say it for the third time-I was satisfied that the FAC had carried out those procedures correctly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April 1991, a number of unanswered questions were incorporated by the Committee in its report. Those questions had been on notice for some considerable time to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). However, the answers were subsequently given to me. One question raised the issue of the new airport facilities at both the Darwin and Alice Springs terminals. I asked a four-point question which related to: the construction timetables and the proposed expenditure; timetable dates; details with regard to the redesign of each of the projects and any financial variations; and specifically, in part four, what proportion of subcontracts in respect of Darwin and Alice Springs airports for supply, services and labour have been let to contractors-suppliers outside the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Information was provided with regard to both Darwin and Alice Springs airports independently. I note that most of the information provided related to structural matters such as steelwork, aerobridges, baggage handling, electrical services and a number of similar-type contracts. I am concerned that one of the issues not addressed by the Federal Airports Corporation relates to the provision of what could probably be described as artworks in both of those new airport terminals. I have pursued this matter independently with the Federal Airports Corporation for some months.

Some time ago, I was advised by the Manager of the Federal Airports Corporation in Darwin, Mr Santalucia, that approximately one per cent of the project figure was being appropriated for the provision of suitable art and craft works in both of the facilities. That would therefore involve subcontracts in respect of provision of art and crafts works at Darwin Airport in the vicinity of some $500,000 and, for Alice Springs, in the vicinity of some $200,000. None of this, of course, is mentioned in the answer that was provided. The issue is important because, like the questions that Senator Bishop has been asking, it is the process of procurement that actually concerns me.

I note that, in a press statement of 25 March 1991, the Federal Airports Corporation detailed a specific policy with regard to art for overseas visitors which it intends to adopt as an arts policy for Federal airports right around Australia. Much of what is stated in that media release follows the representations that I had been making to the Corporation for some specific time with regard to Darwin and Alice Springs airports. I am concerned that what was being allocated as a percentage of the new tender works is now being gobbled up. We have nothing but gobbledegook with regard to broad, general aims and the appointment by the FAC of a new arts policy which has been developed `with the guidance of eminent adviser, the former Chief Executive of the Australia Council, Dr Jean Battersby'. The release went on:
In the future the commissioning or acquisition of artworks will be an integral part of the building design process when the Corporation is adding new facilities or refurbishing existing ones.
All suitable creative media will be used including painting, sculpture, tapestry, mosaics, photography and craftworks to illustrate the breadth of Australian talent.
We intend making our airports better introductions to Australia and its principal regions and play a major role in the community . . .

I do not dispute the necessity to have artworks, but what I want to pursue specifically is the fact that, as to the subcontracts of the new terminals, as acknowledged in the media release, I have been unable to get sufficient and up to date information as to how the process of the expenditure of some $500,000 for Darwin and $200,000 for Alice Springs is, in effect, to be adopted, incorporated or tendered-or whatever the process is.

I am certainly aware that Dr Battersby has made a number of visits to the Northern Territory. She has consulted different groups. She has obviously antagonised different groups. She has made very provocative statements about the availability and the standard of Northern Territory art. I would certainly dispute those provocative and, in fact, critical comments, because, as I believe Senator Collins would acknowledge, there are hundreds of very fine craftsmen and artists of international standard in the Northern Territory, all of whose works I believe should be available to be incorporated for the local colour and quality that can be added to both Darwin and Alice Springs airports.

I am concerned that the issue obviously does not have the sympathetic consideration of the Federal Airports Corporation. For example, I was speaking to the executives of the Arts Council of the Northern Territory recently, who advised me that they have not received any acknowledgment or follow-up to their letter to the Federal Airports Corporation of 10 December 1990, in which they raised a series of questions following a meeting with Dr Battersby. They sought clarification of a number of points: the commissioning or direct purchase of artworks; the perceived role of any advisory committee, which I believe has never functioned nor worked; the FAC policy regarding the purchase of, in particular, the work of local artists; and what budgetary allocations had been established in respect of, in the case of this letter, the installation of artworks for Alice Springs.
Similarly, I received a letter from the Crafts Council of the Northern Territory Inc., over the signature of Leonie McNally, the Executive Director, and dated 30 April 1991. I will read the letter:
Re: New Airport Terminals-Darwin and Alice Springs.

The Board of Management and the members of the Crafts Council of the Northern Territory wish to record their disappointment in relation to the lack of commissioned art and craftworks from the European arts industry of the Northern Territory.

As you would be aware our artistic community makes a significant contribution to tourism and the general economy of the Northern Territory. The Crafts Council of the NT is saddened at the loss of opportunity to showcase our talent and create further employment for Territorians.
The Northern Territory's point of difference, our multicultural society and unique flora and fauna can only be truly reflected by Territorians.
We would welcome an opportunity to discuss this further with you.

I have also received written representations, which I do not have with me at present, from the Fine Arts Department of the University College of the Northern Territory. I am well aware that the principal of that Department has been seeking to discuss this matter now for some months with the Federal Airports Corporation without success or acknowledgment of the representations that have been made.

Given that the amounts of money that are to be allocated-some $500,000 for Darwin airport and some $200,000 for Alice Springs-I should have thought that there would have been a proper process to ensure the involvement of local personalities drawn from the Northern Territory, to ensure that the selection of that art and craft properly reflects the character and representations of Northern Territory artists. We should not have to rely on some adviser imported from Sydney or elsewhere who wanders into town, talks with ministerial staff and other executive officers around the Northern Territory but who is unable to accommodate the wishes of Territorians about such an important event.

I would ask that the Minister clarify the matter, particularly with regard to the fact that in the answer provided to me there is no detail of the significant sums of money that are to be allocated from the budgets and the construction programs as acknowledged by the FAC in its own media release for these two most important airports, which I hope Senator Collins will be opening in the next few months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons why I would imagine that these amounts of money were not included was that they were special appropriations made by the board of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). It is to the great credit of the Federal Airports Corporation that it made these appropriations at all in the current tough times.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to work myself into a lather over the artworks for either airport terminal because my view is that over the years both those terminals will be effectively used to showcase Northern Territory artists, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. Frankly, it would not have surprised me if the Federal Airports Corporation had decided to either remove that amount of money or substantially downgrade it because it is, relatively speaking and in terms of the cost of art, not a huge amount.

The other thing I hope we will be able to do in respect of some very innovative ideas that were proposed by Northern Territory artists is to persuade-and I do not think this will be difficult when times get better-the major operators of the airport, that is, the airlines that use them principally, to commission artworks for the building.

The angst that Senator Tambling feels about comments that might have been made by Jean Battersby are nothing to the angst that I feel about comments that I am told were made by the Northern Territory Minister for Education and the Arts, Shane Stone, in respect of what he thought should go in. Those comments horrified me. I have to tell Senator Tambling that it does not matter whether one is talking about constructing airport terminals, town halls or any other public buildings, there is bound to be a more intense debate about the colour the walls are painted-and I have been involved in that too-and the design of the carpet than anything else. As Senator Tambling would be well aware, there has been a very lively debate about the carpet that will be used in the Darwin Airport terminal, which has seemed to almost totally preoccupy the people currently involved in building it.

My view is that I do not particularly like it, but I am sure it will grow on me. I can remember a council in a Northern Territory town telling me only recently that it had a half-hour debate on the appropriation to construct a multi-million dollar building but spent six months talking about the colour of the carpet and the design of the chairs for the chamber. I am not surprised at that because we will never satisfy all of the demands of the multitude of organisations involved in producing art and craft. As is truly said, beauty is very much in the eye of the beholder.

Frankly, I think the FAC is rightly proud, as is John Holland Pty Ltd, of the extraordinary percentage of major contract work which has, by deliberate policy of the organisation, gone to Northern Territory companies. It is a proud record indeed. As Senator Tambling would be aware, in excess of 70 per cent of the total construction of both airport terminals, that is, $80m worth, has gone to Northern Territory companies.

I think I can say that, without exception, the only work-some of it is major in terms of cost-that has not gone to Northern Territory companies is for contracts for the provision of baggage handling facilities, lifts and other specialist steel fabrication and so on which Northern Territory companies are simply not in a position to provide. It is a proud record of delivery to Northern Territory business which has been achieved. The FAC is rightly proud of it, and so am I. It has been achieved by a deliberate policy of giving preference, wherever possible, to Northern Territory firms.

I can understand the concern that is being expressed. Personally, having seen what is being proposed and having had a number of meetings with Jean Battersby, I think Territorians and the visitors who will be coming through those airport terminals, both domestic and international, will be very pleased with the result that will be there on opening day. It cannot be the final result, because it is a relatively small amount of money, considering the cost of some of the works for the terminals. I have no doubt that as the years proceed the project will be added to significantly. I trust the bulk of the art work that will go into both buildings will be from Northern Territory artists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not in any way disputing the amount of money allocated to this important project, but what the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has failed to clarify for me is the very same issue as I believe Senator Bishop was pursuing, which is the financial and other aspect relating to the process of the selection, whether it is by tender or consultants. Has Dr Battersby walked out and purchased $700,000 worth of art of her own choice, or has she had a process that has involved a selection panel, either in the artistic area or to assess the financial contributions?

SPEECH.PARA: What degree of consistency has been applied to ensure that such important projects also draw on the local available artists and craftsmen of the Northern Territory? To what extent is the art being put into these buildings commissioned interstate and provided from other than the Northern Territory? Those issues are being raised by the Fine Arts Department of the Northern Territory University College, the Arts Council and the Crafts Council of the Northern Territory.

These are issues that I would be most concerned about if, in future, the selection has been left entirely to the choice and style, either financially or otherwise, of Dr Battersby or people who have worked close to her. I ask the Minister for an assurance that there has been no political involvement in the choice by any Minister, by any member of Parliament or by their staffs in the selection of this particular art work.
Tuesday, 4 June 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give Senator Tambling a very firm assurance that I did not choose the carpet for the Darwin Airport terminal. I must say I think that is a very strange question. I have not the slightest interest, frankly, nor do I have the time,-not even approaching it-in directly involving myself in putting political influence into what paintings or art works are hung in the Darwin and Alice Springs airport terminals.
—You don't appreciate art.

—No, I am a philistine. I have no difficulty in saying to Senator Tambling that no, there has been no political involvement in selecting art works; but yes, the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has deliberately chosen, I have to say, a very eminent Australian as the consultant for the art works. Jean Battersby has had years of experience, as Senator Tambling knows, with the Australia Council and since her time with the Australia Council, and is considered to be an authority in providing consultancy for this sort of work. I simply say again that I take on board Senator Tambling's concerns. I sympathise with them; but in the art business-I know this is a fact-one will never satisfy everyone.
—Put a selection panel around.

—I have to respond to that. I think we are a lot safer appointing one eminent consultant rather than a panel. I say again, in terms of the head shaking and Senator Bishop's latter-day interest in the Darwin and Alice Springs airport terminals, that at a time when things are not too flush the FAC is rightly proud of $80m-worth of investment in two brand new, long overdue and badly needed airport terminals in Alice Springs and Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to work myself up into a lather about current concerns regarding the art work in those buildings because I think inevitably the art work is going to become very much a moveable feast. I have no doubt that the major users of the buildings, when they are able to, will substantially contribute to the commissioning of new art works. I know that Senator Tambling is pursuing the questions, with my blessing, with the FAC directly and I know that he will be provided with the detailed answers he is seeking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) advise us how this figure of one per cent for art works was set? Why was it not 2 per cent? Why was it not 5 per cent? Why was it not zero? These are public funds; surely the first determinant here is to have a clean and efficient terminal, not something that is an indulgence for people in the art world, particularly when the people are paying for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am with Senator MacGibbon. In fact, I agree with him absolutely and I am sorry that he was not listening when I said that. I just said a few minutes ago-I will repeat it for Senator MacGibbon's benefit-that in the current economic circumstances I would not have blamed the Federal Airports Corporation Board, which made this decision, had it taken a decision not to proceed. I think there would have been howls of outrage-from me too, frankly-from the Northern Territory's representatives, and particularly Senator Tambling in view of what he has just said, if a decision had been made to cut off all art work to the buildings. I am not so much of a philistine as to think that we should spend $80m on two airport terminals without at least putting some modest degree of art work in them.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the total construction costs of that terminal and the $15m-worth of foundation work that was already in place and was utilised and had been put there during the previous construction, and with the $56m-worth of new construction, half a million dollars is a relatively modest amount of money to spend on art work. The building is going to cost in the vicinity of $70m-odd when it is finally constructed. I would not have blamed the FAC if it had decided-it would have been a controversial decision-not to appoint anybody. Perhaps that would have got Senator Tambling off my back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Senate to a question that Senator Bishop put on notice regarding Ross Carlton's overseas itinerary. Public spending has been mentioned, so if you do not mind, Madam Chair, I will ask a few supplementary questions even though the hour is late. I notice that Ross Carlton departed Sydney via Singapore Airlines, arrived in Zurich the next day and inspected automated baggage systems there. The next day he decided to travel to Milan by train. Knowing that that is a touristy sort of track, which I am sure is dearer than air travel, I was wondering why he took the train, except that it does go through St Moritz and the Bernina Pass as well.

SPEECH.PARA: He got to Milan that evening and he could not have done much inspection because he was off to London. From my experience of Linate airport in Milan-there are two airports there-I would say that it would be the last place on earth anyone would go to have a look at a baggage system, because it is the No. 1 place in the world for losing baggage. However, he decided to carry on to London. Then, after conducting his English inspections, he went back to Europe, did the European tour and went back to London. Then he came home with Continental Airlines.

We are expected to travel overseas with Qantas and return with Qantas, and I believe it is a pleasure to travel with Qantas, so why does Mr Carlton not qualify for the same treatment? Why should he take a touristy train when he can travel more cheaply? Why should he do it in two sections? Why did he not clean up Europe before he went to London, do the English tour and come home, preferably on Qantas instead of Continental Airlines?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the Federal Airports Corporation why he caught the train. That was the question, and I will provide Senator Panizza with an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now want to ask a question, still involving the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), concerning Sydney Earthmoving Pty Ltd, about which I asked questions, some of which were noted as questions remaining unanswered and some questions, which are in the Hansard, remain unanswered. We have received answers to two of the questions I asked on page 21 of Additional Information Received, volume 4, which read:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) What is FAC's relationship with Sydney Earthmoving Pty Limited?
(b) What is the likely source of landfill for the third runway?
Part of the answer to question (b) reads:

A number of sources and types of fill were discussed. Although no conclusions are reached in the report, demolition waste was noted as having a disadvantage in that the estimated annual production in Sydney is only three million cubic metres. However, if it were to be used it would not need processing as provided by Sydney Earthmoving Pty Limited.

I refer to the Hansard record of what Mr Ramsey said. I might say at the outset that I did write to the Minister and ask for these witnesses to come. I found it curious at the time that, having acceded to my request, the Minister then seemed to intercede for and on behalf of the officers of whom I was asking questions, on the basis-I can only assume-that I was only allowed to ask them nice questions. We had two people. One was a public relations sort of person and the other one was a financial person.

I did ask specific questions about the landfill. My information had been that there would be a traditional supplier who would perhaps be using metal from various quarries for the fill for the third runway and that the cost would be $23 to $28 a tonne delivered. Mr Ramsey replied that he had no way of knowing, even in his wildest dreams, what the cost of the fill would be, but he thought that $23 a metre delivered onto the site would be too much and that perhaps it would be sand at the rate of $3 or $4. Then he said:
I would like to check that before you took it as firm evidence . . . Certainly, I do not believe there is any intention by the Corporation to use land based fill for the third runway.

The questions I want to ask the Minister are: is there to be a single supplier of fill; what are the various types of fill that are being considered; and what is the approximate price of that fill to be supplied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the kind of fill that is being considered, all of that information is contained in detail in the draft environmental impact statement with the pros and cons of each kind of fill. Those assumptions, of course, will have to change without question as the project develops. For example, initial testing in an area where it was hoped 50 per cent of the fill was to be recovered from-that is, the space between the two runways-has already been found to be unsuitable for such a purpose because it is too elastic for that purpose. Clearly, that will change after further evaluation of the various options that are being examined.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of whether there will be a single supplier of the fill could hardly be determined if a final decision on the actual kind of fill that will be provided has not been made. Not only has land fill been considered but also, as the draft environmental impact statement points out, industrial waste and slag waste from blast furnaces is being looked at. There is a whole range of fill, but that is a long way from making a decision about any of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, I am interested that in answer to a question the Minister said that there is a need for 11 million cubic metres of fill. Presumably that is subject to further consideration as well. There is an estimate that annual production in Sydney of demolition waste is only 3 million cubic metres a year. Could the Minister tell me what is the basis of that calculation and, indeed, as he says there is likely to be a number of sources of fill, why that source would be ruled out.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be. Can I point out the difference between the two propositions. I would have thought that Senator Bishop herself would have realised this. The reason why 11 million cubic metres of fill can be accurately identified for the runway is that we know how long the runway is going to be, how wide it is going to be and how deep it is going to be. It is not too difficult to work out how many million cubic metres of fill are needed for it. As the draft environmental impact statement points out, quite clearly there are number of various sources being considered for the fill. Further engineering evaluation will need to be conducted when that matter becomes firmer after the Government makes a final decision on whether the construction of the runway will go ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that the design and shape of the third runway is immutable. I am very pleased that it will go ahead and be built. I am glad that the Minister is accurately able to calculate how much fill is required and that we can look forward to it starting fairly soon. I would be most interested, on that basis, for the Minister to supply us, once we get started, with the sources of that fill and the number of suppliers who are likely to be engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Minister is at it, if he looks at pages 90 and 91 of the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard he might be able to answer the question that I tried to ask of his official no less than half a dozen times, and that is, is it a practice that people who do receive contracts from the Federal Airports Corporation make a habit of providing entertainment for officers of the FAC? I could not get an answer last time; perhaps the Minister has been able to think about it and can provide me with one this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder Senator Macdonald is laughing. She is hilarious, isn't she?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not particularly. Very ordinary, I would have said. I have directed that question to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) but, frankly, I do not expect to get an earth-shattering response. I can remember receiving a previous complaint-not from Senator Bishop but from another honourable senator-about alleged excesses of the FAC in terms of entertaining. It turned out, on examination, to involve one relatively small reception in a town where the FAC owned an airport and were engaged in a visit of the board to the town to meet the local aviation community, and it had bunged on a reception to meet them. I am happy to follow this up, but Senator Bishop could assist in the process if she gave some detail-and perhaps she could do it now-of the alleged excesses in which the FAC has been accused of indulging.

—I think the Minister has missed the point of the question. I asked whether it was the practice of those companies which receive contracts to do the entertaining. That is what I am interested in, and I think the Minister might even find there is some interest in the lower House in the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been my experience over the years that companies-and I have been to many-which are successful in getting very large contracts normally do have some kind of an occasion to mark the fact that they have successfully got the contract and are about to commence work on it. I have pursued this matter with the FAC and I will get an answer, but I will not be at all surprised, which is why I said it will not be earth-shattering, to find that the answer is yes. It would be normal practice, I would imagine, for almost any company that got a major contract to have some sort of a function to mark it.
—I thank the Minister and I look forward to receiving that answer. Perhaps when he finds the answer, he would be good enough to let me know just who those firms are.
—I will not get the answer and keep it to myself, I promise the honourable senator.

—Can we move to the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) and to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). This follows on from the question that I asked previously. I will not repeat that question. The Minister has answered already about the problems that have been had with the stocktake for two years. It has been said that the stocktake will be completed by the end of this financial year. Is there any evidence of items going missing at the SBS as a result of that stocktake as there was with the previous one two years ago? In other words, is the situation the same as that which exists in the ABC?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the officers that the stocktake to this point in time has not revealed any discrepancies; but it is continuing.

—I have a question relating to the broadcast by the SBS of the soccer, which matter I raised during the Estimates hearings. Does the Minister have any knowledge of what the arrangement is to be for the ensuing year concerning the broadcast of World Cup soccer? Is it to be covered by the SBS alone? Is it to be broadcast in cooperation with the ABC? If so, are they to have a better arrangement by way of partnership than they had in the past year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The information is that the SBS already has exclusive rights to the next two World Cup soccer matches. Obviously there will be renegotiation after that, but for the next two years it already has exclusive rights.
—What price does it have to pay for those rights?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just over $900,000 for the first final. A final price has not yet been arrived at for the one after that.
—Does the SBS require an additional appropriation to be able to afford that or will it be able to cut back on something else? If so, what?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no.
—The answer is no, they do not get an additional appropriation, but what about cutting back on something else to be able to afford it?

—We did canvass this matter at some considerable length, despite Senator Bishop's concerns about being cut off. As I recall, in terms of actual time, she was engaged for almost an entire hour in questioning the officers on that very point. They are programming decisions to be made by the SBS and, I have to say, are so far down the track in terms of the current Supplementary Estimates processes that I really do not see the point of pursuing them here. The cost is in excess of $900,000 for the first World Cup. The SBS has the exclusive rights for the next two years, and the price has yet to be negotiated for the one after that.

—The Minister could have halved the time it took him to answer that question if he had left out the invective and just given the facts. My next question relates to the answer that was given to me in response to a question that I had on notice about the SBS covering the launch of Beijing's bid for the Olympic Games. The answer that has been given to me is that three people travelled in China for five days to produce four stories. Later in the answer the Department says that, earlier in the year, the SBS journalist undertaking the project received a grant from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for the specific purpose of shooting the stories in China. The value of the grant was $7,500, thus the net cost to the SBS was $1,000. What were the terms and conditions of the grant that they sought and what stories did they identify they would be covering at the time they received the grant from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not know that detail, but I will try to find out. It is 12.25 a.m., and I think that we had better pursue how this $1,000 dollars was spent. I will try to provide Senator Bishop with the most complete answer I can. There is a letter from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to SBS, addressed to Miss Jenny Sheer, SBS sport, who is the journalist concerned, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to advise that your recent application for funding under the North East Asian media visits program for Australian journalists was successful. Your proposal was among seven selected by the assessment panel.

It goes on to describe the panel and the amount of money that she is getting. It then talks about the conditions of the award, but does not go into the detail. We will have to seek further advice on the actual details of the award. The letter goes on to say that a report will be required at the completion of the trip and any material-that is, clippings and so on-produced as a result of the trip. It then goes on to congratulate the journalist for being successful. There are no details attached to this brief of the actual conditions placed on the award, but I will certainly undertake to provide that to Senator Bishop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The relevant word in that letter that was read out is `proposal'-what was proposed and what the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade acceded to. Perhaps the Minister could find out exactly what the proposal was for the four programs and if there was a change to cover the Beijing launch. The Minister will recall that the reason I raised it is that Sydney has indeed launched a bid for the same Olympic Games. It was rather curious that we had Australian taxpayers' money covering somebody else's launch for the Olympic Games. Can the Minister can tell whether there was a change between the time of the proposal being made and the grant being awarded and the actual programs that were decided to be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should not rise to speak in this debate at 12.30 in the morning, but I will.
—Sit down, then.
—At least I can stand up. The facts are that Senator Bishop-
—He is proving that he can stand up.
—You are making a fool of yourself, Senator.
—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. We have had two unparliamentary and quite insulting observations from the Minister and I ask him to withdraw.
—Would the Minister please withdraw the offending remarks.
—Of course, I will withdraw.
—Don't say it in the first place.

—The honourable senator could take that matter up with his colleagues. If they want to raise these matters, they require responding to. Senator Bishop asserted that her reason for these inquiries, and it is true, was the extraordinary proposition that because Sydney was properly launching a bid, and she just repeated it again, for the Olympic Games, then SBS television should not cover or broadcast the launch of a bid for another country. That is what was said in the Hansard, and I refer members to it.
—Exactly right.
—Senator Bishop says, `Exactly right'. What an extraordinary proposition. I want all honourable senators to understand the point that Senator Bishop was making. She has just reaffirmed it.

SPEECH.PARA: Constantly in this chamber we hear cries of political interference being such a dreadful thing. We get told by people such as Senator Bishop that we as a government should crack down-and that was the whole point of the exercise; there are pages of it in the Hansard-on SBS for having the hide to record an event which, let me tell you, was getting a fair bit of world press at the time in relation to the Asian games that were being held conjointly. Senator Bishop is putting the extraordinary proposition that the Government should constrain SBS-or it should be censured, at least-from giving reporting and air time to a competing bid for the Olympic Games because Australia is putting in a bid. I say to Senator Bishop that that is a pretty extraordinary proposition, with respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am constrained to remember the ceremony that was conducted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and this Government in the Great Hall of this building on the occasion of Tiananmen Square.
