I am occasioned to remember that there was an outcry against the behaviour that occurred there and that we maintained that rage for a long period. Indeed, I am constrained to remember that our wool trade suffered because of the actions that we took. Yet we find that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade could find money so that the SBS could cover the Beijing opening.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Minister is a lobbyist par excellence. He holds himself out that way. He knows as well as anybody else in this chamber that, when it comes to the question of lobbying in the international community to obtain those gains, the nuances of whether one country covers an opponent's bid is a very important issue. To sit there and say in a grand style that somehow it is irrelevant and that it is just nice entertainment just does not wash.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am constrained to remind you that we have officers here from SBS. I ask whether there are any further questions for them, or whether they may be allowed to go.
—They do not have homes to go to! Has Senator Bishop finished with SBS?
—The Minister undertook to get me the information; I would be delighted to receive it.
—Has Senator Bishop finished with SBS?
—Yes, I am prepared to move on to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the officers from the SBS. What have we been listening to for the past month from the Opposition with respect to a piece of legislation which we are putting through this Parliament? An absolutely undiminished parade of mewling, puking, hypocritical humbug about constraining free speech, is it not-constraining the freedom of the media and daring to suggest that paid political advertising, which is pretty riveting stuff at the best of times, not be permitted on television. Senator Bishop is quite happy to confirm on behalf of the Opposition that we are supposed to censure or prevent in some way the SBS television network from broadcasting the launch of a Chinese bid for the next Olympic Games; that is extraordinary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we move on to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and away from SBS, that was a pathetic attempt by the Minister. What we are talking about is the allocation of funds from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is taxpayers' money that we are talking about. If Beijing wants to come here and put paid advertising on Australian television, that is fine, but I do not want the taxpayers of Australia to pay for its advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to the ABC. While we are dealing with the question of what is paid for by taxpayers' money, let us look at the way in which the ABC chooses to put some sporting programs to air. I asked the Minister in the Estimates hearings who made the decision about who was to pay fees to the ABC to get a particular sport to air. The answer that was provided at page 13 of Additional Information Received, volume 3, says:

Under section 25(5) of the Act the ABC is prevented from receiving external funding for programs other than government bodies or from bona fide co-producers or organisers of public entertainment. Co-production monies received in respect of sporting events invariably fall within the latter category.

The interesting thing is that there seems to be one rule for some and another rule for others. Because the co-production fee is required to be paid, sporting bodies are required to go out and organise sponsorship, and the sponsorship then, in the arbitrary nature of the ABC, seems to be left off the screens.

I return to page 14 of the same information booklet and deal particularly with the 1990 Dunlop Footwear National Netball Championship, where the All Australian Netball Association Ltd was required to pay $40,000 in order to get its program to air. This relates to the program `Goal Attack', which involved coverage of all the Mobil Superleague of netball. It is my understanding that there is a ruling that, despite the fact that Mobil Oil Australia Ltd is its sponsor, someone in the ABC has made the decision that the word `Mobil' shall be censored from the program. Could the Minister confirm that that is true?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The board provides the guidelines that govern this matter, I am advised. If it is necessary for information, then the sponsor will be named. In respect of Senator Bishop's particular complaints about co-sponsorship and in terms of the arrangements that are entered into for co-production, it is usually the smaller sports rather than the larger sports that are available for the purposes of co-production.

—I think if the Minister does an analysis of the sports that are covered and looks at the source material he may be able to have access to, he will find that is not true. He will find, indeed, that the co-production fees that are payable by large organisations are really quite small, that things like women's golf pay a very large percentage of the co-production fee, and that, in fact, the co-production fee amounts to a de facto purchase of air time, because if one does not come up with the co-production fee the program does not get to air. But the question I was asking very specifically about the Mobil Superleague was whether the Board, if that is the body that has made the decision, has in fact made a decision that Mobil is to get no credit for being the sponsor of that superleague.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I did obtain information about the general principles to be applied, but I did not hear that Senator Bishop wanted to know about that particular matter. The officers present in the chamber at this hour do not have that detailed information, but I will give Senator Bishop an undertaking that we will get a specific response for this particular event.

—I wonder whether at the same time the Minister could let me have a list of all the sporting events that went to air in the previous financial year and of the amount of co-production fee that was required to be paid by each of those sporting bodies.
—Certainly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: -I now wish to refer to the answer that I received concerning the assets that went missing from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. As the Minister may remember, I asked a number of questions and I put a question on notice. I was told, in answer to my question, that I would be given a list of the items that went missing. I have in my possession the most extraordinary answer that one could hope to find in relation to the question of missing assets. It does not identify the assets that went missing. It suggests that maybe some went missing. It also tells us that a system has been put in place which makes the people who utilise those assets accountable. The answer then concludes by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: In these circumstances it is inevitable that losses of such items will occur. However, any losses incurred have not been a serious problem nor material in value.
Why has that list not been provided?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will find out. I will pursue the matter with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. But I am advised that the items that go missing are relatively small beer-if I could use that expression-and to provide that kind of precise detail would be a very extensive and, indeed, expensive exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious matter. Maybe the people on the other side can laugh about it--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators-No, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were laughing about it. But we were informed at the Estimates hearing that those people who were involved in the removal of those assets are no longer in the employ of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). So it was obviously taken relatively seriously by the ABC. I further ask-and when we asked for a list, staff were identified-whether there is any evidence that assets have been taken by people who are not employed by the ABC? Secondly, have any charges been laid against those people who have taken assets?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officer is not aware of any charges having been laid. I want to say, to try to bring this questioning to some sort of conclusion, that I have given Senator Crane an undertaking that I will pursue the matter further with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and I will.

—I will not pursue that matter any further at this point, but I certainly look forward to finding out, firstly, what assets have gone missing and, secondly, why no charges have been laid. My next question is a follow-up to that matter and concerns items that never went on the register, although taxpayers' funds were provided. We were given an undertaking in the Estimates Committee that an answer would be provided in terms of any such items that had not been included on the register although funds had been provided. At this point in time I have not received an answer. What is the reason for this?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just read the answers that have been provided to Senator Crane and, in my view, they are complete answers which provide quite a significant amount of detail to the honourable senator. But if Senator Crane is not satisfied with the detailed answers that have been provided, I will pursue the matter for him with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

—I said initially that the answer which I received to my first question was not satisfactory. I have certainly not received an answer to the question I have just asked about assets on the register, that is, my second question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: -I have an answer in front of me that does appear to provide the answer that Senator Crane is seeking. It does say here that the assets register is integrated into the general register and that a bar code label system has been introduced which matches all of the assets, property, plant and equipment to records that are held in the assets register of the ABC.

—With respect, it is the answer to the ABC question that Senator Crane asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must get a copy of that answer because I have not received it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention tonight to just take a few minutes to address an issue which is of interest to me as I was privileged to be present as a representative of the Parliament at the Nepalese election on 12 May. This of course was significant because it was the first democratic election to be held in that country for 30 years or more since the monarchy intervened in affairs in 1959 and produced an authoritarian system of government which eventually evolved into a process known as panchayat. The panchayat system involved indirect elections to a parliament which lacked influence and a series of local consultations. Those consultations barred organised political parties from involvement in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: A few years ago there emerged a democracy movement in Nepal similar to those that have emerged in other parts of the Asian subcontinent in relatively recent times. The democracy movement consisted of academics and students, trade unionists, human rights activists, people from the legal fraternity and journalists.
There were several bloody clashes during the period of the late 1980s involving the democracy movement and security forces. Between 200 and 500 people died during those clashes.

Ultimately, the movement was successful but not without cost to individuals and to the country as a whole. Nepal is the fourth poorest country in the world, according to the World Bank. Its average income per capita is only $US150 per annum. In over 90 per cent of cases family households are dependent for income on agriculture, and subsistence level agriculture, at that. Nonetheless, even with the problems of the evolution of the democratic movement and the economic constraints within which the new Government which emerged a little over one year ago is operating, it was possible to formulate a new constitution.

The outgoing Prime Minister, Mr K. P. Bhattarai, ought to be commended for the manner in which that constitution was drafted. In particular, the constitution moved away from the panchayat system, which was abandoned, towards a constitutional monarchy built upon a new House of Representatives which consists now of 205 seats. The constitutional process led directly to the general election.

From what the international observers who were present could see, the election campaign was very free and open, certainly by the standards of the subcontinent and, it is fair to say, by world standards. It was a free contest. It consisted of very well attended rallies, of amounts of time allocated between the parties for television and radio, and extensive publication of newspapers. Each political party tended to produce its own newspaper in a broadsheet form. The parties were as wide as the political spectrum could possibly be imagined. In all, some 44 parties or splinters of parties contested the general election. Given the fact that somewhere between 65 per cent and 75 per cent of the people of Nepal are illiterate, the parties were represented by different symbols. The symbols were quite fascinating in their complexity and in their invention.

The Nepali Congress Party, the major party as it turned out, was represented by the tree, which could be seen in most parts of the country, particularly in Kathmandu, and various other symbols were employed by other political organisations. For example, the United Marxist Leninists (UML)-somewhat of a misnomer in view of the party's platform and personalities-was represented by the sun, but there were symbols as different as umbrellas, water taps, eye glasses, various farm animals and crops, right through to relatively modern affectations. All these symbols were employed to represent the political parties.

The voting system employed on the day was ingenious. People simply needed to allocate a stamp with their respective party's symbol reflected on the stamp to register a formal vote. The presence of international observers, including the Australians, really came as an initiative of the Nepalese Government and an organisation called the Nepal Election Observers Committee (NEOC). NEOC really consisted of many of the people who had been selected in the democratic movement. They had taken an active interest in the formation of the democratic process in its infancy and saw it through.

International observers came from right around the globe, including Europe, north America, Asia and the Pacific, whilst the Indian subcontinent was particularly well represented. There is a lot of interest in this Parliament in the affairs of the subcontinent. I know that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has a particular interest in Nepal and Bhutan, as do Senator Maguire and Senator Teague in the Indian subcontinent generally. There was a very wide representation of observers from the democratic political institutions right around the globe, such as the various electoral commissions, human rights activists, political parties and the like. They were allocated to different parts of the country. Some 30 districts right throughout the country were covered during the course of the election. In my case, I went to a district called Sindhupalchowk, which was close to the Tibetan border.

Polling day, by world standards, was well organised. Police were on hand at most of the polling stations. Armed police and military patrols were out, owing to the practice of ballot-box stuffing which is so widespread in other parts of the region. We saw that recently, and most unfortunately, in India.

Election officials, party scrutineers and the like were able to operate freely in the overwhelming majority of cases. There were some unfortunate incidents that tended to mar the process, but overall it was a free and fair ballot in terms of the manner in which it was organised, the votes that were cast and the votes that were counted. In the aftermath, where irregularities were reported to the Electoral Commission, many polling stations had their votes cancelled as being invalid and having been the product of breaches of electoral laws. When I left Kathmandu, some 38 polling stations had been placed in that category.

Might I say briefly that Australian-Nepalese relations are very warm. The Nepalese people are very generous. From my brief experience and from what our Ambassador in Kathmandu, Les Douglas, explained to us, the Nepalese tend to regard Australians very well. That is particularly the case because of the various kinds of aid projects in which we have been involved since 1966. Since the late 1970s, some 25,000 hectares of Nepal have been reafforested through cooperation between Australian and Nepalese experts. We were able to see some of the projects while we were there.

We have also been active in civil aviation and in bringing Nepalese students to study at Australian institutions. Looking at the work that Mr Douglas and his colleagues in Kathmandu have done, they are to be commended for the manner in which they represent Australia, following on from some very good work done by our first Ambassador, Ms Di Johnstone, from 1986 through to 1989-90.

In Nepal, Australia's interests are to be a good international citizen. The Australian delegation certainly sought to contribute to that process. The election overall was free and fair. We have seen emerge a functioning and effective government, based on the Nepalese Congress Party, and a functioning and effective Opposition, based on the UML. It is a very positive development for that region of the world, coming as it does on the heels of the outbreak of democratic movements around the globe. It was a privilege to be present, and I thank Mr President in particular for the opportunity to be present and to see the election and the emergence of a new democratic government in that part of the globe.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.57 a.m. (Tuesday)

The following answer to a question is a reprint of an answer that appeared at page 2131 of Hansard of 9 April 1991, which contained printing errors:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which communities in Western Australia (WA) participated in the Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) scheme in 1988-89, 1989-90 and/or 1990-91.
(2) What were, or are, the total CDEP funds provided for each WA community in 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91.
(3) Have WA participating communities satisfied full acquittal requirements in respect of all grants prior to and including 1989-90; if not, what are the details of the outstanding requirements.

(4) Have any official reviews expressed reservations or has public criticism, when investigated, revealed any discrepancies or inadequacies with regard to `cash' payments by participating communities or by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) offices; if so, provide details.
(5) Have qualified or unsatisfactory audit reports been received in respect of any participating CDEP community; if so, what are the details (in summary).
(6) Has the ATSIC Office of Audit and Evaluation reviewed, or will it be reviewing, the affairs of any project listed in questions 3, 4 or 5; if so, provide details.
(7) Have fraud or criminal investigations been referred to police authorities in respect of any CDEP project; if so, provide details.

(8) What are the outstanding requirements for each CDEP project arising from the Auditor-General's Report No 12 (1990-91) in respect of community development plans, assessment criteria, priority setting, inaccurate payments, management and accounting training and entitlements, allowances and award payments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been provided with the following information by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) &(2) The Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) scheme was introduced in 1977 in response to requests from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities for employment in development projects as an alternative to unemployment benefits (UB). The CDEP scheme provides a basic grant equivalent to the surrendered benefits and additional grants for administration and capital equipment. CDEP forms an important part of the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy.

(3) Grants prior to 1989/90

With the exception of Upurl Upurlila, 1988/89 and Oombulgurri, 1988/89, there are no outstanding matters in relation to acquittance of CDEP grants prior to 1989/90. The outstanding matters in relation to Upurl Upurlila are in the process of being resolved and acquittance will soon be finalised.

In the case of Oombulgurri, ATSIC grants identified in the audited financial statements do not match actual releases. The Regional Office has taken this matter up with the Community and Auditor and an early resolution is expected.
1989/90 Grants

In the Kununurra Region, audited financial statements are still outstanding for Kalumburu, Mandangala, Woolah, Muliarkar and Lamboo Gunian. Recruitment of additional resources is currently being undertaken to commence the acquittal process of these outstanding grants.
In the Derby/Broome Region, all 1989/90 annual audited financial statements have been examined and, where possible, grants have been acquitted.
Where grants cannot be acquitted at this stage, appropriate action has been undertaken as detailed below:
(a) Queries highlighted in Annual Audited Financial Statements have been raised in correspondence to relevant communities; and
(b) Copies of correspondence where queries have been raised have also been sent to relevant Auditors.
Upon receipt of satisfactory responses, relevant grants can be acquitted.
In this Region, audit reports for 1989/90 have not yet been received from Pender and Mowanjum. The auditor and community Chairperson have been advised of this breach of funding conditions.
In the South Hedland Region, audit reports have been received in the Regional Office but have not yet been analysed.
(4) ATSIC is not aware of an official review expressing reservations or inadequacies with regard to cash payments by any of the Western Australian CDEP communities.
(5) Qualified audit reports have been received for 17 (one third) of the 52 CDEP communities in Western Australia. The communities concerned are:

Djarindjin; Bardi; Lombadina; Junjuwa; Yungngora; Junjuwa (Muludja and Ngalingkadji); Wangkatjungka; Kadjina; Looma; Mulan; Beagle Bay; Punmu; Strelley; Burringurrah; Ngangganawili; and Upurl Upurlila.

The audits reveal a number of shortcomings common to these communities, primarily in the areas of bookkeeping, cash systems and management, records maintenance, and accounting systems and procedures. Problems of this nature are not uncommon in remote communities where experienced staff, qualified accountants and training facilities are all scarce resources.

The Commission has taken steps to rectify inadequacies in all the instances identified by the audit reports. Action undertaken includes implementation of financial management training programs for staff and councillors of several communities; the installation of new financial management, internal control and wages systems in a number of communities; and assistance given to communities in the appointment of bookkeeping or management staff.

(6) An evaluation of Grant Acquittals for all Programs is currently being conducted by the Office of Evaluation and Audit on a national basis. The Office will be involved in an evaluation of CDEP this calendar year.

(7) It was discovered that at Yungngora Community one of the staff members was falsifying names on CDEP wages payments. An amount of between $5,000 and $6,000 was allegedly re-directed to her personal account. The matter was referred to police authorities.

The projects officer at Upurl Upurlila, investigated in connection with payments for items of personal benefit, was charged by the Kalgoorlie Criminal Investigation Bureau, convicted and ordered to undertake 180 hours of community service and to pay restitution of approximately $600.
(8) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PLANS

The Commission acknowledges the importance of community development plans. Work has commenced on developing a program. Both the Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training are examining options for providing assistance to communities in the preparation of community development plans.

Under new administrative arrangements for CDEP, communities will have to provide a CDEP works program when making applications for CDEP grant funds. The works program will comprise a list of projects that the community sees as important to its social, cultural, recreational and economic development.
Communities are being encouraged to develop specific CDEP plans and/or community development plans. The CDEP works program would be an integral part of either of these plans.
ASSESSMENT CRITERIA
All CDEP grants are assessed by the Commission on the annual ``Grant Assessment Form'' which is completed by Regional Officers as part of the annual draft estimates documentation.

In addition to the annual grant assessment all CDEP projects are to be fully reviewed on a three- year cycle commencing in 1991/92. It is envisaged that these reviews will be undertaken by officers from the Commission and the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Social Security.
PRIORITY SETTING

Under new administrative arrangements, priorities for the allocation of CDEP Oncost and Support funds will be determined by Regional Managers in consultation with Regional Councils and CDEP communities and organisations.
INACCURATE PAYMENTS

It is acknowledged that some communities have not always submitted fortnightly variation schedules. However, while this can cause short term inaccuracies, community entitlements are adjusted when subsequent schedules are received.
While delays occur between the Commission and DSS this does not result in over or under payments by ATSIC, as any adjustments necessary (after DSS checking) are made in subsequent quarters.
The lack of sanctions under the standard grant offer have been corrected by additional mandatory special conditions for CDEP.

The administrative changes to the CDEP system to take effect from 1 April 1991 have been designed to simplify the calculation of communities' entitlements and should reduce the possibility of inaccuracies.
MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTING
TRAINING

The lack of qualified Aboriginal people has been a problem for DAA/ATSIC and communities alike. Training initiatives have been taken by DAA/ATSIC and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address this issue.

As a part of new administrative arrangements for CDEP, a Training Needs Schedule and a training program to meet these needs for each CDEP is required. Under the Department of Employment, Education and Training (Training for Aboriginals Program) funding is available for communities to engage a consultant, where appropriate, to prepare training needs analyses and/or training schedules for project participants.
ENTITLEMENTS, ALLOWANCES AND
AWARD PAYMENTS

Since the ANAO audits of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were conducted there has been a significant improvement in the take up rate of the Family Allowance Supplement by CDEP participants. The Department of Social Security is promoting this allowance through its Aboriginal Liaison Officers and Community Agents.
While ATSIC encourages the payment of wages at award rates, the setting of hours worked is left to the discretion of community councils and organisations.

Award coverage for CDEP communities is a complex issue as the nature of the work generally is only part-time. The Commission is currently in the process of contracting a consultant to undertake research into industrial relations issues associated with CDEPs including the question of award coverage.
